ALGONA, IOWA - MUNICIPAL CODE 
____________ 
A Codification of the General Ordinances of 
the City of Algona, Iowa 
____________ 
Beginning with Supp. No. 8, 
Supplemented by Municipal Code Corporation 
____________ 

> 
PREFACE 
    The Algona, Iowa, Municipal Code, originally published by Book Publishing Company in 1988, has been kept current by regular supplementation by Matthew Bender & Company, Inc., its successor in interest. 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 8, Municipal Code Corporation will be keeping this code current by regular supplementation. 
    During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and indexed by the editorial staff of Book Publishing Company under the direction of Paul R. Doster, city attorney. 
    The code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number designates, in sequence, the numbers of the Title, chapter, and section. Thus, Section 2.12.040 is Section .040, located in Chapter 2.12 of Title 2. In most instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions. Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion. 
    In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table, following the text of the code, listing by number all ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification; and beginning with Supplement No. 8, legislation can be tracked using the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
    A subject-matter index, with complete cross-referencing, locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers. 
    This supplement brings the Code up to date through Ordinance 1039, passed November 5, 2018. 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
800-262-2633 
HOW TO USE YOUR CODE 
    This code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials, city employees and private citizens. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code. 
Numbering System. 
    The numbering system is the backbone of a Code of Ordinances; Municipal Code Corporation uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this Code. It is based on three tiers, beginning with title, then chapter, and ending with section. Each part is represented in the code section number. For example, Section 2.04.010 is Section .010, in Chapter 2.04 of Title 2. 
Title. 
    A title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled. This code contains about 15 to 20 titles. For example, the first title is Title 1, General Provisions, which may contain ordinances about the general penalty, code adoption and definitions. The titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference. Some titles are Reserved for later use. 
Chapter. 
    Chapters deal with more specific subjects, and are often derived from one ordinance. All of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title. The chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material. For example, Chapter 2.06, City Manager, can be added between 2.04, City Council, and Chapter 2.08, City Attorney. 
Section. 
    Each section of the code contains substantive ordinance material. The sections are numbered by "tens" to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering. 
Tables of Contents. 
    There are many tables of contents in this code to assist in locating specific information. At the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title. In addition, each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters and sections, respectively. 
Ordinance History Note. 
    At the end of each code section, you will find an "ordinance history note," which lists the underlying ordinances for that section. The ordinances are listed by number, section (if applicable) and year. (Example: (Ord. 272 § 1, 1992).) 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 8, a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections. Ordinance history notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end. These history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index. 
Statutory References. 
    The statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality. As the statutes are revised, these references will be updated. 
Cross-Reference Table. 
    When a code is based on an earlier codification, the cross-reference table will help users find older or "prior" code references in the new code. The cross-reference table is located near the end of the code, under the tabbed divider "Tables." This table lists the prior code section in the column labeled "Prior Code Section" and the new code section in the column labeled "Herein." 
    As of Supplement No. 8, this table will no longer be updated. 
Ordinance List and Disposition Table. 
    To find a specific ordinance in the code, turn to the section called "Tables" for the Ordinance List and Disposition Table. This very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code. The table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance. If the ordinance is codified, the chapter (or chapters) will be indicated. (Example: (2.04, 6.12, 9.04).) If the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified, such as budgets, taxes, annexations or rezones, the disposition will be "(Special)." If the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code, usually at the direction of the municipality, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." Other dispositions sometimes used are "(Tabled)," "(Pending)," "(Number Not Used)" or "(Missing)." 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 8, this table will be replaced with the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 8, a Code Comparative Table and Disposition List has been added for use in tracking legislative history. Located in the back of this volume, this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification. The Code Comparative Table and Disposition List specifies the ordinance number, adoption date, description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance. By use of the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List, the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
Index. 
    If you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code, start with the index. This is an alphabetical multi-tier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference, and cross-references where necessary. Look for the main heading of the subject you need, then the appropriate subheadings: 
BUSINESS LICENSE 
See also BUSINESS TAX 
Fee 5.04.030 
Required when 5.04.010 
    The index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended. 
Instruction Sheet. 
    Each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an Instruction Sheet. The Instruction Sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement. It will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted. Following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current. Removed pages should be kept for future reference. 
Page Numbers. 
    When originally published, the pages of this code were consecutively numbered. As of Supplement No. 8, when new pages are inserted with amendments, the pages will follow a "Point Numbering System". (Example: 32, 32.1, 32.2, 32.2.1, 32.2.2., 33). Backs of pages that are blank (in codes that are printed double-sided) will be left unnumbered but the number will be "reserved" for later use. 
Electronic Submission. 
    In the interests of accuracy and speed, we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible. We can accept most any file format, including Word, WordPerfect or text files. If you have a choice, we prefer Word, any version. You can send files to us as an e-mail attachment, by FTP, on a diskette or CD-ROM. Electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is error-free. Our e-mail address is: ords@municode.com. 
For hard copy, send two copies of all ordinances passed to: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
P.O. Box 2235 
Tallahassee, FL 32316 
Customer Service. 
    If you have any questions about this code or our services, please contact Municipal Code Corporation at 1-800-262-2633 or: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
    The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omitted." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 1.01 - CODE ADOPTION* 
Sections: 

1.01.010 - Notice-Adoption-Copies available. 
A.  Pursuant to published notice, a public hearing has been duly held, and the council has determined that the proposed "Algona Municipal Code" in its original form is adopted as the municipal code of Algona, Iowa. 
B.  An official copy of the municipal code, including Chapter 17.04 "Zoning Regulations" which is published as a separate document, is on file at the office of the city clerk and will be certified as to its adoption and effective date after adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
C.  Loose-leaf copies of the "Algona Municipal Code" and Chapter 17.04 "Zoning Regulations" are available at the city clerk's office for public inspection. 
(Ord. 868 § 1, 1999) 
1.01.020 - Title-Citation-Reference. 
    This code shall be known as the "Algona Municipal Code" in any prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof or in any proceeding at law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to, amending, correcting or repealing all or any part or portion thereof as an addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the "Algona Municipal Code." Further reference may be had to the titles, chapters, sections and subsections of the "Algona Municipal Code," and such references shall apply to that numbered title, chapter, section or subsection as it appears in the code. 
(Ord. 868 § 2, 1999) 
1.01.030 - Codification authority. 
    This code consists of all the regulatory and penal ordinances and certain of the administrative ordinances of the city of Algona, Iowa, codified pursuant to the provisions of Iowa Code 380.8. 
(Ord. 868 § 3, 1999) 
1.01.040 - Ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code. 
    The last ordinance included in this code was Ordinance 861, passed November 16, 1998. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to Ordinance 861, but prior to adoption of this code, are adopted and made a part of this code: Ordinance 862, passed January 4, 1999; Ordinance 863, passed January 18, 1999; Ordinance 864, passed March 15, 1999; Ordinance 865, passed May 17, 1999; Ordinance 866, passed August 16, 1999; and Ordinance 867, passed August 16, 1999. 
(Ord. 868 § 4, 1999) 
1.01.050 - Reference applies to all amendments. 
    Whenever a reference is made to this code as the "Algona Municipal Code" or to any portion thereof, or to any ordinance of the city of Algona, Iowa, the reference shall apply to all amendments, corrections and additions heretofore, now or hereafter made. 
(Ord. 868 § 5, 1999) 
1.01.060 - Title, chapter and section headings. 
    Title, chapter and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any title, chapter or section hereof. 
(Ord. 868 § 6, 1999) 
1.01.070 - Reference to specific ordinances. 
    The provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect matters of record which refer to, or are otherwise connected with ordinances which are therein specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are included within the code, but such reference shall be construed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this code. 
(Ord. 868 § 7, 1999) 
1.01.080 - Effect of code on past actions and obligations. 
    Neither the adoption of this code nor the repeal or amendments of any ordinance or part or portion of violations of ordinances, which violations were committed prior to the effective date hereof, nor be construed as a waiver of any license, fee, or penalty at said effective date due and unpaid under such ordinances, nor be construed as affecting any of the provisions of such ordinances relating to the collection of any such license, fee, or penalty, or the penal provisions applicable to any violation thereof, nor to affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit in lieu thereof required to be posted, filed or deposited pursuant to any ordinance and all rights and obligations thereunder appertaining shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 868 § 8, 1999) 
1.01.090 - Severability clause. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code shall be adjudged invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication shall not affect the validity of the code as a whole or any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase thereof not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Ord. 868 § 9, 1999) 
1.01.100 - When effective. 
    This code shall become effective on the date the ordinance adopting this code as the "Algona Municipal Code" shall become effective, which shall be after the ordinance is finally passed, approved and published as provided by law. 
(Ord. 868 § 10, 1999) 
Chapter 1.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

1.04.010 - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this code, unless specifically defined otherwise in another section, shall have the meanings prescribed as follows: 
1.  "Alley" means a public right-of-way, other than a street, affording secondary means of access to abutting property. 
2.  "City" means the city of Algona, Iowa. 
3.  "City code" means the Municipal Code of the city of Algona, Iowa, 1977. 
4.  "Clerk" means the city clerk of Algona, Iowa. 
5.  "Code" means the specific chapter in which a specific subject is covered and bears a descriptive title word (such as the building code and/or a standard code adopted by reference). 
6.  "Council" means the city council of Algona, Iowa. 
7.  "County" means Kossuth County, Iowa. 
8.  "Measure" means an ordinance, amendment, resolution or motion. 
9.  "Month" means a calendar month. 
10.  "Oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "affirm" and "affirmed" shall be equivalent to the words "swear" and "sworn." 
11.  "Occupant" or "tenant," applied to a building or land, means and includes any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
12.  "Ordinances" mean the ordinances of the city of Algona, Iowa as embodied in this code, ordinances not repealed by the ordinance adopting this code, and those enacted hereafter. 
13.  "Person" means an individual, firm, partnership, domestic or foreign corporation, company, association or joint stock association, trust, or other legal entity, and includes a trustee, receiver, assignee, or similar representative thereof, but does not include a governmental body. 
14.  "Preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
15.  "Property" means and includes real property, and tangible and intangible personal property unless clearly indicated otherwise. 
16.  "Property owner" means a person owning private property in the city as shown by the county auditor's plats of the city. 
17.  "Public place" includes in its meaning, but is not restricted to, any city-owned open place, such as parks and squares. 
18.  "Public property" means any and all property owned by the city or held in the name of the city by any of the departments, commissions or agencies within the city government. 
19.  "Public way" means and includes any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare. 
20.  "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the edge of the travelled way, surfacing or curb line and the adjacent property line. 
21.  "State" means the state of Iowa. 
22.  "Statutes" or "laws" means the latest edition of the Code of Iowa, as amended. 
23.  "Street" means and includes any public way, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway or other public thoroughfare, and each of such words includes every other of them, and unless otherwise indicated in the text, includes the entire width between property lines. 
24.  "Writing or written" means and includes printing, typing, lithographing or other mode of representing words and letters. 
25.  "Year" means a calendar year. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0102) 
1.04.020 - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this code the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council or repugnant to the context of the provisions: 
A.  Tense. Words used in the present tense include the future; 
B.  May. Confers a power; 
C.  Must. States a requirement; 
D.  Shall. Imposes a duty; 
E.  Gender. The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter genders; 
F.  Interpretation. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the council may be fully carried out. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0103) 
1.04.030 - Amendments. 
    All ordinances which amend, repeal or in any manner affect this code include proper reference to title, division, chapter, article, section and subsection to maintain an orderly codification of ordinances of the city. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0104) 
1.04.040 - Catchlines and notes. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this code, titles, headings (chapter, division, article, section and subsection), editor's notes, cross references and state law references, unless set out in the body of the section itself, contained in the city code, do not constitute any part of the law, and are intended merely to indicate, explain, supplement or clarify the contents of a section. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0105) 
1.04.050 - Altering code. 
    It is unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with this code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0106) 
1.04.060 - Severability. 
    If any section, provision or part of this code is adjudged invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication will not affect the validity of this code as a whole or any section, provision or part thereof not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0108) 
Chapter 1.08 - CITY CHARTER 
Sections: 

1.08.010 - Title. 
    This chapter may be cited as the "Charter of the City of Algona, Iowa." 
(Prior code § 1-2.0101) 
1.08.020 - Form of government. 
    The form of government of the city of Algona, Iowa, is the mayor-council form of government. 
(Prior code § 1-2.0102) 
1.08.030 - Powers and duties. 
    The council and mayor and other city officers have such powers and shall perform such duties as are authorized or required by state law and by the ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the city. 
(Prior code § 1-2.0103) 
1.08.040 - Number and term of council. 
    The council consists of two councilmen elected at large and one councilman from each of four wards as established by the city code, elected for terms of four years. 
(Prior code § 1-2.0104) 
1.08.050 - Term of mayor. 
    The mayor is elected for a term of two years. 
(Prior code § 1-2.0105) 
1.08.060 - Copies on file. 
    The clerk shall keep an official copy of the Charter on file with the official records of the clerk, the secretary of state, and shall keep copies of the Charter available at the clerk's office for public inspection. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0106) 
Chapter 1.12 - STANDARD PENALTY AND MUNICIPAL INFRACTIONS 
Sections: 

1.12.010 - Standard penalty. 
    Unless another penalty is expressly provided by this code for any particular provision, section or chapter, any person failing to perform a duty, or obtain a license required by, or violating any provision of this code, or any rule or regulation adopted in this code by reference, is guilty of a simple misdemeanor and, upon conviction, is subject to a fine of at least sixty-five dollars but not to exceed six hundred twenty-five dollars, or imprisonment not to exceed thirty days. This section does not preclude a person from being cited for a municipal infraction as provided by Section 1.12.020 et seq. 
(Ord. 910 § 1, 2003) 
(Ord. No. 1032, § 1, 7-17-2017) 
1.12.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, these words have the following meaning: 
    "Code" means the Algona Municipal Code as may be mended from time to time. 
    "Municipal infraction" means a violation of, or the omission or failure to perform any act or duty required by, the Algona Municipal Code or any ordinance or code herein adopted by reference with the exception of those provisions specifically provided under state law as a felony, an aggravated misdemeanor, a serious misdemeanor, or a simple misdemeanor under Chapters 687 through 747 of the Code of Iowa, and is punishable by civil penalty as provided herein. 
    "Officer" means any city employee or official authorized to enforce this code. 
    "Repeat offense" means a recurring violation of the same section of this code. 
(Ord. 832 § 1 (part), 1996) 
1.12.030 - Municipal infraction-Penalties. 
    Unless another civil penalty is provided for specific offenses elsewhere in this code, a municipal infraction is a civil offense punishable as provided in the following schedule of civil penalties: 
Schedule of Civil Penalties 
First offense - Penalty of not more than $750.00 
Each repeat offense - Penalty of not more than $1,000.00 
Each day that a municipal infraction occurs and/or is permitted to exist constitutes a separate (repeat) offense. 
(Ord. 910 § 11, 2003) 
1.12.040 - Alternative relief. 
    Seeking a civil penalty as authorized in this chapter does not preclude the city from seeking alternative relief from the court in the same action. Such alternative relief may include, but is not limited to, an order for abatement or correction costs or injunctive relief. 
(Ord. 832 § 1 (part), 1996) 
1.12.050 - Civil citations. 
    Any officer authorized by the city to enforce this code may issue a civil citation to a person who commits a municipal infraction. The citation may be served by personal service as provided in Rule of Civil Procedure 56.1, by certified mail addressed to the defendant at the defendant's last known mailing address, return receipt requested, or by publication in the manner as provided in Rule of Civil Procedure 60 and subject to the conditions of Rule of Civil Procedure 60.1. A copy of the citation shall be retained by the issuing officer, and one copy shall be sent to the clerk of the district court. The citation shall serve as notification that a civil offense has been committed and shall contain the following information: 
A.  The name and address of the defendant; 
B.  The name or description of the infraction attested to by the officer issuing the citation; 
C.  The location and time of the infraction; 
D.  The amount of civil penalty to be assessed or the alternative relief sought, or both; 
E.  The manner, location and time in which the penalty may be paid; 
F.  The time and place of court appearance; 
G.  The penalty for failure to appear in court. 
(Ord. 832 § 1 (part), 1996) 
1.12.060 - Criminal penalties. 
    The provisions concerning municipal infractions do not preclude a police officer from issuing a criminal citation for a violation of this code if criminal penalties are also provided for the violation. Nor does it preclude or limit the authority of the city to enforce the provisions of this code by criminal sanctions or other lawful means. 
(Ord. 832 § 1 (part), 1996) 
Chapter 1.16 - CITY BOUNDARIES 
Sections: 

1.16.010 - Designated. 
    The boundaries of the city shall be as follows; Beginning at a point on the south section line of Section 3, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M., Kossuth County, Iowa, 502.13 feet west of the southeast corner of said Section 3; thence north 25°03'4? east 61.92 feet; thence north 34°45'35? east 155.42 feet; thence north 19°48'3? east 381 feet+to a point 255 feet west of the east line of Government Lot 1 of the SE1/4 of said Section 3; thence northerly 286 feet+parallel to said east line of Government Lot 1; thence east 135 feet; thence northerly 290 feet parallel to said east line of Government Lot 1; thence east 120 feet to the east line of Government Lot 1 being on the west section line of Section 2, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M.; thence north to the northwest corner of the SW1/4SW1/4 of said Section 2; thence east to the center of the SW1/4, of said Section 2; thence north to the northeast corner of NW1/4SW1/4 of said Section 2; thence west to the west quarter corner of said Section 2; thence north on west line of said Section 2 to the northwest corner of said Section 2; thence north 0°08' west on the east line of Section 34, T96N, R29W, of the 5th P.M. 115 feet to the north right-of-way line of Highway 18; thence north 90°00' west 468.1 feet on said right-of-way line; thence south 0°00' west 35 feet; thence north 90°00' west 121.3 feet; thence north 0°00' east 450.8 feet; thence north 90°00' east 588.5 feet to the west section line of Section 35, T96N, R29W, of the 5th P.M. to a point on said section line 530.8 feet north of the southwest corner of said Section 35; thence continuing north on the west line of said Section 35 to the northwest corner of the S1/2SW1/4 of said Section 35; thence east along the north line of said S1/2SW1/4 to the southwest corner of Lot F as shown on survey recorded in Book 5, Land Plats, page 40; thence north 1070.4 feet to the northwest corner of said Lot F; thence north 0°00' west 380.3 feet; thence north 89°59' east 690.2 feet; thence south 0°00' east 304.1 feet; thence south 15°06' west 79.2 feet; thence south 15°06'30° east 20.8 feet; thence south 200 feet; thence south 0°57' west 600.06 feet; thence south 20°45°10° west 282.1 feet to the north line of said S1/2SW1/4 said Section 35; excepting therefrom Lot Two (2) of Plat of part of the SW1/4 as recorded in Book 4, Land Plats, page 254; thence east along the division line between the S1/2S1/2 and the N1/2S1/2 to the northeast corner of SW1/4SW1/4, of Section 31, T96N, R28W, of the 5th P.M.; thence south to the northeast corner of NW1/4NW1/4 of Section 6, T95N, R28W, of the 5th P.M.; thence continuing south on quarter section line 1051.5 feet; thence west to the west line of said Section 6; thence south along the west line of said Section 6 to the north line of railroad right-of-way; thence east along the north line of railroad right-of-way to the east line of SW1/4NW1/4 of said Section 6; thence south 250 feet, more or less, along the east line of said SW1/4NW1/4 to the south line of that 150 foot wide tract condemned by the City of Algona by action recorded in Book 91, Land Deeds, page 184; thence westerly and southerly along the south line of said condemned tract to the west line of said Section 6; thence south on the west line of said Section 6 to the southwest corner also being the southeast corner of Section 1 T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M.;thence west to the southwest corner of the SE1/4SE1/4 of said Section 1; thence south to the southeast corner of the SW1/4NE1/4, of Section 12, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M.; thence west to the west right-of-way line of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway; thence southeasterly along the west line of the Chicago and northwestern Railway right-of-way line 1026.7 feet; thence west 388.5 feet; thence south 742.1 feet; thence west to the west line of said Section 12; thence north 547.0 feet; thence west to the southwest corner of Lot 1, Government Lot 4, in Section 11, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M.; thence north to a point 259.8 feet south of the northeast corner of Lot 3, Government Lot 4, of said Section 11; thence northwesterly to a point 219 feet south and 66 feet west of the northeast corner of said Lot 3; thence north to the north line of said Lot 3; thence north 20 feet; thence west 179 feet; thence north to the quarter section line of said Section 11; thence west to the Des Moines River; thence northwesterly and southwesterly along the north line of said river to the center of Section 11; thence north to the southeast corner of Lot 4 of plat recorded in Book 2, Land Plats, page 13; thence northwesterly along the south line of Lots 4 and 5 as established by said plat to the southwest corner of Lot 5, also being the east line of South Hall Street; thence southwesterly along the east line of South Hall Street to its intersection with the southeasterly extension of the southerly line of River View Heights Third Addition with the east line of South Hall Street; thence north 68°38.3' west (recorded bearing) along the southeasterly extension of River View Heights Third Addition to the southeast corner of Lot 43 of River View Heights Third Addition to the City of Algona; thence northwesterly along the southerly line of River View Heights Third Addition to the southwest corner of Lot 33 of River View Heights Third Addition; thence northeasterly along the westerly line of River View Heights Third Addition to the southerly line of River View Heights Second Addition to City of Algona; thence along the southerly line of River View Heights Second Addition to City of Algona to the southwest corner of said Addition; thence south to southeast corner of the N1/4NE1/4 of Section 10, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M.; thence west to east fork of Des Moines River; thence north along east bank of east fork of Des Moines River to north line of said Section 10; thence east along north line of said Section 10 to a point 502.13 feet west of the northeast corner of said Section 10, said point also being 502.13 feet west of the southwest corner of Section 3, T95N,R29W, of the 5th P.M. and the point of beginning. 
    Those parts of Section 3, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M., and Section 4, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M., Kossuth County, Iowa, described as follows; commencing at the west quarter corner of said Section 3; thence north 50 feet; thence east 680.9 feet; thence south 500 feet; thence northwesterly to a point on the west line of said Section 3 being 50 feet south of the west quarter corner; thence south 0°11' west 507.27 feet along the west line of said Section 3, also being the east line of Section 4; thence north 48°22' west 475.50 feet; thence north 89°52.5' west 2433.8 feet; thence north 0°08.5' east 2153.3 feet; thence north 48°22' west 1856.72 feet; thence east along the north line of said Section 4, 4014.8 feet, more or less, to the northeast corner of said Section 4; thence south 0°10' east along the east line of said Section 4 to the point of beginning. 
    The south 530.8 feet of the S1/2 of Section 34, T96N, R29W, of the 5th P.M., Kossuth County, Iowa, except the following; 
1.  Public roads and easements for public roads; 
2.  A tract of land in the SE1/4SE1/4, of said Section 34, described as follows; commencing at the southeast corner of said Section 34; thence north 0°08' west along the easterly line of the SE1/4 of said Section 34 a distance of 115.0 feet to the north right-of-way line of U.S. Highway 18 and the point of beginning; thence north 90°00' west along said Highway 18 north line a distance of 468.1 feet; thence south 0°00' west along said Highway 18 right-of-way line a distance of 35 feet; thence north 90°00' west along said Highway north line a distance of 121.3 feet; thence north 0°00' east a distance of 450.8 feet; thence south 90°00' east a distance of 588.5 feet; thence south 0°08' east a distance of 415.8 feet to the point of beginning, containing 5.7216 acres; 
3.  A tract of land described as follows; beginning at the southeast corner of the SW1/4 of said Section 34; thence north along the east line of said SW1/4 of said Section 34 a distance of 280 feet to the point of beginning; thence north 250.8 feet along the east line of said SW1/4 said Section 34; thence west 500 feet on a line parallel with the south line of said SW1/4 said Section 34; thence south 250.8 feet on a line parallel to the east line of said SW1/4 said Section 34; thence east 500 feet on a line parallel with the south line of said SW1/4 said Section 34 to the point of beginning. 
    A tract of land located in the northwest quarter (NW1/4) of Section 3, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M., Kossuth County, Iowa, more particularly described as follows; beginning at the northwest corner of said NW1/4; thence south along the west line of said NW1/4 to the south right-of-way line of U.S. Highway No. 18; thence east along said south right-of-way line to the intersection of U.S. Highway No. 18 south right-of-way line and the east right-of-way line of the north-south Kossuth County gravel road that is located along the west line of said NW1/4, which point is the point of beginning; thence from said point of beginning south 200 feet along the east right-of-way line of the above-described Kossuth County gravel road; thence east 200 feet along the line parallel to the south right-of-way line of U.S. Highway No. 18; thence north 200 feet along the line parallel to the east right-of-way line of the above-described Kossuth County gravel road; thence west 200 feet along the south right-of-way line of U.S. Highway No. 18 to the point of beginning, containing 0.918 acres, more or less. 
    All that part of Government Lot 4 of Section 3, T95N, R29W, of the 5th P.M., Kossuth County, Iowa, described as follows; commencing at point of intersection of the extended west line of Robinson Drive in Auditor's Plat of Robinson's Subdivision of Government Lot 4 of the NE1/4 of Section 3, T95N, R29W, and south line of Highway No. 18 at point of beginning; thence in a southerly direction 217.1 feet, more or less, to the northwest corner of said Robinson Drive; thence north 89°50' east 435 feet; thence north on a line perpendicular to the aforesaid line to the south line of Highway No. 18; thence in a westerly direction along the south line of Highway No. 18 to the point of beginning. Containing 2.12 acres, more or less. 
(Ord. 770 § 1, 1991) 
Chapter 1.20 - WARDS AND VOTING PRECINCTS 
Sections: 

1.20.010 - Wards established. 
    The city is divided into four wards as follows: 
A.  First Ward. The first ward shall include all of that part of the City lying west of the centerline of Minnesota Street from the south city limits line extended north to the centerline of South Street; and lying north of the centerline of South Street from Minnesota Street extended east to the centerline of Wooster Street; and lying west of the centerline of Wooster Street from South Street extended north to College Street; and lying south of the centerline of College Street from Wooster Street extended west to the centerline of Jones Street; and lying west of the centerline of Jones Street from College Street extended north to the centerline of Nebraska Street; and lying south of the centerline of Nebraska Street from Jones Street extended west to the centerline of Lowe Street; and lying west of the centerline of Lowe Street from Nebraska Street extended north to the centerline of State Street; and lying south of the centerline of State Street from Lowe Street extended west to the centerline of West Street; and lying west of the centerline of West Street from State Street extended north to the centerline of Call Street; and lying south of the centerline of Call Street from West Street extended west to the west city limits line. 
B.  Second Ward. The second ward shall include all of that part of the City lying east of the centerline of Minnesota Street from the south city limits line extended north to the centerline of South Street; and lying south of the centerline of South Street from Minnesota Street extended east to the centerline of Wooster Street; and lying east of the centerline of Wooster Street from South Street extended north to the centerline of McGregor Street; and lying south of the centerline of McGregor Street from Wooster Street extended east to Phillips Street; and lying east of the centerline of Phillips Street from McGregor Street extended north to State Street; and lying south of the centerline of State Street from Phillips Street extended east to the centerline of Ackley Street; and lying east of the centerline of Ackley Street from State Street extended north to the centerline of North Street; and lying south of the centerline of North Street from Ackley Street extended east to the centerline of Main Street; and lying east of the centerline of Main Street from North Street extended north to the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way; and lying south of the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way from Main Street extended east to the east city limits line. 
C.  Third Ward. The third ward shall include all of that part of the City lying east of the centerline of Highway 169 from the north city limits line extended south to the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way; and lying north of the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way from Highway 169 extended east to the centerline of Garfield Street; and lying east of the centerline of Garfield Street from the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way extended south to the centerline of North Street; and lying south of the centerline of North Street from Garfield Street extended west to the centerline of Wooster Street; and lying east of the centerline of Wooster Street from North Street extended south to the centerline of Call Street; and lying south of the centerline of Call Street from Wooster Street extended west to the centerline of Minnesota Street; and lying east of the centerline of Minnesota Street from Call Street extended south to the centerline of College Street; and lying north of the centerline of College Street from Minnesota Street extended east to the centerline of Wooster Street; and lying west of the centerline of Wooster Street from College Street extended north to the centerline of McGregor Street; and lying north of the centerline of McGregor Street from Wooster Street extended east to Phillips Street; and lying west of the centerline of Phillips Street from McGregor Street extended north to State Street; and lying north of the centerline of State Street from Phillips Street extended east to the centerline of Ackley Street; and lying west of the centerline of Ackley Street from State Street extended north to the centerline of North Street; and lying north of the centerline of North Street from Ackley Street extended east to the centerline of Main Street; and lying west of the centerline of Main Street from North Street extended north to the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way; and lying north of the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way from Main Street extended east to the east city limits line. 
D.  Fourth Ward. The fourth ward shall include all of that part of the City lying west of the centerline of Highway 169 from the north city limits line extended south to the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way; and lying south of the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way from Highway 169 extended east to the centerline of Garfield Street; and lying west of the centerline of Garfield Street from the south boundary of the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railroad right-of-way extended south to the centerline of North Street; and lying north of the centerline of North Street from Garfield Street extended west to the centerline of Wooster Street; and lying west of the centerline of Wooster Street from North Street extended south to the centerline of Call Street; and lying north of the centerline of Call Street from Wooster Street extended west to the centerline of Minnesota Street; and lying west of the centerline of Minnesota Street from Call Street extended south to the centerline of College Street; and lying north of the centerline of College Street from Minnesota Street extended west to the centerline of Jones Street; and lying east of the centerline of Jones Street from College Street extended north to the centerline of Nebraska Street; and lying north of the centerline of Nebraska Street from Jones Street extended west to the centerline of Lowe Street; and lying east of the centerline of Lowe Street from Nebraska Street extended north to the centerline of State Street; and lying north of the centerline of State Street from Lowe Street extended west to the centerline of West Street; and lying east of the centerline of West Street from State Street extended north to the centerline of Call Street; and lying north of the centerline of Call Street from West Street extended west to the west city limits line. 
(Ord. 886 § 1, 2001: Ord. 781 § 1, 1991) 
(Ord. No. 976, § 1, 8-15-2011) 
1.20.020 - Voting precincts. 
    There shall be four voting precincts numbered from one to four, both inclusive, which shall correspond and be co-extensive with the limits of the respective wards as provided in Section 1.20.010 of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 1-2.0203) 
Chapter 1.24 - FRANCHISES 
Sections: 

1.24.010 - Franchise required. 
    No person or other entity shall erect, maintain, or operate plants or systems for electric light and power, heating, telephone, telegraph, cable television, district telegraph and alarm, cable communication system of any type, motor bus, trolley bus, street railway or other public transit, waterworks or gasworks, within the city without a franchise from the city. 
(Ord. 830 § 1 (part), 1996) 
1.24.020 - Remedies for noncompliance. 
    Any person or other entity who violates Section 1.24.010 shall pay a user fee to the city equal to ten percent of the gross revenue derived from any sales through the distribution system within the city. Said payment is a form of rent and grants no rights to any person or other entity. Any person or other entity (whether paying a user fee or not) may be ejected from public property if operating without a franchise, and in addition the city reserves to itself all rights and remedies it may have at law, in equity or otherwise against such persons or other entities. 
(Ord. 830 § 1 (part), 1996) 
1.24.030 - Procedural requirements. 
    No franchise or permit giving or granting to any person the right or privilege to erect, construct, operate or maintain or use any natural gas pipeline, plant or system or gasworks, or electric light and power system or works or water or telephone or cable communications system of any type within the city in order to sell or distribute or provide non-municipal natural gas or electrical power and energy to any user or consumer within the city or, to use the streets or alleys of the city for such purpose or, to interconnect any building, structure or facility of any kind to any natural gas pipeline or system, or electrical line or system other than to the natural gas or electrical system of the city shall be given or granted unless such franchise or permit be given or granted by ordinance in accordance with Chapter 364 of the Code of Iowa, as amended. 
(Ord. 895 § 1, 2002: Ord. 830 § 1 (part), 1996) 
1.24.040 - Prohibitions. 
    Unless a franchise has been granted under the provisions of Section 1.24.030, no person shall erect, construct, operate or maintain or use any natural gas pipeline, plant or system or gasworks, or electric light and power system or works or water or telephone or cable communications system within the city in order to sell or distribute or provide nonmunicipal natural gas or electrical power and energy or communication or telephone services to any user or consumer within the city; or, use the streets or alleys of the city for such purpose, or interconnect any building, structure or facility of any kind to any natural gas pipeline or system, or electrical line or system or communication or telephone system other than to a system of the city. 
(Ord. 830 § 1 (part), 1996) 
1.24.050 - Enforcement. 
    If any person, firm or corporation constructs, operates or maintains any natural gas pipeline, plant or system or gasworks, or electric light and power system or works or water or telephone or cable communications system or sells or distributes any natural gas or electricity or communication or telephone services within the city, or makes any connections with gas or electrical lines or communications systems contrary to the provisions of this chapter, the city attorney may commence an action in the name of and on behalf of the city for suitable and appropriate legal, equitable or other relief. 
(Ord. 830 § 1 (part), 1996) 
Chapter 1.28 - LOCAL HISTORICAL LANDMARKS 

1.28.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to designate certain property within the city as local historical landmarks. 
(Ord. No. 985, § 1, 7-2-2012) 
1.28.020 - Local historical landmarks designated. 
    The following properties are hereby designated as local historical landmarks: 
1.  The O.B. Laing campus. Said landmark is known as the O.B. Laing building located on Lots 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 of Block Forty-seven (47), Original Plat, Algona, Kossuth County, Iowa, and the Annex building located on Lot 5 of Block Twenty-six (26), Original Plat, Algona, Kossuth County, Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 985, § 1, 7-2-2012) 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 
Chapter 2.04 - CITY COUNCIL 

2.04.010 - Membership-Term. 
    The council consists of two council members elected at large and one council member from each of four wards as established by the city code, elected for terms of four years. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0301) 
2.04.020 - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the council shall include, but are not limited to the following: 
A.  General. All powers of the city are vested in the council except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance; 
B.  Wards. By ordinance, the council may divide the city into wards based upon population, change the boundaries of wards, eliminate wards or create new wards; 
C.  Fiscal Authority. The council shall apportion and appropriate all funds, and audit and allow all bills, accounts, payrolls and claims, and order payment thereof. It shall make all assessments for the cost of street improvements, sidewalks, sewers and other work, improvement or repairs which may be specially assessed; 
D.  Public Improvements. The council shall make all orders for the doing of work, or the making or construction of any improvements, bridges or buildings; 
E.  Contracts. The council shall make or authorize the making of all contracts, and no contract shall bind or be obligatory upon the city unless either made by ordinance or resolution adopted by the council, or reduced to writing and approved by the council, or expressly authorized by ordinance or resolution adopted by the council; 
F.  Employees. The council shall authorize, by resolution, the number, duties and compensation of employees not otherwise provided for by state law or the city code; 
G.  Records. The council shall maintain records of its proceedings; 
H.  Setting Compensation for Elected Officers. By ordinance, the council shall prescribe the compensation of the mayor, council members and other elected city officers, but a change in the compensation of the mayor shall not become effective during the term in which the increase is adopted, and the council shall not adopt such an ordinance changing the compensation of any elected officer during the months of November and December immediately 
following a regular city election. A change in the compensation of council members shall become effective for all council members at the beginning of the term of the council members elected at the election next following the adoption of the increase in compensation. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0302) 
2.04.030 - Exercise of power-Authorized when. 
    The council shall exercise a power only by the passage of a motion, a resolution, an amendment or an ordinance in the following manner: 
A.  Approved Action by Council. Passage of an ordinance, amendment or resolution requires an affirmative vote of not less than a majority of the council members. A motion to spend public funds in excess of ten thousand dollars on any one project, or a motion to accept public improvements and facilities upon their completion, also requires an affirmative vote of not less than a majority of the council members. Each council member's vote on an ordinance, amendment or resolution must be recorded; 
B.  Overriding Mayor's Veto. Within thirty days after the mayor's veto, the council may repass the ordinance or resolution by a vote of not less than two-thirds of the council members, and the ordinance or resolution becomes effective upon repassage and publication; 
C.  Measures Become Effective. Measures passed by the council, other than motions, become effective in one of the following ways: 
1.  If the mayor signs the measure, a resolution becomes effective immediately upon signing and an ordinance or amendment becomes a law when published, unless a subsequent effective date is provided within the measure, 
2.  If the mayor vetoes a measure and the council repasses the measure after the mayor's veto, a resolution becomes effective immediately upon repassage, and an ordinance or amendment becomes a law when published, unless a subsequent effective date is provided within the measure, 
3.  If the mayor takes no action on the measure a resolution becomes effective fourteen days after the date of passage and an ordinance or amendment becomes law when published, but not sooner than fourteen days after the day of passage, unless a subsequent effective date is provided within the measure. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0303) 
2.04.040 - Meetings. 
    Meetings of the council shall be as follows: 
A.  Regular Meetings. The regular meetings of the council shall be held on the first Monday and third Monday of each month at 4:30 p.m. in the council chambers at City Hall. If a regular meeting falls on a holiday, said meeting shall be held on the next day at 4:30 p.m. in the council chambers at City Hall, unless the council passes a Motion setting a different date and time for said regular meeting. 
B.  Special Meetings. Special meetings shall be held upon call of the mayor or upon the written request of a majority of the members of the council submitted to the clerk. Notice of a special meeting shall specify the date, time, place and subject of the meeting and such notice shall be given personally or left at the usual place of residence of each member of the council. A record of the service of notice shall be maintained by the clerk; 
C.  Quorum. A majority of all council members is a quorum; 
D.  Rules of Procedure. The council shall determine the rules of its own proceedings by resolution and the clerk shall keep such rules on file for public inspection. 
(Ord. 891 § 1, 2002; Ord. 838 § 1, 1996; Ord. 738 § 1, 1989; prior code § 1-3.0304) 
(Ord. No. 974, § 1, 8-1-2011) 
2.04.050 - Appointment of officials-Establishment of duties and compensation. 
    The council shall appoint the following officials and prescribe their powers, duties, compensation and term of office: 
1.  City clerk; 
2.  City attorney; 
3.  Superintendent of public improvements; 
4.  Cemetery board of trustees; 
5.  Planning and zoning commission; 
6.  Sewer superintendent; 
7.  Airport commission; 
8.  Zoning board of adjustment. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0305) 
2.04.060 - Compensation. 
    The salary of each council member shall be two thousand four hundred dollars per year, plus twenty-five dollars for each special meeting of the council attended. Twenty-five dollars shall be deducted from a council member's annual salary for each regular city council meeting missed. 
(Ord. 937 § 1, 2007) 
2.04.070 - Attendance of members. 
    The council shall have power to compel the attendance of absent members in such manner and under such penalties as they may prescribe. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0307) 
Chapter 2.08 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 

2.08.010 - Oath of office. 
    The oath of office shall be required and administered in accordance with the following: 
A.  Qualify for Office. All elected officers and the following appointed officers shall qualify for office by taking the prescribed oath: 
1.  City clerk, 
2.  Deputy city clerk, 
3.  Peace officer, 
4.  Fire chief; 
B.  Prescribed Oath. The prescribed oath is: "I, (name), do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Iowa, and that I will faithfully and impartially, to the best of my ability, discharge all duties of the office of (name of office) in Algona as now or hereinafter required by law"; 
C.  Officers Empowered to Administer Oaths. The following are empowered to administer oaths and to take affirmations in any matter pertaining to the business of their respective office: 
1.  The mayor, 
2.  The clerk, 
3.  Members of all boards, commissions or bodies created by law. 
(Amended during 1988 codification; Ord. 694 § 1, 1984; prior code § 1-1.0201) 
2.08.020 - Terms of officers. 
A.  The following designated officers shall serve for the period of time set forth and no other officers or employees of the city shall serve for any specified term of office: 
1.  The city clerk shall serve a term of office not to exceed two years which shall end at five p.m. on the day the city council's first meeting in January is held of each even-numbered year, 
2.  The chief of police of the Algona police department shall serve a term of office not to exceed two years which shall end at one p.m. on the first day in January which is not a Sunday or legal holiday, of each even-numbered year, 
3.  The fire chief of the Algona fire department shall serve a term of office not to exceed two years which shall end at one p.m. on the first day in January which is not a Sunday or legal holiday, of each even-numbered year; 
B.  At the end of the term of office for any the above-named officers, the office shall automatically become vacant and the relevant appointing person or body, as the case may be, shall have the right to reappoint the incumbent office holder or appoint a different person to the position. The failure to reappoint a person to any of the above positions shall not constitute a discharge requiring compliance with the procedures set forth in Section 2.08.080 of this chapter. The discharge procedures of Section 2.08.080 of this chapter shall apply to the above-named individuals only in the event they are discharged during their term of office; 
C.  In the event a vacancy occurs in the office of city clerk, police chief or fire chief, a person appointed to fill such vacancy shall serve out the balance of the term of office so that the office becomes vacant as of one p.m. of the first day in January which is not a Sunday or legal holiday of each even-numbered year; 
D.  Nothing in this section shall affect the term of office for elected officials or the following appointed positions: 
1.  Cemetery board of trustees, 
2.  Planning and zoning commission, 
3.  Airport commission, 
4.  Zoning board of adjustment, 
5.  Board of trustees of Algona public library, 
6.  Board of electrical examiners, 
7.  Board of trustees for Algona municipal utilities, 
8.  Playground and recreation commission. 
(Amended during 1988 codification; Ord. 705 § 1, 1986: prior code § 1-1.0211) 
2.08.030 - Bonds-Required when-Approval-Recording. 
    Surety bonds shall be provided in accordance with the following: 
A.  The council shall by resolution provide for a surety bond running to the city and covering the mayor, clerk and such other officers and employees as may be necessary and advisable; 
B.  Surety. Any association or incorporation which does the business of insuring the fidelity of others, and which has authority by law to do business in this state, shall be accepted as surety upon any bonds required; 
C.  Bonds Approved. Bonds shall be approved by the council; 
D.  Bonds Filed. All bonds, after approval and proper record, shall be filed with the clerk; 
E.  Record. The clerk shall keep a book, to be known as the "Record of Official Bonds" in which shall be recorded the official bonds of all city officers, elective or appointive. 
(Ord. 694 § 2, 1985; prior code § 1-1.0202) 
2.08.040 - Powers and duties. 
    Each municipal officer shall exercise the powers and perform the duties prescribed by law and city code, or as otherwise directed by the council unless contrary to state law or City Charter. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0203) 
2.08.050 - Books and records-Accessibility of the public. 
    All books and records required to be kept by law or ordinance shall be open to inspection by the public upon request. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0204) 
2.08.060 - Transfer to successor. 
    Each officer shall transfer to his successor in office all books, paper, records, documents and property in his custody and appertaining to his office. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0205) 
2.08.070 - Resignations. 
    An elected officer who wishes to resign may do so by submitting his resignation in writing to the clerk so that it shall be properly recorded and considered. A person who resigns from an elective office is not eligible for appointment to the same office during the time for which he was elected if during that time, the compensation of the office has been increased. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0208) 
2.08.080 - Appointed officer removal. 
    Except as otherwise provided by state or city law, all persons appointed to city office may be removed by the officer or body making the appointment, but every such removal shall be by written order. The order shall give the reasons, be filed in the office of the clerk, and a copy shall be sent by certified mail to the person removed who, upon request filed with the clerk within thirty days of the date of mailing the copy, shall be granted a public hearing before the council on all issues connected with the removal. The hearing shall be held within thirty days of the date the request is filed, unless the person removed requests a later date. 
(Prior code § 1-1.0209) 
2.08.090 - Vacancies. 
    A vacancy in an elective city office during a term of office shall be filled, at the council's option, by one of the two following procedures: 
A.  By appointment by the remaining members of the council, except that if the remaining members do not constitute a quorum of the full membership, subsection B of this section shall be followed. The appointment by the council shall be done in accordance with state law; 
B.  By a special election held to fill the office for the remaining balance of the unexpired term. The special election shall be held in accordance with state law. 
(Amended during 1988 codification: prior code § 1-1.0210) 
Chapter 2.12 - MAYOR 

2.12.010 - Term of office. 
    The mayor is elected for a term of two years. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0101) 
2.12.020 - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the mayor shall be as follows: 
A.  Chief Elected Official. The mayor shall function as the chief elected official of the city and shall be responsible for representing the city as the council may direct and shall have responsibility for the general public relations of the city; 
B.  Presiding Officer. The mayor shall act as the presiding officer at all regular and special council meetings. The mayor pro tem shall serve in this capacity in the mayor's absence; 
C.  Special Meetings. The mayor shall call special meetings of the council when he deems such meeting necessary to the interests of the city; 
D.  Mayor's Veto. The mayor may sign, veto, or take no action on an ordinance, amendment or resolution passed by the council. However, the mayor may not veto a measure if he was entitled to vote on the measure at the time of passage. If the mayor exercises his veto power, he must explain the reason for such veto to the council at the time of the veto. The council may override the mayor's veto by two-thirds majority of the council members; 
E.  Contracts. The mayor shall, whenever authorized by the council, sign all contracts on behalf of the city; 
F.  Professional Services. The mayor shall, upon order of the council, secure for the city such specialized and professional services not already available to the city. In executing the order of the council, he shall conduct himself in accordance with this code and the laws of the state; 
G.  Licenses and Permits. The mayor shall sign all licenses and permits which have been granted by the council, except those designated by law or ordinance to be issued by another municipal officer. 
(Ord. 702 § 1, 1986: prior code § 1-3.0102) 
2.12.030 - Appointment of officials. 
    The mayor shall appoint the following officials: 
A.  Mayor pro tem; 
B.  Board of library trustees; 
C.  Police chief; 
D.  Board of electric examiners; 
E.  Fire chief; 
F.  Municipal utilities; 
G.  Playground and recreation commission. 
(Amended during 1988 codification; prior code § 1-3.0103) 
2.12.040 - Compensation. 
    The salary of the mayor shall be established at seven thousand dollars annually. 
(Ord. 938 § 1, 2007) 
2.12.050 - Casting deciding votes for the council-Authorized when. 
    While the city is operating with an even number of councilmen, the mayor may vote to break a tie vote on motions. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0105) 
Chapter 2.16 - MAYOR PRO TEMPORE 

2.16.010 - Vice president of council. 
    The mayor pro tempore shall be vice president of the council. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0201) 
2.16.020 - Powers and duties. 
    Except for the limitations otherwise provided in this chapter, the mayor pro tempore shall perform the duties of the mayor in cases of absence or inability of the mayor to perform his duties. In the exercise of the duties of his office the mayor pro tempore shall not have power to employ or discharge from employment officers or employees that the mayor has the power to appoint, employ or discharge without the approval of the council. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0202) 
2.16.030 - Voting rights. 
    The mayor pro tempore shall have the right to vote as a member of the council. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0203) 
2.16.040 - Compensation. 
    If the mayor pro tem performs the duties of the mayor during his absence or disability for a continuous period of fifteen days or more, the mayor pro tem may be paid for that period such compensation as determined by the council, based upon his performance of the mayor's duties and upon the compensation of the mayor. 
(Prior code § 1-3.0204) 
Chapter 2.20 - CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

2.20.010 - Purpose of chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for a city administrator for the city. 
(Ord. 697 § 1, 1985) 
2.20.020 - Appointment-Term. 
    The city administrator is to be appointed by a majority vote of the council. The council may enter into an employment agreement with the city administrator for any length of time which outlines the terms of his or her employment. The city administrator shall be subject to removal by a majority vote of the council. The city administrator shall be a person competent by education and experience to perform the duties imposed upon such person by this chapter, who shall possess a college degree in public administration or some related field and also two years of experience as a city administrator or a related occupation. 
(Ord. 942 § 1, 2007) 
2.20.030 - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties of the city administrator shall be as follows: 
1.  To supervise enforcement and execution of city laws; 
2.  To attend all meetings of the council unless excused by the council; 
3.  To recommend to the council such measures as may be necessary or expedient for the good government and welfare of the city; 
4.  To have the general supervision and direction of the administration of the city government; 
5.  To be directly responsible to the council for the administration of municipal affairs as directed by the council. All city departmental administration requiring the attention of the council shall be brought before the council by the administrator. Council involvement in administration initiated by the council must be coordinated through the administrator; 
6.  To supervise and direct the official conduct of all officers, departments and employees of the city, specifically including but not limited to the police, fire, street, parks, cemeteries, ambulance, wastewater treatment, recreation, airport and administration departments. To effectuate this responsibility, the city administrator shall have the power and authority to employ such assistants and other employees of the city for which the council has approved the position generally, and to discharge all employees of the departments, unless a city board or commission, or the city council itself is otherwise specifically authorized or directed to employ, appoint and/or discharge certain employees under other provisions of this code. However, a departmental head, subject to the approval of the city administrator, shall have the authority to suspend or otherwise discipline (but not discharge) subordinates subject to their control. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, the mayor shall retain the power to appoint the police chief and the fire chief; and, the city council shall retain the power to appoint the city clerk as provided by Chapter 2.24 of this title; 
7.  To supervise the performance of all contracts for work to be done for the city, supervise all purchases of material and supplies and see that such material and supplies are received, and are of the quality and character called for by the contract; 
8.  To represent the city, as directed by the council, in all negotiations with employees, contractors, architects, engineers and other independent contractors in matters in which the city might have an interest; 
9.  To prepare and submit to the council annually the required budget and to administer it after receiving council approval; 
10.  To supervise the construction, improvement, repair, maintenance and management of all city property, capital improvements and undertakings of the city, including the making and preservation of all surveys, maps, plans, drawings, specifications and estimates for capital improvements, except property, improvements and undertakings managed by a utility board of trustees; 
11.  To cooperate with and advise any administrative agency, city board or commission, or, utility board of trustees, and act as the council's liaison with such entities; 
12.  To be responsible for supervision of the cleaning, sprinkling and lighting of streets, alleys and public places; 
13.  To investigate the affairs and conduct of any department, agency, officer or employee under the supervision of the administrator as deemed appropriate; 
14.  To keep the council fully advised of the financial and other conditions of the city, and of its future needs; 
15.  To conduct the business affairs of the city and cause accurate records to be kept by modern and efficient accounting methods; 
16.  To make to the council periodic reports of the general condition of the city in writing, at such intervals as the council directs; 
17.  To perform such other duties as the council may direct; 
18.  To coordinate with the city attorney on the preparation of ordinances and consult with the city attorney on legal matters; 
19.  To order in writing the removal at public expense, any nuisance for which no person can be found responsible and liable. Any such order to remove a nuisance shall be carried out by the police department under the direction of the police chief; 
20.  To facilitate industrial development; 
21.  To coordinate interdepartmental efforts of the various boards and commissions of the city and assist them in meeting their duties under city code; 
22.  To handle the bid letting process on behalf of the city. In all cases where bids or proposals are required to be taken in connection with any public improvement, the city administrator, or in the absence of the city administrator the city clerk, is designated the duty of conducting and presiding over such public meeting or hearing as may be required by the council in connection with receiving and opening such bids and announcing the results, and upon announcing the results, the city administrator, or in the absence of the city administrator the city clerk, shall thereupon report the results of such bidding together with his or her recommendations thereon, to the council at its next meeting. 
(Ord. 717 § 1, 1986; Ord. 715 § 1, 1986; Ord. 701 § 1, 1986: Ord. 697 § 4, 1985) 
2.20.040 - Bond required. 
    The city administrator shall be bonded for the faithful performance of all duties, and in favor of the city in an amount to be determined by the council by resolution but which amounts shall not be less than ten thousand dollars. The city shall pay the cost of this bond. 
(Ord. 697 § 5, 1985) 
2.20.050 - Relationship to council. 
    The city administrator shall not take part in any election for council person, other than by casting his or her vote, and shall not appoint a council person to a city office or employment, nor shall a council member accept such appointment. 
(Ord. 697 § 6, 1985) 
2.20.060 - Compensation. 
    The city administrator shall receive such annual salary and benefits as the council shall from time to time determine by resolution, and payment shall be made from the treasury of the city, in the matter provided for paying other officers and employees. 
(Ord. 697 § 3, 1985) 
2.20.070 - Residence in city required. 
    Within six months after becoming employed, the city administrator shall reside within the city limits of the city of Algona, Iowa, and shall continue to reside within the city limits until he or she is no longer so employed. 
(Ord. 759 § 1, 1990) 
Chapter 2.24 - CITY CLERK 

2.24.010 - Appointment. 
    At its first meeting in January following the regular city election the council shall appoint by majority vote a city clerk to serve for a term of office not to exceed two years which shall end at five p.m. on the day the city council's first meeting in January is held of each even-numbered year. 
(Amended during 1988 codification; prior code § 1-4.0101) 
2.24.020 - Powers and duties. 
    The clerk, or in his absence or inability to act, the deputy clerk, shall have the powers and duties as provided in this chapter, this code and the law. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0102) 
2.24.030 - Recording and publication of meeting minutes. 
    The clerk shall attend all regular and special council meetings and within fifteen days following a regular or special meeting shall cause the minutes of the proceedings thereof to be published. Such publication shall include a list of all claims allowed, a summary of all receipts and the gross amount of the claims approved. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0103) 
2.24.040 - Recording measures considered. 
    The clerk shall promptly record each measure considered by the council, with a statement where applicable indicating whether the mayor signed, vetoed or took no action on the measure, and whether the measure was repassed after the mayor's veto. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0104) 
2.24.050 - Publication of business-Method and time requirements. 
    The clerk shall cause to be published all ordinances, enactments, proceedings and official notices requiring publication as follows: 
A.  Time. If notice of an election, hearing or other official action is required by this code or law, the notice must be published at least once, not less than four nor more than twenty days before the date of the election, hearing or other action, unless otherwise provided by law. 
B.  Manner of Publication. A publication required by this code or law must be in a newspaper published at least once weekly and having general circulation in the city. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0105) 
2.24.060 - Authentication. 
    The clerk shall authenticate all such measures except motions with his signature, certifying the time and manner of publication when required. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0106) 
2.24.070 - Certify measures. 
    The clerk shall certify all measures establishing any zoning district, building lines or fire limits and a plat showing the district, lines or limits to the recorder of the county containing the affected parts of the city. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0107) 
2.24.080 - Recordkeeping-General requirements. 
    The clerk shall maintain the specified city records in Sections 2.24.090 through 2.24.130 of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0108 (part)) 
2.24.090 - Recordkeeping-Ordinances and codes. 
    The clerk shall maintain copies of all effective city ordinances and codes for public use. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0108(1)) 
2.24.100 - Recordkeeping-Writing or documents. 
    The clerk shall custody and be responsible for the safekeeping of all writings or documents in which the city is a party in interest unless otherwise specifically directed by law or ordinance. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0108(2)) 
2.24.110 - Recordkeeping-Time requirements. 
    Ordinances, resolutions, council proceedings, and records and documents relating to real property transactions or bond issues or accurate reproductions of those ordinances, resolutions, council proceedings, and records and documents relating to real property transactions or bond issues, shall be maintained permanently by the clerk. The clerk shall maintain all other city records and documents, or accurate reproductions, for at least five years. However, if state law provides for a longer period of retention of certain city records or documents, then the clerk shall follow state law and retain the records for a longer period of time. If state law provides for a shorter period of retention of certain city records or documents, then the clerk may follow state law and maintain the records for less than five years. 
(Ord. 755 § 1, 1990: prior code § 1-4.0108(3)) 
2.24.120 - Recordkeeping-Municipal officer and public accessibility. 
    The clerk shall furnish upon request to any municipal officer a copy of any record, paper or public document under his control when it may be necessary to such officer in the discharge of his duty. The clerk shall furnish a copy to any citizen when requested upon payment of the fee set by council resolution. The clerk shall, under the direction of the mayor or other authorized officer, affix the seal of the corporation to those public documents or instruments which by ordinance and city code are required to be attested by the affixing of the seal. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0108(4)) 
2.24.130 - Filing of communications. 
    The clerk shall keep and file all communications and petitions directed to the council or to the city generally. The clerk shall endorse thereon the action of the council taken upon matters considered in such communications and petitions. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0108(5)) 
2.24.140 - Attendance at meetings. 
    At the direction of the council the clerk shall attend meetings of committees, boards and commissions. The clerk shall record and preserve a correct record of the proceedings of such meetings. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0109) 
2.24.150 - Issue licenses and permits. 
    The clerk shall issue or revoke licenses and permits when authorized by this code, and keep a record of licenses and permits issued which shall show date of issuance, license or permit number, official receipt number, name of person to whom issued, term of license or permit and purpose for which issued. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0110) 
2.24.160 - Notify appointees. 
    The clerk shall inform all persons appointed by the mayor or council to offices in the city government of their position and the time at which they shall assume the duties of their office. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0111) 
2.24.170 - Elections. 
    The clerk shall accept the nomination petition of a candidate for a city office for filing if on its face it appears to have the requisite number of signatures and it is timely filed. The clerk shall deliver all nomination petitions to the county commissioner of elections not later than five p.m. on the day following the last day on which nomination petitions can be filed. 
(Prior code § 1-4.0112) 
2.24.180 - City seal. 
    The city seal shall be in the custody of the clerk and shall be attached by him to all transcripts, orders and certificates which it may be necessary or proper to authenticate. The city seal shall be circular in form, in the center of which shall be the words "Seal" and around the margin the words "City Algona, Iowa." 
(Prior code § 1-4.0113) 
Chapter 2.28 - CITY TREASURER 

2.28.010 - Duties assigned to city clerk. 
    The city clerk now performs the duties and responsibilities previously exercised by the city treasurer. Therefore, all of the duties of the treasurer listed hereafter in this chapter shall be performed by the city clerk. 
(Amended during 1988 codification: prior code § 1-4.0201) 
2.28.020 - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties of the treasurer shall be as follows: 
A.  Custody of Funds. The treasurer shall be responsible for the safe custody of all funds of the city in the manner provided by law, and council direction; 
B.  Record of Fund. The treasurer shall keep the record of each fund separate;
