    It is unlawful for any person owning, controlling or caring for any animal to permit said animal to excrete solid waste material upon any public or private property within the city limits, other than the property of the owner of the animal, unless said solid waste material is immediately thereafter removed from the public or private property and disposed of in a sanitary manner. This section shall not apply to animals properly trained and certified to assist persons with disabilities while such animals are acting in such capacity. 
(Ord. 893 § 1, 2002) 
6.04.240 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  An owner of an animal who violates any of the provision of this chapter shall upon conviction be guilty of a simple misdemeanor. 
B.  A violation of any portion of this chapter shall be a municipal infraction, unless the violation would be a felony or a serious misdemeanor or aggravated misdemeanor under the laws of the state of Iowa. 
C.  Violators may be subject to other appropriate remedies such as court orders to abate and/or halt the violations. 
(Ord. 893 § 2, 2002) 
Chapter 6.08 - DEER FEEDING REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

6.08.010 - Prohibition on feeding deer. 
    No person shall engage in the artificial feeding of deer within the city limits of Algona except as set forth in Section 6.08.020 of this chapter. "Artificial feeding" shall be defined as the placement of shelled corn and/or other types of grain, salt or minerals, fruit or vegetable matter on the ground or in feeders, mangers or any other type of structure or receptacle for the purpose of feeding or attracting deer, on any private or public property. 
(Ord. 933 § 1 (part), 2006) 
6.08.020 - Exceptions. 
    The prohibition set forth in Section 6.08.010 of this chapter shall not apply to any of the following: 
A.  Use of bird feeders or their equivalent for the primary purpose of feeding of birds. 
B.  Cultivation of naturally growing grains, fruits or vegetables for purposes other than the feeding of deer, but which inadvertently attract deer. 
(Ord. 933 § 1 (part), 2006) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapter 8.04 - BURGLAR AND FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS 
Sections: 

8.04.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall be construed to have the meanings set forth unless it is apparent from the context that a different meaning is intended: 
A.  "Alarm business" means the business of selling, leasing, maintaining, inspecting, servicing, repairing, replacing, altering, moving or installing any alarm system. 
B.  "Alarm system" means either a fire, burglar or hold-up alarm system. 
C.  "Burglar alarm system" means a system of detecting and signalling the presence, entry or attempted entry of an intruder into protected premises. 
D.  "Central alarm system" means a system installed, maintained and operated by an alarm business by which all alarms are transmitted to and received by one receiver located at the police station. 
E.  "Fire alarm system" means a method of detecting and signalling the presence of fire, the products of combustion, or heat in a protected premises. 
F.  "Protected premises" means that part of a building to which protection is afforded by an alarm system. 
(Prior code § 2.1-4.0401) 
8.04.020 - Connection to central system-Required when. 
    All alarms presently existing or hereinafter installed for which a permit is required shall be connected to the central alarm system. Expense of installing, maintaining and operating each alarm in the system shall be paid by the owner or the person controlling the protected premises. 
(Prior code § 2.1-4.0402) 
8.04.030 - Permit-Required. 
    No person shall have or maintain at premises under his control or ownership an alarm system in the absence of a currently valid alarm system permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 2.1-4.0403) 
8.04.040 - Alarm systems exempt from regulations. 
    No alarm system permit is required if an alarm signal is transmitted only to the residence of the person in control of or owning the protected premises or the residence of someone who is his regular employee or if it is audible at the protected premises. 
(Prior code § 2.1-4.0404) 
8.04.050 - Permit-Application. 
    Application for permits shall be filed with the chief of police on forms provided for that purpose. 
(Prior code § 2.1-4.0405) 
8.04.060 - Chief of police-Authority to impose regulations. 
    The chief of police may propose regulations prescribing minimum standards for the construction, maintenance and operation of fire, burglar and hold-up alarm systems and requiring inspection and approval of all such systems. He shall consult with the fire chief on standards for fire alarm systems. Such standards shall have the full force and effect of law upon adoption of a resolution of approval by the council. Copies of these standards shall be available for inspection in the office of the chief of police. 
(Prior code § 2.1-4.0406) 
8.04.070 - Alarms terminating at city facilities. 
    A central control burglar or fire alarm may terminate and give a signal at the police station. The police chief may set standards, rules and regulations governing such equipment and may limit the number of alarm systems so terminated. Alarm reporting equipment in the police station shall be privately owned and the owner or lessor shall be responsible for its proper maintenance, operation and repair. 
(Prior code § 2.1-4.0407) 
8.04.080 - Right to appeal-Procedures. 
    An applicant or any person, firm or corporation aggrieved by a decision of the chief of police shall have the right to appeal to the council. Notice of appeal must be filed with the clerk within fifteen days after the decision. The notice of appeal shall briefly state the basis for such appeal and shall be heard by the council at the next regular council meeting following the filing of notice of appeal. 
(Prior code § 2.1-4.0408) 
Chapter 8.08 - FIREWORKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1031, § 1, adopted June 9, 2017, amended Ch. 8.08 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 8.08, §§ 8.08.010, 8.08.020, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from an amendment of 1988 and prior code §§ 2.1-1.0404(1), (2). 

8.08.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide standards for the sales and usages of fireworks within the city. All State of Iowa codes for fireworks shall apply within the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
8.08.020 - Definitions. 
    For the use of this chapter the following terms are defined: 
    "Consumer fireworks:" For purposes of this section, the definition of "consumer fireworks" as enumerated in Iowa Code section 727.2 is incorporated herein by reference. 
    "Display fireworks:" For purposes of this section, the definition of "display fireworks" as enumerated in Iowa Code section 727.2 is incorporated herein by reference. 
    "Novelties:" For purposes of this section, the definition of "novelties" as enumerated in Iowa Code section 727.2 is incorporated herein by reference. 
    "Person:" Any individual, firm, partnership or corporation. 
    "Retailer:" Any person engaged in the business of making retail sales of consumer fireworks to the general public. 
    "Sales:" The exchange of articles of fireworks for money and also includes barter, exchange, gift or offer and each such transaction made by any person, whether as principle proprietor, salesperson, agent, association, co-partnership, or one or more individual(s). 
    "State fire marshal's permit:" The appropriate fireworks permit issued by the State of Iowa Fire Marshal's Office. 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
8.08.030 - Permits and permit fees. 
    All sales sites shall comply with State of Iowa codes and the Algona Municipal Code. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person to sell or to offer for sale in the City of Algona any item of consumer fireworks without first having secured a state fire marshal's permit and a permit issued by the City of Algona. 
(2)  Permits issued by the City of Algona are not transferable. 
(3)  Permits to sell consumer fireworks from a permanent structure that meets requirements, is valid only from June 1 through July 8 and December 10 through January 3 each year, all dates inclusive. For a temporary structure that meets requirements, the permit is valid from June 13 through July 8 each year, both dates inclusive. 
(4)  The City of Algona fireworks permit fee is established by resolution of the Algona City Council. 
(5)  A permit to sell consumer fireworks in the City of Algona must be issued. The application shall be obtained through the Algona Fire Department and shall contain the following: 
a.  Name, address and telephone number of applicant. 
b.  List physical address of sales location. 
c.  The applicant shall be the natural person who will operate or be responsible for the sales. 
d.  The applicant shall be the same as the name on the state fire marshal's permit. 
e.  Acknowledgement that applicant is liable for all violations of this chapter by persons under his/her supervision. 
f.  Written authorization from the owner of the permanent structure or land owner of the temporary structure. 
(6)  A copy of the state fire marshal's permit shall be submitted to the City of Algona Fire Department. 
(7)  A copy of state sales tax number which has been obtained for sales tax purposes shall be submitted with the application. 
(8)  Permanent structure buildings used for display and sale of consumer fireworks shall be required to have automatic fire sprinkler and fire alarm systems protection. 
(9)  No sales or display for sale of fireworks may occur on any property within the Central General Business District or within three hundred feet of a residential district. 
(10)  All permits and plan reviews as required by the City of Algona Site Plan Ordinance, Zoning Code, or Building Code shall be obtained. 
(11)  The application must contain evidence that general liability insurance has been obtained by applicant naming the City of Algona as additional insured for at least two thousand dollars for each occurrence, with respect to bodily injury liability and property damage liability. 
(12)  A city codes inspector shall inspect the sales site for compliance with applicable codes and ordinances before the permit by the city is issued. 
(13)  A person under the age of eighteen years shall not buy, purchase, acquire or obtain consumer fireworks. A person shall not sell consumer fireworks to a person under the age of eighteen years and shall request a photographic ID before making a sale. 
(14)  A clearly visible sign shall be posted at the display stand that states: MUST BE AT LEAST 18 YEARS OR OLDER TO PURCHASE. PHOTO ID REQUIRED. 
(15)  A clearly visible sign at the display site shall be posted which states: NO SMOKING. 
(16)  Fireworks may not be stored or kept near any flammable or combustible materials. 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
8.08.040 - Permit revocation. 
    The City of Algona may revoke any permit upon failure of the retailer to correct any of the following violations within thirty-six hours after the retailer is given written notice by a City of Algona Code Official: 
(1)  When the permittee or the permittee's operator violates any lawful rule, regulation, or order of the City of Algona. 
(2)  When the permittee's application contains any false or untrue statements. 
(3)  When the permittee fails to timely file any report or pay any tax, fee, fine or charge. 
(4)  When the permittee or permittee's operator violates any city fireworks ordinance or State of Iowa Statute. 
    However, when any activities of the permittee constitute a distinct hazard to life or property, the City of Algona Code Official may revoke the permit immediately. 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
8.08.050 - Usage of fireworks within the city limits of Algona. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or explode any consumer or display fireworks within the city limits of Algona; provided the city may, upon application in writing, grant a permit for the use of consumer or display fireworks by a city agency, fair associations, amusement parks and other organizations or groups of individuals approved by city authorities when such fireworks display will be handled by a competent operator. No permit shall be granted hereunder unless the operator or sponsoring organization has filed with the city evidence of insurance in the following amounts: 
A.  Personal Injury: Two hundred fifty thousand dollars per person 
B.  Property Damage: Fifty thousand dollars 
C.  Total Exposure: One million dollars 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
8.08.060 - Extreme fire danger. 
    During periods of extreme fire danger, as determined by the fire chief or county emergency management director, discharge of fireworks shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
8.08.070 - Exclusions. 
    Nothing in this chapter prohibits the sale by a resident, dealer, manufacturer, or jobber of such fireworks as are not prohibited by this chapter, or State of Iowa codes, or the sale of any kind of fireworks if they are to be shipped out of the state, or the sale or use of blank cartridges for a show or the theater, or for signal purposes in athletic sports or by railroads or trucks, for signal purposes, or by a recognized military organization. This chapter does not apply to any substance or composition prepared and sold for medicinal or fumigation purposes. Unless specifically provided otherwise, this chapter does not apply to novelties. 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
8.08.080 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any violation of any provision of this chapter is a simple misdemeanor punishable by a minimum fine of two hundred fifty dollars for the first offence and six hundred twenty-five dollars for the second and any subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
8.08.090 - Seizure and disposal of fireworks. 
    The city police department may seize consumer fireworks that it has probable cause to believe are used, possessed, or sold in violation of this chapter and shall forfeit seized fireworks to the city fire department for disposal. 
(Ord. No. 1031, § 1, 6-9-2017) 
Chapter 8.12 - NUISANCES 
Sections: 

8.12.010 - Definitions. 
    For use in this chapter, the following terms are defined: 
A.  "Nuisance" means whatever is injurious to health, indecent or offensive to the senses or an obstacle to the free use of property so as essentially to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property. The following are declared to be nuisances: 
1.  Offensive Smells. The erecting, continuing or using of any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacture, which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, offensive smells or other annoyances, becomes injurious and dangerous to the health, comfort or property of individuals or the public; 
2.  Filth or Noisome Substance. The causing or suffering any offal, filth or noisome substance to be collected or to remain in any place to the prejudice of others; 
3.  Impeding Passage of Navigable River. The obstructing or impeding without legal authority the passage of any navigable river, harbor or collection of water; 
4.  Water Pollution. The corrupting or rendering unwholesome or impure the water of any river, stream or pond, or unlawfully diverting the same from its natural course or state, to the injury or prejudice of others; 
5.  Blocking Public and Private Ways. The obstructing or encumbering by fences, buildings or otherwise the public roads, private ways, streets, alleys, commons, landing places or burying grounds; 
6.  Billboards. Billboards, signboards and advertising signs, whether erected and constructed on public or private property, which so obstruct and impair the view of any portion or part of a public street, avenue, highway, boulevard or alley or of a railroad or street railway track as to render dangerous the use thereof; 
7.  Cottonwood Trees. Cotton-bearing cottonwood trees and all other cotton-bearing poplar trees; 
8.  Abandoned Appliances. Placing or allowing to be placed, any discarded, abandoned, unattended or unused refrigerator, ice box, oven or similar container equipped with an air-tight door or lid, snap lock or other locking device which cannot be released from the inside, in a location accessible to children, outside any building, dwelling or within an unoccupied or abandoned building or dwelling, or other structure, under the control of any person without first removing the door, lid, snap lock or other locking device from the icebox, refrigerator, oven or similar container. This provision applies equally to the owner of any such refrigerator, ice box, oven or similar container, and to the owner or occupant of the premises where the hazard is permitted to remain; 
9.  Storing of Inflammable Junk. The depositing or storing of inflammable junk, such as old rags, rope, cordage, rubber, bones and paper, by dealers in such articles within the fire limits of the city, unless it be in a building of fireproof construction; 
10.  Air Pollution. The emission of dense smoke, noxious fumes or fly ash; 
11.  Weeds or Grasses. Weeds or grasses are allowed to grow to a height of eight inches on the average on real estate that is zoned BGC (Central General Business District), BN (Neighborhood Business District), HSB (Highway Service Business District), MH (Mobile Home District), RS (Residential Single-Family District) and RM (Residential Multi-Family District); twelve inches in average height on real estate that is zoned HM (Heavy Manufacturing District) and LM (Light Manufacturing District); and eighteen inches in average height on real estate that is zoned CN (Conservation District) and AG (Agricultural District). Any weeds or grasses taller than the above-described heights are a nuisance. In addition, the dense growth of vines, brush or other vegetation so as to constitute a health, safety or fire hazard is also a nuisance. This section shall not apply to prairies, well-head protection areas, wetlands, farm crops or other areas of naturalized perennial vegetation which can be verified by the public works director to not constitute a nuisance of health, safety, or fire hazard; 
12.  Dutch Elm Disease. Trees infected with Dutch Elm Disease; 
13.  Airport Air Space. Any object or structure hereafter erected within one thousand feet of the limits of any municipal or regularly established airport or landing place, which may endanger or obstruct aerial navigation including take-off and landing, unless such object or structure constitutes a proper use or enjoyment of the land on which the same is located; 
14.  Houses of Ill Fame. Houses of ill fame, kept for the purpose of prostitution and lewdness, gambling houses or houses resorted to for the use of opium or hashish or houses where drunkenness, quarreling, fighting or breaches of the peace are carried on or permitted to the disturbance of others; 
15.  Trees, Hedges, Billboards. All trees, hedges, billboards or other obstructions which prevent persons from having a clear view of traffic approaching an intersection from cross streets in sufficient time to bring a motor vehicle driven at a reasonable speed to a full stop before the intersection is reached; 
16.  Effluent. Effluent from septic tank or drainfield running or ponding on the ground in the open; 
17.  Obstructions. Any article or substance placed upon a street, alley, sidewalk, public ground, or in any ditch, waterway, or gutter so as to obstruct the drainage; 
18.  Rubbish and Trash. Accumulations of rubbish or trash tending to harbor vermin or rodents, and also rank growth of weeds or other vegetation and plants which is conducive to such a hazard; 
19.  Motor Vehicle Used for Storage. A motor vehicle, whether licensed or unlicensed, or parts of a motor vehicle parked on private property in a residential district and used for storage of items, unless said motor vehicle or parts of a motor vehicle are in an enclosed structure. 
B.  "Property owner" means the contract purchaser if there is one of record, otherwise it shall mean the record holder of legal title. 
(Ord. 913 § 2, 2003; Amended during 1988 codification; prior code § 3-1.0101; Ord. 996, § 1, 8-19-2013) 
8.12.020 - Nuisances prohibited-Abatement generally. 
    The creation or maintenance of a nuisance is prohibited, and a nuisance, public or private, may be abated in the manner provided for in this chapter or state law. 
(Prior code § 3-1.0102) 
8.12.030 - Abatement-Written notice required. 
    Whenever the mayor or other authorized municipal officer finds that a nuisance exists, he shall cause to be served upon the property owner a written notice to abate the nuisance within a reasonable time after notice. 
(Prior code § 3-1.0201) 
8.12.040 - Notice to abate-Contents. 
    The notice to abate shall contain: 
A.  Description of Nuisance. A description of what constitutes the nuisance or other condition; 
B.  Location of Nuisance. The location of the nuisance or condition; 
C.  Acts Necessary to Abate. A statement of the act or acts necessary to abate the nuisance or condition; 
D.  Reasonable Time. A reasonable time within which to complete the abatement; 
E.  Assessment at City Costs. A statement that if the nuisance or condition is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the time prescribed, the city will abate it and assess the costs against such person. 
(Prior code § 3-1.0202) 
8.12.050 - Service procedures. 
    The notice may be in the form of an ordinance, may be sent by certified mail to any property owner or may be personally served upon any property owner by a city police officer. 
(Ord. 725 § 1, 1987: prior code § 3-1.0203) 
8.12.060 - Request for hearing. 
A.  Any person ordered to abate a nuisance may have a hearing with the council as to whether a nuisance exists. A request for a hearing must be made in writing and delivered to the clerk within the time stated in the notice, or it will be conclusively presumed that a nuisance exists and it must be abated as ordered. The hearing will be before the council at a time and place fixed by the council. 
B.  The findings of the council shall be conclusive and, if a nuisance is found to exist, it shall be ordered abated within a reasonable time under the circumstances. 
(Prior code § 3-1.0204) 
8.12.070 - Emergency abatement-Assessment of costs. 
    If it is determined that an emergency exists by reason of the continuing maintenance of the nuisance or condition, the city may perform any action which may be required under this chapter without prior notice. The city shall assess the costs as provided in Section 8.12.090 of this chapter after notice to the property owner under the applicable provisions of Sections 8.12.030, 8.12.040 and 8.12.050 and hearing as provided in Section 8.12.060. 
(Prior code § 3-1.0205) 
8.12.080 - Abatement by city-Authorized when. 
    If the person notified to abate a nuisance or condition neglects or fails to abate as directed, the city may perform the required action to abate, keeping an accurate account of the expense incurred. The itemized expense account shall be filed with the clerk who shall pay such expenses on behalf of the city. 
(Prior code § 3-1.0206) 
8.12.090 - Abatement by city-Collection of costs. 
    The clerk shall mail a statement of the total expense incurred to the property owner who has failed to abide by the notice to abate, and if the amount shown by the statement has not been paid within one month, the clerk shall certify the costs to the county auditor and it shall then be collected with, and in the same manner, as general property taxes. 
(Amended during 1988 codification; prior code § 3-1.0207) 
8.12.100 - Abatement by city-Installment payment of cost of abatement. 
    If the amount expended to abate the nuisance or condition exceeds one hundred dollars, the city shall permit the assessment to be paid in up to ten annual installments, to be paid in the same manner and with the same interest as benefited property. 
(Prior code § 3-1.0208) 
8.12.110 - Violation-Failure to abate. 
    Any person causing or maintaining a nuisance who fails or refuses to abate or remove the same within the reasonable time required and specified in the notice to abate shall be in violation of this code. 
(Prior code § 3-1.0209) 
Chapter 8.16 - SOLID WASTE CONTROL, COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
Sections: 
Article I. - General Provisions 

8.16.010 - Definitions. 
    For use in this chapter the following terms are defined: 
1.  "Approved incinerator" means equipment or facilities for the enclosed burning of refuse having a stack adequate to maintain a draft sufficient for efficient combustion and equipped with a screen sufficiently fine to prevent ejection of particles of burning materials as approved by the Iowa Air Quality Commission. 
2.  "Back yard burning" means the disposal of residential waste by open burning on the premises of the property where such waste is generated. 
3.  "Discard" means to place, cause to be placed, throw, deposit or drop. 
4.  "Executive director" means the executive director of the State Department of Environmental Quality or his designee. 
5.  "Garbage" means all solid and semisolid, putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparing, cooking, storing, serving and consuming of food or of material intended for use as food, and all offal, excluding useful industrial by-products, and includes all such substances from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
6.  "Landscape waste" means any vegetable or plant wastes except garbage. The term includes trees, tree trimmings, branches, stumps, brush, weeds, leaves, grass, shrubbery and yard trimmings. 
7.  "Litter" means any garbage, rubbish, trash, refuse, waste materials or debris. 
8.  "Open burning" means any burning of combustible materials where the products of combustion are emitted into the open air without passing through a chimney or stack. 
9.  "Open dumping" means the depositing of solid wastes on the surface of the ground or into a body or stream of water. 
10.  "Owner" means in addition to the record titleholder, any person residing in, renting, leasing, occupying, operating or transacting business in any premises, and as between such parties the duties, responsibilities, liabilities and obligations hereinafter imposed shall be joint and several. 
11.  "Refuse" means putrescible and nonputrescible wastes, including but not limited to garbage, rubbish, ashes, incinerator residues, street cleanings, market and industrial solid wastes and sewage treatment wastes in dry or semisolid form. 
12.  "Residential waste" means any refuse generated on the premises as a result of residential activities. "Residential waste" includes landscape wastes grown on the premises or deposited thereon by the elements, but excludes garbage, tires and trade wastes. 
13.  "Rubbish" means nonputrescible solid waste consisting of combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as ashes, paper, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery or litter of any kind. 
14.  "Rubble" means stone, brick or similar inorganic material. 
15.  "Salvage operation" means any business, industry or trade engaged wholly or in part in salvaging or reclaiming any product or material, including, but not limited to, chemicals, drums, metals, motor vehicles or shipping containers. 
16.  "Sanitary disposal" means a method of treating solid waste so that it does not produce a hazard to the public health or safety or create a nuisance. 
17.  "Sanitary disposal project" means all facilities and appurtenances including all real and personal property connected with such facilities, which are acquired, purchased, constructed, reconstructed, equipped, improved, extended, maintained or operated to facilitate the final disposition of solid waste without creating a significant hazard to the public health or safety, and which are approved by the executive director. 
18.  "Solid waste" means garbage, refuse, rubbish and other similar discarded solid or semisolid materials, including but not limited to such materials resulting from industrial, commercial, agricultural and domestic activities. Solid waste may include vehicles, as defined by subsection (1) of Section 321.1 of the Code of Iowa. 
19.  "Toxic and hazardous wastes" means waste materials, including but not limited to poisons, pesticides, herbicides, acids, caustics, pathological wastes, flammable or explosive materials and similar harmful wastes which require special handling and which must be disposed of in such a manner as to conserve the environment and protect the public health and safety. 
20.  "Yard waste" means organic debris such as grass, grass clippings, leaves, garden waste, prunings, weeds, brush and tree branches. Yard waste does not include tree stumps. 
21.  "Composting" means a controlled microbial degradation of organic waste to produce a relatively nuisance free product of potential value as a soil conditioner or soil amendment. Only composting of decomposed plant material, grass clippings and garden vegetable matter shall be allowed. 
22.  "Bags" means any bags acceptable to the composting station or used by the licensed yard waste collection hauler. 
23.  "Container" means a reusable receptacle constructed of plastic or metal materials. 
24.  "Bundle" means a stack of brush and/or tree branches bound together. 
(Ord. 766 § 1, 1991; prior code § 3-4.0102) 
8.16.020 - Intent and purpose of chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the sanitary storage, collection and disposal of solid wastes and, thereby, to protect the citizens of this city from such hazards to their health, safety and welfare as may result from the uncontrolled disposal of solid wastes. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0101) 
8.16.030 - Accumulation constituting health hazard unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to permit to accumulate on any premises, improved or vacant, or on any public place, such quantities of solid waste, either in containers or not, that shall constitute a health or sanitation hazard. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0103) 
8.16.040 - Container storage required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to permit to accumulate quantities of solid waste within or close to any building, unless the same is stored in containers in such a manner as not to create a fire hazard. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0104) 
8.16.050 - Open burning prohibited-Exceptions. 
    No person shall allow, cause or permit open burning of combustible materials, except that the following shall be permitted: 
A.  Disaster Rubbish. The open burning of rubbish, including landscape waste, for the duration of the community disaster period in cases where an officially declared emergency condition exists; 
B.  Diseased Trees. The open burning of diseased trees. However, when the burning of diseased trees causes a nuisance appropriate action may be taken to require relocation of the burning operation. Rubber tires shall not be used to ignite diseased trees; 
C.  Flare Stacks. The open burning or flaring of waste gases, provided such open burning or flaring is conducted in compliance with applicable rules of the State Department of Environmental Quality; 
D.  Landscape Waste. The disposal by open burning of landscape waste originating on the premises. However, the burning of landscape waste produced in clearing, grubbing and construction operations shall be limited to areas located at least one-fourth mile from any inhabited building. Rubber tires shall not be used to ignite landscape waste; 
E.  Recreational Fires. Persons residing at the property where a recreational fire is burning as well as individuals who are in charge of such recreational fire shall comply with the following: 
1.  A recreational fire is defined as an open fire for cooking, heating, recreation or ceremonies, provided such fire complies with the limits for emission of visible air contaminants established by the State Department of Environmental Quality. 
2.  All such fires must use only charcoal, clean dry untreated wood, natural gas or propane. No processed wood such as plywood, building materials, or materials with paint, adhesives, nails or screws may be burned. All untreated wood shall be no longer than three feet in length. 
3.  All such fires shall be contained within a noncombustible device, structure, or fire ring designed for the purpose of containing a fire. All of the devices must have adequate separation from combustibles and vegetation. Fires are to be kept to a small size and the flame height must always be less than three feet. 
4.  All such fires must be attended by a competent person at all times. A water source must be readily available. 
5.  The fire chief or his designee shall have the authority to order any fire extinguished if such fire is determined to constitute a hazardous condition; 
F.  Residential Waste Burning. Burning of residential waste at dwellings of four family units or less is permitted through the fall of 2002 as follows: 
1.  Beginning on the second to last Friday in September through the last Saturday of October each year, burning shall be allowed on Fridays and Saturdays only from dawn to dusk. 
2.  No burning shall be allowed on the Saturday of the annual Band Days celebration in Algona. 
3.  No files shall ever be left unattended. 
4.  All fires must be at least fifty feet from any structure. 
5.  Whenever burning is taking place, the person attending the fire shall have a source of water nearby. 
    After the last Saturday in October, 2002, no burning of residential waste shall be allowed in any future years; 
G.  Training Fires. Fires set for the purpose of bona fide training of public or industrial employees in fire fighting methods; provided, that the executive director of the State Department of Environmental Quality receives notice in writing at least one week before such action commences; 
H.  Variance. Any person wishing to conduct open burning of materials not exempted in this chapter may make application for a variance to the executive director of the State Department of Environmental Quality. 
(Ord. 929 § 1, 2005; Ord. 881 § 1, 2000; Ord. 584 § 1, 1978; prior code § 3-4.0105) 
8.16.060 - Littering prohibited. 
    No person shall discard any litter onto or in any water or land, except that nothing in this section shall be construed to affect the authorized collection and discarding of such litter in or on areas or receptacles provided for such purpose. When litter is discarded from a motor vehicle, the driver of the motor vehicle shall be responsible for the act in any case where doubt exists as to which occupant of the motor vehicle actually discarded the litter. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0106) 
8.16.070 - Open dumping unlawful. 
    No person shall dump or deposit or permit the open dumping or depositing of any solid waste except rubble at any place other than a sanitary disposal project approved by the executive director of the State Department of Environmental Quality. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0107) 
8.16.080 - Toxic and hazardous waste regulations. 
A.  Labeling. All containers used for the storage, collection or transportation of toxic or hazardous wastes shall be plainly marked so as to provide adequate notice of the contents thereof. 
B.  Vehicles and Containers. All vehicles and containers used for the storage, collection and transportation of toxic and hazardous wastes shall be so constructed that they can be loaded, moved and unloaded in a manner that does not create a danger to public health or safety and in compliance with federal and state laws, rules and regulations. 
C.  Disposal. No person shall deposit in a solid waste container or otherwise offer for collection any toxic or hazardous wastes. Such materials shall be transported by the owner, responsible person or his agent, to a place of safe deposit or disposal as prescribed by the health officer or his authorized representative. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0108) 
8.16.090 - Waste storage containers required-Specifications. 
    Every person owning, managing, operating, leasing or renting any premises, dwelling unit or any place where refuse accumulates shall provide and at all times maintain in good order and repair portable containers for refuse in accordance with the following: 
A.  Container Specification. Waste storage containers shall comply with the following specifications: 
1.  Residential. Residential waste containers shall be of not less than twenty gallons nor more than thirty-five gallons in nominal capacity; shall be leakproof, waterproof and fitted with a flytight lid which shall be kept in place except when depositing or removing the contents thereof. They shall have handles, bails or other suitable lifting devices or features and be of a type originally manufactured for the storage of residential wastes with tapered sides for easy emptying. They shall be of light weight and sturdy construction with the total weight of any individual containers and contents not exceeding seventy-five pounds. Galvanized metal containers, rubber or fiberglass containers and plastic containers which do not become brittle in cold weather may be used. Disposable containers or other containers as approved by the city may also be used, 
2.  Commercial. Every person owning, managing, operating, leasing or renting any commercial premise where excessive amounts of refuse accumulate and where its storage in portable containers as required above is impractical, shall maintain metal bulk storage containers approved by the city; 
B.  Location of Containers. Residential solid waste containers shall be stored upon the residential premises. Commercial solid waste containers shall be stored upon private property, unless the owner shall have been granted written permission from the city to use public property for such purposes. The storage site shall be well drained; fully accessible to collection equipment, public health personnel and fire inspection personnel; 
C.  Nonconforming Containers. Solid waste containers which are not adequate will be collected together with their contents and disposed of after due notice to the owner. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0109) 
8.16.095 - Separation of yard wastes required. 
    All yard wastes shall be separated by the owner or occupant from all other solid waste accumulated on the premises. The owner or occupant may either compost their yard waste on the premises or contain it in authorized bags, containers or bundles. 
(Ord. 766 § 2, 1991) 
8.16.100 - Yard waste storage. 
    Owners or occupants choosing not to manage yard waste on their own property shall contain yard waste in authorized bags, containers or bundles so as to prevent the dispersal of wastes placed therein upon the premises served, upon adjacent premises or upon adjacent public rights-of-way. A licensed collector may specify the type of collection receptacle an owner or occupant must use before said collector is required to pick up the yard waste. The number of authorized bags, container or bundles containing yard waste which residents may place out for collection shall be unlimited. Tree limbs less than four inches in diameter and brush shall be securely tied in bundles not larger than forty-eight inches long and eighteen inches in diameter when not placed in storage containers. The weight of any individual bundle, bag or container shall not exceed seventy-five pounds. 
(Ord. 766 § 3, 1991) 
8.16.105 - Composting. 
    Owners and occupants who engage in composting shall accumulate upon property under their control such quantities of leaves and/or yard debris from their own property as can be properly composted without creating offensive odors, a nuisance, litter or fire problems. Such composting so carried out shall be deemed to be an alternative disposition of the disposal of yard waste in satisfaction of any requirement to separate yard waste. The Kossuth County Extension Service can be contacted to determine what is considered suitable composting. 
(Ord. 766 § 4, 1991) 
8.16.110 - Sanitary disposal required. 
    It shall be the duty of each owner to provide for the sanitary disposal of all refuse accumulating on his premises before it becomes a nuisance. Any such accumulation remaining on any premises for a period of more than thirty days shall be deemed a nuisance and the city may proceed to abate such nuisances in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 8.12 of this title, or by initiating proper action in district court. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0111) 
8.16.120 - Unlawful acts designated. 
    It is unlawful for any person to: 
A.  Unlawful Use of Containers. Deposit refuse in any solid waste containers other than his own without the written consent of the owner of such containers; 
B.  Interfere With Collectors. Interfere in any manner with solid waste collection equipment or with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such, whether such equipment or collectors be those of the city, or those of any other authorized waste collection service; 
C.  Unlawful Disposal. Dispose of refuse at any facility or location which is not an approved sanitary disposal project; 
D.  Unlawful Collection. Engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of refuse within the city without a contract therefor with the city or a valid permit therefor; 
E.  Incinerators. Burn rubbish or garbage except in approved incinerators so maintained and operated as to prevent the emission of objectionable odors or particulate matter. 
F.  Unlawful Combination of Yard Waste and Solid Waste. Put into the solid waste collection system of the city any yard waste. This prohibition applies to any owner, lessee, or occupant of any residential, commercial or institutional property in the city. 
(Ord. 766 § 5, 1991; prior code § 3-4.0112) 
8.16.125 - Punishment of violators. 
    A violation of Section 8.16.120 or any other section of Chapter 8.16 by any person shall be a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, will carry a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or imprisonment not to exceed thirty days. 
(Ord. 766 § 6, 1991) 
Article II. - Collection and Transportation 

8.16.130 - Definitions for Article II. 
    For use in this article the following terms are defined: 
A.  "Collectors" means any person authorized by this article to gather solid waste or yard waste from public and private places. 
B.  "Property served" means any property which is being used or occupied and is eligible to receive solid waste or yard waste collection and disposal service as provided herein. 
(Ord. 766 § 7 (part), 1991; prior code § 3-4.0201) 
8.16.140 - Collection-Authority. 
    The collection of solid waste or yard waste within the city shall be only by collectors licensed by the city. 
(Ord. 766 § 7 (part), 1991; prior code § 3-4.0202) 
8.16.150 - Collection-Vehicle regulations. 
    Vehicles or containers used for the collection and transportation of garbage and similar putrescible waste or solid waste containing such materials shall be leakproof, durable and of easily cleanable construction. They shall be cleaned to prevent nuisances, pollution or insect breeding and shall be maintained in good repair. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0203) 
8.16.160 - Collection-Method. 
    Vehicles or containers used for the collection and transportation of any solid waste or yard waste shall be loaded and moved in such a manner that the contents will not fall, leak or spill therefrom, and shall be covered to prevent blowing or loss of material. Where spillage does occur, the material shall be picked up immediately by the collector or transporter and returned to the vehicle or container and the area properly cleaned. 
(Ord. 766 § 7 (part), 1991; prior code § 3-4.0204) 
8.16.170 - Collection-Frequency. 
    All solid waste shall be collected from residential premises at least once each week and from commercial, industrial and institutional premises as frequently as may be necessary, but not less than once each week. All yard waste shall be collected from residential, commercial, industrial and institutional premises at least once each month during the months of March, June, July, August, September and December. All yard waste shall be collected at least twice each month during the months of April, May, October and November. 
(Ord. 766 § 12, 1991; prior code § 3-4.0205) 
8.16.180 - Container location and placement. 
    Location of containers. Containers for the storage of solid waste or yard waste awaiting collection shall be placed out-of-doors at some easily accessible place by the owner or occupant of the premises served. 
(Ord. 766 § 7 (part), 1991; prior code § 3-4.0206) 
8.16.190 - Bulky rubbish. 
    Bulky rubbish which is too large or heavy to be collected in the normal manner of other solid waste may be collected by the collector at his discretion. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0207) 
8.16.200 - Tree limbs and brush. 
    Tree limbs of less than four inches in diameter and brush will be collected provided they are placed at the curb or alley line, securely tied in bundles not more than forty-eight inches long or eighteen inches in diameter when not in approved containers and weigh no more than seventy-five pounds. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0208) 
8.16.210 - Yard wastes. 
    Yard wastes will be collected provided they are stored in authorized bags, containers or bundles so as to prevent the dispersal of wastes placed therein upon the premises served, upon adjacent premises or upon adjacent public rights-of-way. A licensed collector may specify the type of collection receptacle an owner or occupant must use before said collector is required to pick up the yard waste. The weight of any individual bag, container or bundle shall not exceed seventy-five pounds. 
(Ord. 766 § 13, 1991) 
8.16.220 - Right of entry-Authority-Limitations. 
    Solid waste collectors are authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of collecting solid waste or yard waste therefrom as required by this article, however solid waste collectors shall not enter dwelling units or other residential buildings. 
(Ord. 766 § 7 (part), 1991; prior code § 3-4.0210) 
8.16.230 - Collector's license required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting, processing or disposing of solid waste or yard waste other than his own within the city without first obtaining from the city an annual license in accordance with the following: 
A.  Application. Application for a solid waste or yard waste collector's license shall be made to the clerk and provide the following: 
1.  Name and Address. The full name and address of the applicant, and if a corporation, the names and addresses of the officers thereof, 
2.  Equipment. A complete and accurate listing of the number and type of collection and transportation equipment to be used, 
3.  Collection Program. A complete description of the frequency, routes and method of collection and transportation to be used, 
4.  Disposal. A statement as to the precise location and method of disposal or processing facilities to be used. A yard waste collection hauler shall provide the city a detailed description of the manner in which the collector intends to separately collect and haul away yard waste. Each licensed collector shall haul the yard waste to an appropriate disposal location and shall keep an accurate accounting of the amount of such yard waste. Each licensed collector shall submit an annual written report to the city detailing the amount of such yard waste that has been collected and delivered for composting during each month of the reporting year. A licensed collector shall not mix yard waste and solid waste together. The license of any hauler who delivers for disposal yard waste and solid waste mixed together may be revoked. The city administrator shall determine whether the license will be revoked. If it is revoked, the hauler may appeal the decision, within ten days, to the city council. The city council shall by motion decide whether to uphold the revocation or allow the hauler to keep his license; 
5.  Duplication not required. In the event a collector wishes to be licensed for solid waste and yard waste, only one application needs to be completed and only one license fee needs to be paid; 
B.  Insurance. No collectors license shall be issued until and unless the applicant therefor, in addition to all other requirements set forth, shall file and maintain with the city evidence of satisfactory public liability insurance covering all operations of the applicant pertaining to such business and all equipment and vehicles to be operated in the conduct thereof; 
C.  License Fee. A license fee in the amount of five dollars shall accompany the application. In the event the requested license is not granted, the fee paid shall be refunded to the applicant; 
D.  License Issued. If the council upon investigation finds the application to be in order and determines that the applicant will collect, transport, process or dispose of solid waste or yard waste without hazard to the public health or damage to the environment and in conformity with law and ordinance the requested license shall be issued to be effective for a period of one year from the date approved; 
E.  License Renewal. An annual license may be renewed simply upon payment of the required fee if operated in substantially the same manner as provided in the original application and by providing the clerk with a current listing of vehicles, equipment and facilities in use; 
F.  License Not Transferable. No license authorized by this article may be transferred to another person; 
G.  Owner May Transport. Nothing herein is to be construed so as to prevent the owner from transporting solid waste accumulating upon premises owned, occupied or used by him, provided such refuse is disposed of properly in an approved sanitary disposal project. In addition, nothing herein is to be construed so as to prevent the owner from transporting yard waste accumulating on the premises of the owner, provided such yard waste is disposed of properly in an approved composting station, neighborhood collection site or is disposed of in some other way that is not in violation of the law; 
H.  Grading or Excavation Excepted. No license or permit shall be required for the removal, hauling or disposal of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities, however, all such materials shall be conveyed in tight vehicles, trucks or receptacles so constructed and maintained that none of the material being transported shall spill upon the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. 766 §§ 7 (part), 8-10, 1991; prior code § 3-4.0211) 
8.16.235 - Unit based pricing required. 
    All collectors licensed by the city shall charge for the collection of residential solid waste by using a unit-based pricing system acceptable to the Algona city council. Any licensed collector proposing a subsequent change in rates shall give the city thirty days notice of their intent to revise rates and a copy of the proposed rates. 
(Ord. 848 § 1, 1997) 
Article III. - Solid Waste Disposal 

8.16.240 - Definitions for Article III. 
    For use in this article the following terms are defined: 
A.  "Operator" means the person or agency authorized to conduct disposal operations at a public sanitary disposal project or licensed private sanitary disposal project. 
B.  "Processing facility" means any incinerator, baler, shredder or similar facility or process employed to reduce the volume of, or change the characteristics of, solid waste prior to final disposal. 
C.  "Resident" means in addition to any person residing in the city, any person occupying or using any commercial, industrial or institutional premises within the city. 
D.  "Scavenging" means the collection, picking up or gathering of discarded material no longer of value for its original purpose but which has value if reclaimed. 
E.  "Site" means any location, place or tract of land used for collection, storage, conversion, utilization, incineration or burial of solid wastes. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0301) 
8.16.250 - Sanitary disposal required. 
    All solid wastes generated or produced within the city shall be disposed of at a sanitary disposal project designated by the city and approved by the executive director of the State Department of Environmental Quality. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0302) 
8.16.260 - Open dumping prohibited. 
    No person shall cause, allow or permit the disposal of solid wastes upon any place within the jurisdiction of the city owned or occupied by him unless such place has been designated by the city as a licensed sanitary disposal project, public sanitary disposal project or an approved processing facility. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0303) 
8.16.270 - Exceptions to article provisions. 
    Nothing in this article shall prohibit the filling, leveling or grading of land with earth, sand, dirt, stone, brick, gravel, rock, rubble or similar inert wastes provided these materials are not contaminated or mixed with combustible, putrescible or other waste materials, nor to the disposal of animal and agricultural wastes on land used or operated for farming. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0304) 
8.16.280 - Toxic and hazardous wastes. 
    Toxic or hazardous wastes shall be disposed of only upon receipt of and in accordance with explicit instructions obtained from the executive director of the State Department of Environmental Quality. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0305) 
8.16.290 - Radioactive materials. 
    Materials that are radioactive shall not be disposed of in a sanitary disposal project. Luminous timepieces are exempt. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0306) 
8.16.300 - Private sanitary disposal projects. 
    No person may establish and operate a private sanitary disposal project within the city. 
(Prior code § 3-4.0307) 
Article IV. - Collection and Disposal of Recyclable Materials 

8.16.310 - Collection-Authority. 
    The collection of recyclable materials within the city shall be only by collectors licensed by the city. All collectors who have a license for the collection of solid waste shall also be required to provide for the collection of recyclable materials from their customers. Nothing shall prevent a licensed collector from contracting with another firm to provide for the collection of recyclable material; however, the licensed collector shall remain responsible and liable for the collection and disposal activities of said firm and shall remain accountable to the city for all reports and any and all other aspects of this article. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.320 - Collection-Vehicle regulations. 
    Vehicles or containers used for the collection and transportation of recyclable materials shall be leakproof, durable and of easily cleanable construction. They shall be clean to prevent nuisances, pollution or insect breeding and shall be maintained in good repair. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.330 - Collection-Method. 
    Vehicles or containers used for the collection and transportation of any recyclable material shall be loaded and moved in such a manner that the contents will not fall, leak or spill therefrom, and shall be covered to prevent blowing or loss of material. Where spillage does occur, the materials shall be picked up immediately by the collector or transporter and returned to the vehicle or container and the area properly cleaned. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.340 - Collection-Frequency. 
    All recyclable materials shall be collected from residential, commercial, industrial and institutional premises at least once a month. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.350 - Container location and placement. 
    Containers for the storage of recyclable materials awaiting residential collection shall be placed at curbside and picked up at curbside by the licensed collector. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.360 - Right of entry-Authority-Limitations. 
    Licensed collectors of recyclable materials are authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of collecting recyclable materials therefrom as required by this chapter, however said collector shall not enter dwelling units or other residential buildings without the resident's consent. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.370 - Collection-Type of materials. 
    Collectors of recyclable materials shall only be required to pick up recyclable materials that can be delivered to a recycling processing or storage and transfer site within Kossuth County. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.380 - Proper disposal required. 
    All recyclable materials shall be disposed of by collectors in a manner which is in compliance with state law and the regulations of the Department of Natural Resources. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.390 - Owner may transport. 
    Nothing in this article is to be construed so as to prevent the owner or occupant from transporting recyclable materials to a recycling processing site or storage and transfer site. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
8.16.400 - Collector's license required. 
    Collectors or recyclable materials at the curbside must also be licensed under Section 8.16.230 to collect solid waste and yard waste. No additional license or license fee shall be required. As a part of the annual license, the collector shall provide the following: 
A.  Collection Program. A detailed description of the frequency, routes and method of collection and transportation to be used. 
B.  Disposal. A detailed description of the manner in which the collector intends to collect and haul away each recyclable material. In addition, the collector shall set forth the precise location of where the recyclable materials will be disposed of. Each licensed collector shall haul the recyclable materials to an appropriate disposal location and shall keep an accurate accounting of the amount, in tonnage, of recyclable material collected. Each licensed collector shall submit, or before August 1st, an annual written report to the city detailing the amount, in tonnage, of recyclable material that has been collected and disposed of during each month of the prior fiscal year. 
(Ord. 769 § 1 (part), 1991) 
Chapter 8.20 - JUNKED VEHICLES AND MACHINERY 
Sections: 

8.20.010 - Junk motor vehicle or junk machinery defined. 
    Junk motor vehicle and junk machinery constitute a threat to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. For use in this chapter, the term "junk motor vehicle" or "junk machinery" means any motor vehicle or piece of machinery stored within the corporate limits of the city for a period of time in excess of seventy-two hours, and which has any one of the following characteristics; 
A.  Broken Glass. Any vehicle with a broken or cracked windshield, window, headlight or taillight, or any other cracked or broken glass; 
B.  Broken or Loose Part. Any vehicles with a broken or loose fender, door, bumper, hood, hood ornament, door handle, window handle, runningboard, steering wheel, trunk top, trunk handle, radio aerial, tail pipe or decorative piece; 
C.  Habitat for Nuisance Animals or Insects. Any vehicle or piece of machinery which has become the habitat for rats, mice or snakes, or any other vermin or insects; 
D.  Flammable Fuel. Any vehicle or machinery which contains gasoline or any other flammable fuel; 
E.  Defective or Obsolete Condition. Any other vehicle or piece of machinery which, because of its defective or obsolete condition, in any other way constitutes a threat to the public health or safety; 
F.  Inoperable Vehicle. Any motor vehicle if it: 
1.  Lacks current registration. A vehicle that is licensed with storage plates does not have "current registration"; 
2.  Lacks an engine or two or more wheels or other parts the absence of which renders the vehicle unfit for legal operation on the streets and highways; or 
3.  Cannot be started and driven around one city block. 
(Ord. 913 § 1, 2003; Ord. 779 §§ 1, 2, 1991; Ord. 723 § 1, 1987; Ord. 652 § 1 (part), 1982: prior code § 6-3.0201) 
8.20.020 - Junk defined. 
    "Junk" means all old or scrap copper, brass, lead or any other nonferrous metal; iron, steel or other old or scrap ferrous materials; dismantled or inoperable vehicles, machinery and appliances or parts of such vehicles, machinery or appliances; old or discarded rope, rags, batteries, paper, tires, trash, rubber, debris, waste or used lumber or salvaged wood; old or discarded glass, tinware, plastic or old or discarded household goods, household furnishings, furniture or hardware. Neatly stacked firewood located on a side yard or rear yard is not considered junk. 
(Ord. 879 § 1 (part), 2000) 
8.20.030 - Junk, junk motor vehicle and junk machinery prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to store, accumulate or allow any junk, junk motor vehicle or junk machinery to remain on any private property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 879 § 1 (part), 2000) 
8.20.040 - Storage-Nuisance declared. 
    It is declared that any junk, junk motor vehicle or junk machinery located upon private property, unless excepted by Section 8.20.050, constitutes a threat to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens is a nuisance within the meaning of this code and/or Section 657.1 of the Code of Iowa. If any junk, junk motor vehicle or junk machinery is stored upon private property in violation hereof, the owner or person in control of the property upon which it is stored shall be prima facie liable for such violation. 
(Ord. 879 § 1 (part), 2000) 
8.20.050 - Exemptions from chapter provisions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any junk, junk motor vehicle or junk machinery stored within a garage or other enclosed structure. In addition, the provisions shall not apply to any auto salvage yard, junk yard or any other business premises lawfully operated within the city which is in the business of repairing or storing junk motor vehicles or junk machinery. 
(Ord. 879 § 1 (part), 2000) 
8.20.060 - Abatement procedures-Notice. 
    Upon discovery or any junk or junk motor vehicle or junk machinery stored upon private property in violation of this chapter, the city may within a reasonable time initiate abatement procedures as outlined in Sections 8.12.030 through 8.12.110 of this code. In the alternative, or in addition thereto, the city may pursue a municipal infraction against the owner or person in control of the property. 
(Ord. 879 § 1 (part), 2000) 
Chapter 8.24 - FIRE ZONES 
Sections: 

8.24.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to create and establish fire limit districts required by the building code for the protection of life, limb, property, health, safety and welfare. 
(Prior code § 2.2-2.01) 
8.24.020 - Designated. 
    The entire incorporated area of the city is declared to be and is established as the fire district and such fire district shall be known and designated as Fire Zones 1, 2 and 3. 
(Prior code § 2.2-2.02) 
8.24.030 - Indication on official zoning map. 
    Fire zones shall be as shown on a map marked and designated as fire zones of the city of Algona, "Official Zoning Map," and dated December 18, 1969. 
(Prior code § 2.2-2.03) 
Chapter 8.28 - HARASSMENT 
Sections: 

8.28.010 - Acts constituting harassment. 
    A person commits harassment when, with intent to intimidate, annoy or alarm another person, the person does any of the following: 
A.  Communicates with another by telephone, telegraph or writing without legitimate purpose and in a manner likely to cause the other person annoyance or harm; 
B.  Places any simulated explosive or simulated incendiary device in or near any building, vehicle, airplane, railroad engine or railroad car or boat occupied by such person; 
C.  Orders merchandise or services in the name of another, or to be delivered to another, without such other person's knowledge or consent; 
D.  Reports or causes to be reported false information to a law enforcement authority implicating another in some criminal activity, knowing that the information is false, or reports the alleged occurrence of a criminal act, knowing the same did not occur. 
(Added during 1988 codification: prior code § 2.1-1.0416) 
Chapter 8.32 - HARMING OR HARASSING POLICE DOGS 
Sections: 

8.32.010 - Unlawful acts designated. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to intentionally and without justification cause bodily harm to a police dog when the dog is involved in law enforcement investigation or apprehension, or the dog is in the custody of or under the control of a peace officer. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to harass a police dog when the dog is involved in law enforcement investigation or apprehension, or the dog is in the custody of or under the control of a police officer. Acts of harassment shall include but not be limited to the following: 
1.  An act committed with the intent to intimidate, annoy or alarm the police dog; 
2.  Knocking on the windows of a police car when a police dog is inside the police car. 
(Added during 1988 codification: prior code § 2.1-1.0417) 
Chapter 8.36 - HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES 
Sections: 

8.36.010 - Purpose. 
    In order to reduce the danger to public health, safety and welfare from the leaks and spills of hazardous substances, these regulations are promulgated to establish responsibility for the treatment, removal and cleanup of leaks and spills within the city limits. 
(Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1994) 
8.36.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, these words have the following meaning: 
    "Cleanup" means actions necessary to contain, collect, control, identify, analyze, clean up, treat, disperse, remove or dispose of a hazardous substance or hazardous waste. (455B.381(1), Code of Iowa.) 
    "Hazardous condition" means any situation involving the actual, imminent or probable spillage, leakage or release of a hazardous substance or hazardous waste onto the land, into a water of the state, or into the atmosphere, which creates an immediate or potential danger to the public health or safety or to the environment. (455B.381(4), Code of Iowa.) 
    "Hazardous substance" means any substance or mixture of substances that presents a danger to the public health or safety and includes, but is not limited to, a substance that is toxic, corrosive or flammable, or that is an irritant or that generates pressure through decomposition, heat or other means. "Hazardous substance" may include any hazardous waste identified or listed by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency under the Solid Waste Disposal Act as amended by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, or any toxic pollutant listed under Section 307 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act as amended to January 1, 1977, or any hazardous substance designated under Section 311 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act as amended to January 1, 1977, or any hazardous material designated by the Secretary of Transportation under the Hazardous Materials Transportation Act. (455B.381(5), Code of Iowa.) 
    "Hazardous waste" means a waste or combination of wastes that, because of its quantity, concentration, biological degradation, leaching from precipitation, or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, has either of the following effects: 
1.  Causes, or significantly contributes to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible, illness; 
2.  Poses a substantial danger to human health or the environment. "Hazardous waste" may include but is not limited to wastes that are toxic, corrosive or flammable or irritants, strong sensitizers or explosives. "Hazardous waste" does not include: (1) agricultural wastes, including manures and crop residues that are returned to the soil as fertilizers or soil conditioners; (2) source, special nuclear or by-product material as defined in the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended to January 1, 1979. (455B.411(3), Code of Iowa.) 
    "Person" means individual, corporation, limited liability company, government or governmental subdivision or agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership or association, or any other legal entity. (4.1(20), Code of Iowa.) 
    "Responsible person" means a person who at any time produces, handles, stores, uses, transports, refines or disposes of a hazardous substance or hazardous waste the release of which creates a hazardous condition, including bailees, carriers and any other person in control of a hazardous substance or hazardous waste when a hazardous condition occurs, whether the person owns the hazardous substance or waste, or is operating under a lease, contract or other agreement with the legal owner of the hazardous substance or waste. (455B.381(7), Code of Iowa.) 
    "Treatment" means a method, technique or process, including neutralization, designed to change the physical, chemical or biological character or composition of a hazardous substance so as to neutralize it or to render the substance nonhazardous, safe for transport, amenable for recover, amenable for storage, or to reduce it in volume. 
(Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1994) 
8.36.030 - Cleanup required. 
A.  Whenever a hazardous condition is created so that a hazardous substance or waste or a constituent of the hazardous waste or substance may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any waters, including ground waters, the responsible person shall cause the condition to be remedied by a "cleanup," as defined by Section 8.36.020, as rapidly as feasible to an acceptable safe condition, and restore the affected area to its state prior to the hazardous condition as far as practicable. The cost of cleanup shall be borne by the responsible person. 
B.  If the responsible person does not cause the cleanup to begin in a reasonable time in relation to the hazard and circumstances of the incident, the city may, by its city administrator or his or her designee, give reasonable notice based on the character of the hazardous condition, setting a deadline for commencing and accomplishing the cleanup or the city may proceed to procure cleanup services. The city may immediately seek any state or federal funds available for such cleanup. 
(Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1994) 
8.36.040 - Liability for cleanup costs. 
    The responsible shall be strictly liable to the city for all of the following: 
A.  The reasonable cleanup costs incurred by the city as a result of the failure of the person to clean up a hazardous substance or waste involved in a hazardous condition caused by that person, including emergency treatment of the hazardous condition; 
B.  The reasonable costs incurred by the city to evacuate people from the area threatened by a hazardous condition caused by the person; 
C.  The reasonable damages to the city for the injury to, destruction of, or loss of city property, including parks and roads, resulting from a hazardous condition caused by that person, including the costs of assessing the injury, destruction or loss; 
D.  Any other excessive or extraordinary costs incurred by the city in connection with the hazardous condition caused by the responsible person. 
(Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1994) 
8.36.050 - Notifications. 
A.  A person manufacturing, storing, handling, transporting or disposing of a hazardous substance or waste shall notify the Algona fire department of the occurrence of a hazardous condition as soon as possible, but not later than six hours after the onset of the hazardous condition or discovery of the hazardous condition. The fire department shall notify the proper state office in the manner established by the state. 
B.  Any city employee or any member of a law enforcement agency, or any member of a city fire department who discovers a hazardous condition shall notify the fire department, which shall notify the appropriate city departments and the proper state office in the manner established by the state. 
(Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1994) 
8.36.060 - Police authority. 
    If the circumstances so require, the police chief or his or her designee may: 
A.  Excavate persons from their homes to areas away from the site of a hazardous condition; and/or 
B.  Establish perimeters or other boundaries at or near the site of a hazardous condition and limit access to cleanup personnel. 
    No person shall disobey an order issued under this section by the police chief or any other law enforcement officer. 
(Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1994) 
8.36.070 - Liability. 
    The city of Algona shall not be liable to any person for claims of damages, injuries or losses resulting from any hazardous condition, unless the city is the responsible person as defined in Section 8.36.020. 
(Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1994) 
8.36.080 - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision, section or paragraph of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars or be imprisoned for not more than thirty days. Each day a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 806 § 1 (part), 1994) 
Chapter 8.40 - MOWING OF PROPERTY 

8.40.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to require property owners and occupants to maintain lawns at a neat and uniform height within the boundaries of their property and abutting street right-of-way in order to prevent unsightly, offensive or nuisance conditions. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.020 - Mowing of properties. 
    Grasses or weeds are allowed to grow to a height of eight inches on the average on real estate that is zoned RS (Residential Single-Family District), RM (Residential Multi-Family District), BGC (Central General Business District), BN (Neighborhood Business District), HSB (Highway Service Business District) and MH (Mobile Home District); twelve inches in average height on real estate that is zoned LM (Light Manufacturing District) and HM (Heavy Manufacturing District); and eighteen inches in average height on real estate that is zoned CN (Conservation District) and AG (Agricultural District). Any grasses or weeds taller than the above-described heights are in violation of this chapter. The property owner and occupant are jointly and severally responsible for mowing the grasses or weeds taller than the above-described heights on the property as well as the abutting space between the lot line and the curb line or edge of the traveled portion of the street right-of-way and one-half of any alley abutting the property and one-half of any street abutting the property which are not improved. This prohibition shall not apply to prairies, well-head protection areas, wetlands, farm crops or other areas of naturalized perennial vegetation which can be verified by the public works director not to constitute a nuisance of health, safety or fire hazard. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.030 - Violation. 
    A violation of this chapter will be determined by visual observation and measurement. When a violation has occurred, the director of public works, or his or her designee, will provide a written notice to the property owner and/or occupant informing said owner and/or occupant of the violation and the action that is to be taken to remedy the violation. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.040 - Notice-Contents. 
    The notice shall contain the following: 
A.  It shall describe the conditions on the property which caused the notice to be sent. 
B.  It shall set forth the address of the property in question. 
C.  It shall instruct the property owner and/or occupant that he or she has ten days from the date of the notice to have the vegetation cut so that the height conforms with this chapter. 
D.  It shall state that if the required mowing is not done and no request for hearing is made within the time prescribed, the city will mow the property and assess the costs against the property or pursue other remedies. 
E.  It shall instruct the property owner and/or occupant that the notice being given constitutes notice for the balance of the mowing season and that further action will be taken by the city to remedy the problem that occurs again on the same property without additional written notice being given. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.050 - Service procedures. 
    The notice may be sent by certified mail or may be personally served by a city police officer or other law enforcement official. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.060 - Request for hearing. 
    Any person receiving a notice pursuant to this chapter may have a hearing with the council as to whether a violation of this chapter exists. A request for a hearing must be made in writing and delivered to the clerk within the time stated in the notice, or it will be conclusively presumed that a violation exists and the required corrective action needs to be taken. The hearing will be before the council at a time and place fixed by the council. Findings of the council shall be conclusive and if the council finds that a violation of this chapter occurred, corrective action will need to be done within a reasonable time under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.070 - Failure to comply. 
    If the property owner and/or occupant fails to cut the vegetation so that it conforms with this chapter, and within the time period set forth in the notice, the person shall be in violation of this chapter. The city may then cause the vegetation to be cut. A fee for this service shall be set by resolution of the council. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.080 - Collection of costs. 
    The clerk shall mail a statement of the total expenses incurred by the city to the property owner and/or occupant who has violated the requirements of this chapter. If the amount shown by the statement has not been paid within thirty days from the date of the statement, the clerk shall certify the cost to the county auditor and it shall then be collected with, and in the same manner, as general property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.090 - Additional violations. 
    Any property owner and/or occupant who violates this chapter will be given one notice per mowing season without additional written notice being given. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
8.40.100 - Alternative remedies. 
    In the alternative, or in addition thereto, the city may pursue a municipal infraction against the property owner or occupant if a provision of this chapter is violated. 
(Ord. No. 1033, § 1, 8-7-2017) 
Title 9 - PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE 
Chapter 9.04 - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC OFFICERS AND GOVERNMENT 

9.04.010 - Interference with city officers. 
    It is unlawful for a person to interfere with or hinder any policeman, fireman, officer or city official in the discharge of his duty. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0413) 
9.04.020 - Resisting arrest. 
    It is unlawful for a person after being informed of the intention to arrest him, to attempt to escape or forcibly resist when arrest is being made by an officer.
