(Amended during 1988 codification; prior code § 2.1-1.0409) 
9.04.030 - Resisting execution of process. 
    It is unlawful for a person to knowingly or willfully resist or oppose any officer of this state, or any person authorized by law in serving or attempting to execute any legal writ, rule, order or process whatsoever, or to knowingly and willfully resist any such officer in the discharge of his duties without such writ, rule, order or process. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0407) 
9.04.040 - Refusing to assist an officer. 
    If any person being lawfully required by any sheriff, deputy sheriff, constable or other peace officer, willfully neglects or refuses to assist him in the execution of the duties of his office in any criminal case, or in any case of escape or rescue, he shall be considered to have violated the city code. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0408) 
9.04.050 - Impersonating an officer. 
    It is unlawful for a person to falsely assume to be a judge, magistrate, sheriff, deputy sheriff, peace officer, special agent of the State Department of Public Safety or conservation officer, and take upon himself to act as such or require anyone to aid or assist him in any manner. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0406) 
9.04.060 - False alarms. 
    It is unlawful for a person to give or cause to be given a false alarm of fire by setting fire to any combustible material, or by crying or sounding an alarm, or by any other means, without cause. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0405) 
9.04.070 - False reports to or communications with public safety entities. 
A.  A person who reports or causes to be reported false information to a fire department, a law enforcement authority or other public safety entity, knowing that the information is false, or who reports the alleged occurrence of a criminal act knowing the act did not occur, commits a simple misdemeanor, if the alleged criminal act reported is a simple misdemeanor. 
B.  A person who telephones an emergency 911 communications center knowing that the person is not reporting an emergency or otherwise needing emergency information or assistance commits a simple misdemeanor. 
C.  A person who knowingly provides false information to a law enforcement officer who enters the information on a citation commits a simple misdemeanor, if the criminal act for which the citation is issued is a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 910, § 6, 2003) 
Chapter 9.08 - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON 

9.08.010 - Assault and battery. 
    It is unlawful for a person to apply, or to threaten or attempt to apply, an unlawful and unpermitted physical force to the person of another in a rude and insolent manner, or with the intent to do physical harm, with the apparent ability to execute any attempt or threat. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0101) 
Chapter 9.12 - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC DECENCY 

9.12.020 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1002, § 1, adopted Feb. 13, 2014, repealed § 9.12.020, which pertained to indecent public exposure and derived from Prior code § 2.1-1.0204. 
9.12.030 - Urinating in public. 
    It is unlawful for a person to urinate in public, except in a public restroom, locker room or other place where the prescribed use is as a restroom. 
(Added during 1988 codification: prior code § 2.1-1.0205) 
9.12.040 - Stench bombs. 
    It is unlawful to throw, drop, pour, explode, deposit, release, discharge or expose any stench bomb or tear bomb, or any liquid, gaseous or solid substance or matter of any kind that is injurious to persons or property, or that is nauseous, sickening, irritating or offensive to any of the senses in, upon or about any theatre, restaurant, car, structure, place of business or amusement or any place of public assemblage, or to attempt to do any of these acts, or to prepare or possess such devices or materials with intent to do any of these acts. This provision shall not apply to duly constituted police, military authorities, prison officials or peace officers in the discharge of their duties, or to licensed physicians, nurses, pharmacists and other similar persons licensed under the laws of this state; nor to any established place of business or home having tear gas installed as a protection against burglary, robbery or holdup, nor to any bank or other messenger carrying funds or other valuables. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0403) 
9.12.050 - Spitting. 
    It is unlawful for a person to spit within any food establishment, restaurant, hotel, motor inn, cocktail lounge or tavern. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0401) 
Chapter 9.16 - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 

9.16.010 - Disorderly conduct. 
    It is unlawful when a person does any of the following: 
A.  Engages in fighting or violent behavior in any public place or in or near any lawful assembly of persons, provided, that participants in athletic contests may engage in such conduct which is reasonably related to that sport; 
B.  Makes loud and raucous noise in the vicinity of any residence or public building which causes unreasonable distress to the occupants thereof; 
C.  Directs abusive epithets or makes any threatening gesture which the person knows or reasonably should know is likely to provoke a violent reaction by another; 
D.  Without lawful authority or color of authority, the person disturbs any lawful assembly or meeting of persons by conduct intended to disrupt the meeting or assembly; 
E.  By words or action, initiates or circulates a report or warning of fire, epidemic, or other catastrophe, knowing such report to be false or such warning to be baseless; 
F.  Knowingly and publicly uses the flag of the United States in such a manner as to show disrespect for the flag as a symbol of the United States, with the intent or reasonable expectation that such use will provoke or encourage another to commit a public offense; 
G.  Without authority or justification, the person obstructs any street, sidewalk, highway, or other public way, with the intent to prevent or hinder its lawful use by others. 
(Ord. 910 § 9 (part), 2003) 
9.16.020 - Disturbing congregations or other assemblies. 
    It is unlawful for a person to willfully disturb any assembly of persons met for religious worship by profane discourse or rude and indecent behavior, or by making a noise, either within the place of worship or so near as to disturb the order and solemnity of the assembly, or willfully to disturb or interrupt any school, school meeting or literary society or other lawful assembly of persons. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0104) 
9.16.030 - Disturbing of peace-Excessive noise. 
    It is unlawful for a person to disturb the peace by excessive, loud or unusual noise, by blowing horns or ringing bells, or by the use of sirens, radios or any type of speaking devices or noise makers. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0105) 
9.16.040 - Unlawful assembly. 
    An unlawful assembly is three or more persons assembled together, with them or any of them acting in a violent manner, and with intent that they or any of them will commit a public offense. It is unlawful for a person to willingly join in or remain a part of an unlawful assembly, knowing or having reasonable grounds to believe that it is such. 
(Ord. 910 § 9 (part), 2003) 
9.16.050 - Failure to disperse. 
    A peace officer may order the participants in a riot or unlawful assembly or persons in the immediate vicinity of a riot or unlawful assembly to disperse. It is unlawful for any person within such hearing distance of such command to refuse to obey such command. 
(Ord. 910 § 9 (part), 2003) 
9.16.060 - Disturbing of peace-Sound amplification systems. 
    It is unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to operate or permit operation of a sound system within a vehicle (including but not limited to a radio, tape player, compact disc or any other sound amplification device), that can be heard at a distance of three hundred feet or greater from the vehicle. In addition, it is unlawful for a person to operate or permit operation of a sound amplification device (including but not limited to a radio, tape player, compact disc or any other sound amplification device) that can be heard at a distance of three hundred feet or greater from its source. Parades, athletic contests, outdoor warning systems and special events (including but not limited to Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Founders Day and Band Day) shall be exempt from this section. The chief of police or the city council may grant a temporary variance to this section to facilitate special events, subject to such terms and conditions as may be established. 
(Ord. 880 § 1, 2000) 
9.16.070 - Engine brakes and compression brakes. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to use or operate or cause to be used or operated within the city, any engine brake, compression brake, or mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in the braking or deceleration of any vehicle that results in excessive, loud, unusual or explosive noise from such vehicle. 
B.  The usage of an engine brake, compression brake, or mechanical exhaust device designed to aid in braking or deceleration in such manner so as to be audible at a distance of three hundred feet from the motor vehicle shall constitute evidence of a prima facie violation of this section. 
C.  The scheduled fine for a violation of this section shall be fifty dollars. 
(Ord. No. 982, § 1, 4-16-2012) 
Chapter 9.20 - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

9.20.010 - Criminal mischief. 
    Any damage, defacing, alteration, or destruction of tangible property is criminal mischief when done intentionally by one who has no right to so act. 
(Ord. 910 § 10 (part), 2003) 
9.20.020 - Multiple acts. 
    Whenever criminal mischief is committed upon more than one item of property at approximately the same location or time period, so that all of these acts of mischief can be attributed to a single scheme, plan or conspiracy, such acts shall be considered as a single act of criminal mischief. 
(Ord. 910 § 10 (part), 2003) 
9.20.030 - Unauthorized computer access. 
    It is unlawful for a person to knowingly and without authorization access a computer, computer system, or computer network. 
(Ord. 910 § 10 (part), 2003) 
9.20.040 - Trespassing prohibited. 
A.  The term "property" shall include any land, dwelling, building, conveyance, vehicle, or other temporary or permanent structure whether publicly or privately owned. 
B.  It is unlawful for a person to commit one or more of the following acts: 
1.  Enter upon or in property without the express permission of the owner, lessee, or person in lawful possession with the intent to commit a public offense, to use, remove therefrom, alter, damage, harass, or place thereon or therein anything animate or inanimate; 
2.  Enter or remain upon or in property without justification after being notified or requested to abstain from entering or to remove or vacate therefrom by the owner, lessee, or person in lawful possession, or the agent or employee of the owner, lessee, or person in lawful possession, or by any peace officer, magistrate, or public employee whose duty it is to supervise the use or maintenance of the property; 
3.  Enter upon or in property for the purpose or with the effect of unduly interfering with the lawful use of the property by others; 
4.  Be upon or in property and wrongfully using, removing therefrom, altering, damaging, harassing, or placing thereon or therein anything animate or inanimate, without the implied or actual permission of the owner, lessee, or person in lawful possession; 
5.  Enter or remain upon or in railway property without lawful authority or without the consent of the railway corporation which owns, leases, or operates the railway property. This paragraph does not apply to passage over a railroad right-of-way, other than a track, railroad roadbed, viaduct, bridge, trestle, or railroad yard, by an unarmed person if the person has not been notified or requested to abstain from entering on to the right-of-way or to vacate the right-of-way and the passage over the right-of-way does not interfere with the operation of the railroad. 
C.  The term "trespassing" shall not mean entering upon the property of another for the sole purpose of retrieving personal property which has accidentally or inadvertently been thrown, fallen, strayed, or blown on to the property of another, provided that the person retrieving the property takes the most direct and accessible route to and from the property to be retrieved, exits the property as quickly as is possible, and does not unduly interfere with the lawful use of the property. 
D.  The term "trespass" does not mean the entering upon the right-of-way of a public road or highway. 
(Ord. 910 § 10 (part), 2003) 
9.20.050 - Stowing away. 
    A person commits the offense of stowing away when, without lawful authority or the consent of a railway corporation, the person does either of the following: 
A.  Rides on the outside of a train or train component; 
B.  Rides on the inside of a train or train component which is not a passenger car. 
(Ord. 910 § 10 (part), 2003) 
Chapter 9.24 - OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST MINORS 

9.24.010 - Minor defined. 
    The term "minor" means in this chapter, any unemancipated person below the age of eighteen years. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0302(1)) 
9.24.020 - Curfew-Hours designated. 
    It is unlawful for any minor to be or remain upon any of the alleys, streets or public places or places of business and amusement in the city between the hours of ten-thirty p.m. and five a.m. of the following day on days commencing on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursdays and between the hours of twelve thirty-one a.m. and five a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
(Ord. 649 § 1, 1982: prior code § 2.1-1.0302(2)) 
9.24.030 - Curfew-Exceptions. 
A.  The restriction provided by Section 9.24.020 of this chapter shall not apply to any minor who is accompanied by a guardian, parent or other person charged with the care and custody of such minor, or other responsible person over eighteen years of age, nor shall the restriction apply to any minor who is traveling between his home or place of residence and the place where any approved place of employment, church, municipal or school function is being held. 
B.  These exceptions shall not apply when a minor is playing or unnecessarily loitering in or upon the enumerated public or private places, even though he is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other person charged with the minor's care and custody. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0302(3)) 
9.24.040 - Adult responsibilities. 
    It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person charged with the care and custody of any minor to allow or permit such minor to be in or upon any of the streets, alleys, places of business or amusement or other public places within the curfew hours set by Section 9.24.020, except as otherwise provided in Section 9.24.030. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0302(4)) 
9.24.050 - Business establishment responsibilities. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation operating a place of business or amusement to allow or permit any minor to be in or upon any place of business or amusement operated by them within the curfew hours set by Section 9.24.020, except as otherwise provided in Section 9.24.030. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0302(5)) 
9.24.060 - Enforcement. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to imprisonment not exceeding thirty days, or a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars. In addition, any peace officer of the city while on duty is empowered to arrest any minor who violates any of the provisions of this chapter. Upon arrest, the minor shall be returned to the custody of the parent, guardian or other person charged with the care and custody of the minor. If a minor violates this chapter more than two times: 
A.  The minor may be subject to arrest for violation of a simple misdemeanor; or 
B.  The peace officer may notify the probation officer, or the county attorney if there is no probation officer, of the violations and then prepare a statement setting forth the violations to be filed with the clerk of the juvenile court upon the approval of the probation officer or county attorney. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0302(6)) 
9.24.070 - Minors in billiard rooms. 
    It is unlawful for any person who keeps a billiard hall where beer is sold, or the agent, clerk or employee of any such person, or any person having charge or control of any such hall, to permit any minor under eighteen years of age to remain in such hall or to take part in any of the games known as billiard or pool. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0301) 
9.24.080 - Possession of tobacco by a minor. 
    It is unlawful for any minor to smoke, use, possess, purchase, or attempt to purchase any tobacco, tobacco products or cigarettes. However, possession of cigarettes or tobacco products by a minor is not a violation of this section if said minor possesses the cigarettes or tobacco products as part of the individual's employment and the individual is employed by a person who holds a valid permit under Chapter 453A of the Code of Iowa or who lawfully offers for sale or sells cigarettes or tobacco products. 
(Ord. 1002, § 2, 2-13-2014) 
Chapter 9.28 - WEAPONS 

9.28.010 - Carrying concealed weapons. 
A.  Prohibition. It is unlawful for any person, except as hereinafter provided, to go armed with or to carry a dirk, dagger, sword, pistol, revolver, stiletto, metallic knuckles, pocket billy, sandbag, skull cracker, slug shot, or other offensive or dangerous weapon, except hunting knives adapted and carried as such, concealed on or about the person, except in one's own dwelling, house, place of business, or other land possessed by him. 
B.  Except as provided in this section, no person shall go armed with, or carry a pistol, revolver, or any loaded firearm of any kind, whether concealed or not, nor shall any person carry or transport in a vehicle, a pistol or revolver. 
C.  Exceptions: 
1.  A peace officer, reserve officer certified by the state to carry weapons, correctional officer serving under the authority of the Iowa Department of Corrections, a person engaged in the business of transporting prisoners under a contract with the Iowa Department of Corrections or similar agency from another state, or a law enforcement officer from another state when the officer's duties require the person to carry such weapon; 
2.  A person who for any lawful purpose carries an unloaded pistol, revolver, or other dangerous weapon inside a closed and fastened container or securely wrapped package which is too large to be concealed on the person; 
3.  A person who for any lawful purpose carries or transports an unloaded pistol or revolver, in a vehicle inside a closed and fastened container or securely wrapped package which is too large to be concealed on the person or inside a cargo or luggage compartment where the pistol or revolver will not be readily accessible to any person riding in the vehicle or common carrier; 
4.  A person who carries a knife used in hunting or fishing while actually engaged in lawful hunting or fishing; 
5.  A person who has in the person's possession and who displays to a peace officer on demand a valid permit to carry weapons which has been issued to the person, and whose conduct is within the limits of that permit. A person shall not be convicted of a violation of this section if the person produces at the person's trial a permit to carry weapons which was valid at the time of the alleged offense and which would have brought the person's conduct within this exception if the permit had been produced at the time of the alleged offense; 
6.  A person armed with a revolver, pistol, or pocket billy concealed upon the person shall have in the person's possession the permit provided for under the Code of Iowa, and shall produce the permit for inspection at the request of a peace officer. 
(Ord. 910 § 8, 2003) 
9.28.020 - Discharging weapons. 
    It is unlawful for a person to discharge rifles, shotguns, revolvers, pistols, guns or firearms of any kind within the city limits except by authorization of the council. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0411) 
9.28.030 - Throwing and shooting. 
    It is unlawful for a person to throw stones or missiles of any kind or to shoot arrows, rubber guns, slingshots, air rifles or other dangerous instruments or toys on or into any street, highway, alley, sidewalk or public place. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0412) 
Chapter 9.32 - MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS 

9.32.010 - Sale of tainted food. 
    It is unlawful for a person to sell or offer for sale any tainted, unsound or rotten meat, fish, fowl, fruit, vegetables, eggs, butter, canned goods, packaged goods or other articles of food, or to sell or offer for sale the flesh of any animal that was diseased. 
(Prior code 2.1-1.0402) 
9.32.020 - Antenna and radio wires. 
    It is unlawful for a person to allow antenna wires, antenna supports, radio wires or television wires to exist over any street, alley, highway, sidewalk or public property. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0410) 
9.32.030 - Barbed wire. 
    It is unlawful for a person to use barbed wire to enclose land within the city limits without the consent of the council unless such land consists of land zoned for agricultural use. 
(Prior code § 2.1-1.0414) 
Chapter 9.36 - THEFT 

9.36.010 - Theft defined. 
A.  A person commits theft when the person does any of the following: 
1.  Takes possession or control of the property of another, or property in the possession of another, with the intent to deprive the other thereof. 
2.  Misappropriates property which the person has in trust, or property of another which the person has in the person's possession or control, whether such possession is lawful or unlawful, by using or disposing of it in a manner which is inconsistent with or a denial of the trust or of the owner's right's in such property, or appropriates such property to the person's own use, when the owner of such property is known to the person. Failure by a bailee or lessee of personal property to return the property within seventy-two hours after a time specified in a written agreement of lease or bailment shall be evidence of misappropriation. 
3.  Obtains the labor or services of another, or a transfer of possession, or ownership of another, or the beneficial use of property of another, by deception. When compensation for goods and services is ordinarily paid immediately upon the obtaining of such goods or the rendering of such services, the refusal to pay or leaving the premises without payment or offer to pay or without having obtained from the owner or operator the right to pay subsequent to leaving the premises gives rise to an inference that the goods or services were obtained by deception. 
4.  Exercises control over stolen property knowing such property to have been stolen, or having reasonable cause to believe that such property has been stolen, unless the person's purpose is to promptly restore it to the owner or to deliver it to an appropriate public officer. The fact that a person is found in possession of property which has been stolen from two or more persons on separate occasions, or that the person is a dealer or other person familiar with the value of such property and has acquired it for a consideration which is far below its reasonable value, shall be evidence from which the court or jury may infer that the person knew or believed that the property had been stolen. 
5.  Takes, destroys, conceals, or disposes of property in which someone else has a security interest, with the intent to defraud the secured party. 
6.  This paragraph intentionally omitted. 
7.  Obtains gas, electricity or water from a public utility or obtains cable television or telephone service from an unauthorized connection to the supply or service line or by intentionally altering, adjusting, removing or tampering with the metering or service device so as to cause inaccurate readings. 
8.  This paragraph intentionally omitted. 
9.  Obtains the temporary use of video rental property with the intent to deprive the owner of the use and possession of the video rental property without the consent of the owner. 
10.  Any act that is declared to be theft by any provision of the Algona Municipal Code. 
B.  The theft of property as defined above not exceeding two hundred dollars in value is a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 910 § 4 (part), 2003) 
9.36.020 - Value. 
    The value of property is its highest value by any reasonable standard at the time that it is stolen. Reasonable standard includes but is not limited to market value within the community, actual value, or replacement value. 
(Ord. 910 § 4 (part), 2003) 
9.36.030 - Video rental property theft. 
A.  "Video rental property" means an audiovisual recording, including a videotape, videodisc, or other tangible medium of expression on which an audiovisual work is recorded or otherwise stored, or any equipment or supplies used to view the recording, and which is held out for rental to the public in the ordinary course of business. 
B.  The fact that a person obtains possession of video rental property by means of deception, including but not limited to furnishing a false name, address, or other identification to the owner, is evidence that possession was obtained with intent to knowingly deprive the owner of the use and possession of the video rental property. 
C.  The fact that a person having lawfully obtained possession of video rental property, fails to pay the owner the fair market value of the video rental property or to return or make arrangements acceptable to the owner to return the video rental property to the owner within forty-eight hours after receipt of written notice and demand from the owner is evidence of an intent to knowingly deprive the owner of the use and possession of the video rental property. 
D.  It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under Section 9.36.010(A)(9)(a), if the defendant in possession of video rental property pays the owner the fair market value of the video rental property or returns the property to the owner within forty-eight hours of arrest, together with any standard overdue charges for the period that the owner was unlawfully deprived of possession, but not to exceed one hundred twenty days, and the value of the damage to the property, if any. 
(Ord. 910 § 4 (part), 2003) 
9.36.040 - Theft detection devices-Shield or removal prohibited. 
A.  A person shall not remove or attempt to remove a theft detection device with the intent of committing a theft and without the permission of the merchant who is displaying or selling the goods, wares or merchandise. 
B.  For the purposes of this section, "theft detection shielding device" means any laminated or coated bag or device designed to shield merchandise from detection by an electronic or magnetic theft alarm system or any other system designed to alert a person of a possible theft. "Theft detection device" means any electronic or other device attached to goods, wares, or merchandise on display or for sale by a merchant. 
C.  A person who violates this section commits a simple misdemeanor if the value of the goods, wares or merchandise does not exceed two hundred dollars. 
(Ord. 910 § 4 (part), 2003) 
Chapter 9.40 - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA 

9.40.010 - Definitions. 
A.  As used in this chapter, "drug paraphernalia" means all equipment, products, or materials of any kind used or attempted to be used in combination with a controlled substance, except those items used in combination with the lawful use of a controlled substance, to knowingly or intentionally and primarily do any of the following: 
1.  Manufacture a controlled substance; 
2.  Inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance; 
3.  Test the strength, effectiveness, or purity of a controlled substance; 
4.  Enhance the effect of a controlled substance. 
B.  "Drug paraphernalia" does not include hypodermic needles or syringes if manufactured, delivered, sold or possessed for a lawful purpose. 
(Ord. 910 § 5 (part), 2003) 
9.40.020 - Violation. 
    It is unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally manufacture, deliver, sell, or possess drug paraphernalia. 
(Ord. 910 § 5 (part), 2003) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapter 10.04 - TITLE AND DEFINITIONS 

10.04.010 - Title. 
    This title may be known and cited as the "Algona Traffic Code." 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0101) 
10.04.020 - Definitions. 
    Where words and phrases used in this chapter are defined by state law, such definitions shall apply to their use in this chapter and are adopted by reference. Those definitions so adopted that need further definition or are reiterated, and other words and phrases used in this title, shall have the following meanings: 
1.  "Business district" means the territory contiguous to and including the following designated streets: 
a.  State Street from Jones Street to Williams Street; 
b.  Nebraska Street from Minnesota Street to Hall Street; 
c.  Call Street from Jones Street to Williams Street. 
2.  "Controlled access facility" means the highways or streets designated by Section 10.48.040 of this title. 
3.  "Park or parking" means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
4.  "Peace officer" means every officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
5.  "Residence district" means the territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business, suburban or school district, where forty percent or more of the frontage on such a highway for a distance of three hundred feet or more is occupied by dwellings or by dwellings and buildings in use for business. 
6.  "School district" means the territory contiguous to and including a highway for a distance of two hundred feet in either direction from a school house. 
7.  "Stand or standing" means the halting of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers. 
8.  "Stop" when required, means the complete cessation of movement. 
9.  "Stop or stopping" when prohibited, means any halting of a vehicle, even momentarily, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a peace officer or traffic-control sign or signal. 
10.  "Suburban district" means all other parts of the city not included in the business, school or residence districts. 
11.  "Traffic-control device" means all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter, lawfully placed or erected for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
12.  "Vehicle" means any vehicle in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, street or alley. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0102) 
Chapter 10.08 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

10.08.010 - Administration and enforcement. 
    Provisions of this chapter and the state law relating to motor vehicles and law of the road shall be enforced by the police chief. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0103) 
10.08.020 - Officials authorized to direct traffic. 
    A peace officer, and any officer of the fire department when at the scene of a fire, is authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws. In the event of an emergency traffic may be directed as conditions require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0104) 
10.08.030 - Traffic accidents-Report filing required. 
    The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident within the limits of this city shall file a report as and when required by the State Department of Public Safety. A copy of this report shall be filed with the city for the confidential use of peace officers and shall be subject to the provisions of Section 321.271 of the Code of Iowa, 1975. Such reports, or cards referring to them, shall be filed alphabetically by location. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0105) 
10.08.040 - Traffic accidents-Police investigation. 
    The police chief shall investigate all accidents reported. If sufficient evidence of a violation is found, proper action will be taken to punish the violator. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0106) 
10.08.050 - Traffic accidents-Examination of patterns. 
    Whenever the accidents at any particular location become numerous, the chief of police shall conduct studies of such accidents and propose remedial measures. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0107) 
10.08.060 - Traffic accidents-Recordkeeping. 
    The police chief shall maintain a suitable record of all traffic accidents, warnings, arrests, convictions and complaints reported for each driver during the most recent three-year period. Such reports shall be filed alphabetically under the name of the driver concerned. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0108) 
10.08.070 - Habitual traffic violators. 
    The police chief shall study the cases of all drivers charged with frequent or serious violations of the traffic laws or involved in frequent traffic accidents or any serious accident, and shall attempt to discover the reasons therefor, and shall take whatever steps are lawful and reasonable to prevent the same, or to have the license of such persons suspended or revoked as provided by state law. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0109) 
10.08.080 - Annual traffic report issuance. 
    The police chief shall prepare annually a traffic report which shall be filed with the mayor and council. Such report shall contain information on the number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed and injured, the number and nature of violations, and other pertinent traffic data including plans and recommendations for future traffic safety activities. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.0110) 
10.08.090 - Arrest or citation for violation. 
    Whenever a police officer has reasonable cause to believe that a person has violated any provision of this chapter such officer may: 
A.  Immediate Arrest. Immediately arrest such person and take him before a local magistrate; or 
B.  Issue Citation. Without arresting the person, prepare in quadruplicate a combined traffic citation and complaint as adopted by the Iowa Commissioner of Public Safety and deliver the original and a copy to the court where the defendant is to appear, a copy to the defendant and retain the fourth copy for the records of the city. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.1201) 
10.08.100 - Parking violations-Fee. 
    Admitted violations of any parking restrictions imposed by this chapter may be charged upon a simple notice of a fine of three dollars payable at the office of the city clerk. If such fine is not paid within seven days, a citation shall be issued as provided above. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.1202) 
10.08.110 - Parking violations-Issuance. 
    When a vehicle is parked in violation of this chapter and the driver is not present, the notice of fine or citation as hereinbefore provided shall be attached to the vehicle in a conspicuous place. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.1203) 
10.08.120 - Parking violations-Illegal parking presumptions. 
    In any proceeding charging a standing or parking violation, a prima facie presumption that the registered owner was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred, shall be raised by proof that: 
A.  The particular vehicle described in the information was parked in violation of this chapter; and 
B.  The defendant named in the information was the registered owner at the time in question. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.1204) 
10.08.130 - Vehicle impoundment-Authorized when. 
    A police officer is authorized to remove, or cause to be removed, a vehicle from a street, public alley, public parking lot or highway to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the city, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated: 
A.  Disabled Vehicle. When a vehicle is upon a roadway and is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person or persons in charge of the vehicle are by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
B.  Illegally Parked Vehicle. When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so illegally parked as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
C.  Parked Over Forty-Eight-Hour Period. When any vehicle is left parked upon a street for a continuous period of forty-eight hours or more. A diligent effort shall first be made to locate the owner. If the owner is found he shall be given an opportunity to remove the vehicle. 
D.  Costs. In addition to the standard penalties provided, the owner or driver of any vehicle impounded for the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be required to pay the reasonable cost of towing and storage. 
(Prior code § 2.1-2.1205) 
Chapter 10.12 - STATE STATUTES ADOPTED 

10.12.010 - Violation of regulations. 
    Any person who fails to abide by the provisions of this chapter and the applicable provisions of the following state statutory laws relating to motor vehicles and the statutory laws of the road is in violation of this chapter. The following sections of the Code of Iowa, 2001, as amended, are hereby incorporated by reference: 
17. Misdemeanor to violate registration provisions: 321.17; 20B. Proof of security against liability - driving without liability coverage: 321.20B; 25. Application for registration and title-cards attached: 321.25; 32. Registration card signed, carried, and exhibited: 321.32; 34. Plates or validation sticker furnished - retained by owner - special plates: 321.34; 37. Display of plates: 321.37; 38. Plates, method of attaching - imitations prohibited: 321.38; 256. Obedience to official traffic-control devices: 321.256; 257. Official traffic control signal: 321.257; 259. Unauthorized signs, signals or markings: 321.259; 260. Interference with devices, signs, or signals - unlawful possession: 321.260; 262. Damage to vehicle: 321.262; 263. Information and aid-leaving scene of accident: 321.263; 264. Striking unattended vehicle: 321.264; 265. Striking fixtures upon a highway: 321.265; 266. Reporting accidents: 321.266; 267. Supplemental reports: 321.267; 268. Driver unable to report: 321.268; 275. Operation of motorcycles and motorized bicycles: 321.275; 276. Use of electronic communication device while driving-Text-messaging: 321.276; 277. Reckless driving: 321.277; 277A. Careless driving: 321.277A; 278. Drag racing prohibited: 321.278; 281. Actions against bicyclists: 321.281; 284. Open containers in motor vehicles - drivers: 321.284; 284A. Open containers in motor vehicles - passengers: 321.284A; 285. Fail to stop in assured clear distance: 321.285; 285. Speed: 321.285; 288. Control of vehicle - reduced speed: 321.288; 294. Minimum speed regulation: 321.294; 295. Limitation on bridge or elevated structures: 321.295; 297. Driving on right-hand side of roadway - exceptions: 321.297; 298. Meeting and turning to right: 321.298; 299. Overtaking a vehicle: 321.299; 302. Overtaking on the right: 321.302; 303. Limitations on overtaking on the left: 321.303; 304. Prohibited passing: 321.304; 305. One-way roadways and rotary traffic islands: 321.305; 306. Roadways laned for traffic: 321.306; 307. Following too closely: 321.307; 308. Motor trucks and towed vehicles - distance requirements: 321.308; 309. Towing - convoys - drawbars: 321.309; 310. Towing four-wheeled trailers: 321.310; 311. Turning at intersections: 321.311; 312. Turning on curve or crest of grade: 321.312; 313. Starting parked vehicle: 321.313; 314. When signal required: 321.314; 315. Signal continuous: 321.315; 316. Stopping: 321.316; 317. Signals by hand and arm or signal device: 321.317; 318. Method of giving hand and arm signals: 321.318; 319. Entering intersections from different highways: 321.319; 320. Left turns - yielding: 321.320; 321. Entering through highways: 321.321; 322. Vehicles entering stop or yield intersection: 321.322; 323. Moving vehicle backward on highway: 321.323; 323A. Approaching certain stationary vehicles: 321.323A; 324. Operation on approach of emergency vehicles: 321.324; 324A. Funeral processions: 321.324A; 325. Pedestrians subject to signals: 321.325; 326. Pedestrians on left: 321.326; 327. Pedestrians' right of way: 321.327; 328. Crossing at other than crosswalk: 321.328; 329. Duty of driver - pedestrians crossing or working on highways: 321.329; 330. Use of crosswalks: 321.330; 331. Pedestrians soliciting rides: 321.331; 332. White canes restricted to blind persons: 321.332; 333. Duty of drivers: 321.333; 334. Penalties: 321.334; 340. Driving through safety zone: 321.340; 341. Obedience to signal of train: 321.341; 342. Stop at certain railroad crossings - posting warning: 321.342; 343. Certain vehicles must stop: 321.343; 344. Heavy equipment at crossing: 321.344; 344A. Reported violations for failure to stop at a railroad crossing: 321.344A; 344B. Immediate safety threat - penalty: 321.344B; 353. Stop before crossing sidewalks - right of way: 321.353; 354. Stopping on traveled way: 321.354; 355. Disabled vehicle: 321.355; 356. Officers authorized to remove: 321.356; 357. Removed from bridge: 321.357; 358. Stopping, standing or parking: 321.358; 359. Moving other vehicle: 321.359; 360. Theaters, hotels and auditoriums: 321.360; 361. Additional parking regulations: 321.361; 362. Unattended motor vehicle: 321.362; 363. Obstruction to driver's view: 321.363; 364. Preventing contamination of food by hazardous material: 321.364; 365. Coasting prohibited: 321.365; 366. Acts prohibited on fully controlled-access facilities: 321.366; 367. Following fire apparatus: 321.367; 368. Crossing fire hose: 321.368; 369. Putting debris on highway: 321.369; 370. Removing injurious material: 321.370; 371. Clearing up wrecks: 321.371; 372. Discharging pupils - regulations: 321.372; 372A. Prompt investigation of reported violation of failing to obey school bus warning devices: 321.372A; 373. Required construction - rules adopted: 321.373; 374. Inspection - seal of approval: 321.374; 376. License - permit - instruction requirement: 321.376; 379. Violations: 321.379; 381. Movement of unsafe or improperly equipped vehicles: 321.381; 381A. Operation of low-speed vehicles: 321.381A; 382. Upgrade pulls - minimum speed: 321.382; 383. Exceptions - slow vehicles identified: 321.383; 384. When lighted lamps required: 321.384; 385. Head lamps on motor vehicles: 321.385; 385A. Citation for unlighted headlamp or rear lamp: 321.385A; 386. Head lamps on motorcycles and motorized bicycles: 321.386; 387. Rear lamps: 321.387; 388. Illuminating plates: 321.388; 389. Reflector requirement: 321.389; 390. Reflector requirements: 321.390; 392. Clearance and identification lights: 321.392; 393. Color and mounting: 321.393; 394. Lamp or flag on projecting load: 321.394; 395. Lamps on parked vehicles: 321.395; 396. Exception: 321.396; 397. Lamps on bicycles: 321.397; 398. Lamps on other vehicles and equipment: 321.398; 402. Spot lamps: 321.402; 403. Auxiliary driving lamps: 321.403; 404. Signal lamps and signal devices: 321.404; 404A. Light-restricting devices prohibited: 321.404A; 405. Self-illumination: 321.405; 406. Cowl lamps: 321.406; 408. Back-up lamps: 321.408; 409. Mandatory lighting equipment: 321.409; 415. Required usage of lighting devices: 321.415; 417. Single-beam road-lighting equipment: 321.417; 418. Alternate road-lighting equipment: 321.418; 419. Number of driving lamps required or permitted: 321.419; 420. Number of lamps lighted: 321.420; 421. Special restrictions on lamps: 321.421; 422. Red light in front: 321.422; 423. Flashing lights: 321.423; 430. Brake, hitch and control requirements: 321.430; 431. Performance ability: 321.431;
