C.  The decision of the hearing officer shall be final. 
D.  Failure of the objector to appear at the scheduled hearing shall constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing and the bond shall be forfeited. 
E.  The only issue to be considered at the hearing shall be the validity of the determination that the vehicle is an abandoned vehicle. The hearing will not be determinative of or adjudicate any outstanding or unsettled traffic violation notice or warrant. 
(Added during 1988 codification) 
10.52.060 - Auction or disposal-State statutes adopted. 
    The department shall follow the procedures in state law for the auction or disposal of abandoned vehicles. 
(Added during 1988 codification) 
10.52.070 - Limitation on liability. 
    No person, firm, corporation, unit of government, garage keeper or police authority upon whose property an abandoned vehicle is found or who disposes of such abandoned vehicle in accordance with this chapter or the applicable state law shall be liable for damages by reason of the removal, sale, or disposal of such vehicle. 
(Ord. 774 § 1 (part), 1991) 
10.52.080 - Penalty for abandonment. 
    Any person who abandons a vehicle shall be guilty of a simple misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 774 § 1 (part), 1991) 
Chapter 10.56 - BICYCLES, SKATEBOARDS AND SCOOTERS 
Article I. - Bicycle Licensing 

10.56.010 - License-Required. 
    No person who resides within the city shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles unless such bicycle has been licensed and a license decal is attached thereto as provided herein. 
(Ord. 679 § 1 (part), 1984: prior code § 2.1-5.0201(1)) 
10.56.020 - License-Application. 
    Application for a bicycle license and license decal shall be made upon a form provided by the city and shall be made to the chief of police. A license fee of two dollars shall be paid to the city before each license is granted. 
(Ord. 679 § 1 (part), 1984: prior code § 2.1-5.0201(2)) 
10.56.030 - License-Issuance. 
    The chief of police, upon receiving proper application therefor is authorized to issue a bicycle license which shall be effective immediately. 
(Ord. 679 § 1 (part), 1984: prior code § 2.1-5.0201(3)) 
10.56.040 - Transfer of ownership. 
    Upon the sale or other transfer of a licensed bicycle, the licensee shall remove the license decal. 
(Ord. 679 § 1 (part), 1984: prior code § 2.1-5.0201(4)) 
10.56.050 - License-Term. 
    All licenses issued hereunder shall be valid for as long as the applicant retains ownership of the bicycle licensed hereunder. Transfer of ownership or possession of a bicycle licensed hereunder shall render such license void. 
(Ord. 679 § 1 (part), 1984: prior code § 2.1-5.0201(5)) 
10.56.060 - License plates or decals-Issuance. 
    The chief of police upon issuing a bicycle license shall also issue a license plate or decal bearing the license number assigned to the bicycle and the name of the city. 
(Ord. 679 § 2 (part), 1984: prior code § 2.1-5.0202(1)) 
10.56.070 - License plates or decals-Attachment to bicycle. 
    The chief of police shall cause such license plate or decal to be firmly attached to the bicycle for which issued in such position as to be plainly visible from the rear. 
(Ord. 679 § 2 (part), 1984: prior code § 2.1-5.0202(2)) 
10.56.080 - License plates or decals-Removal unlawful. 
    No person shall remove a license plate or decal from a bicycle during the period for which issued except upon a transfer of ownership or in the event the bicycle is dismantled and no longer operated upon any street in the city. 
(Ord. 679 § 2 (part), 1984: prior code § 2.1-5.0202(3)) 
10.56.090 - Recordkeeping responsibilities. 
    The chief of police shall keep a record of the number of each license, the date issued, the name and address of the person to whom issued, and the number on the frame of the bicycle for which issued, and a record of all bicycle license fees collected by him. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0203) 
10.56.100 - Rental agencies-Licensing and equipment regulations. 
    A rental agency shall not rent or offer any bicycle for rent unless the bicycle is licensed and a license plate is attached thereto as provided herein and such bicycle is equipped with the lamps and other equipment required in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0204) 
Article II. - Bicycle Regulations 

10.56.110 - Scope of regulations. 
    These regulations shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated herein. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0101) 
10.56.120 - Signal device required. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least one hundred feet, except that a bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0104(2)) 
10.56.130 - Brakes required. 
    Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0104(3)) 
10.56.140 - Nighttime use. 
    Every bicycle shall be equipped with a lamp on the front exhibiting a white light, at any time from sunset to sunrise, visible from a distance of at least three hundred feet to the front and with a lamp on the rear exhibiting a red light visible from a distance of three hundred feet to the rear; except that a red reflector meeting the requirements of Chapter 321 of the Code of Iowa, 1987, may be used in lieu of a rear light. 
(Amended during 1988 codification: prior code § 2.1-5.0104(1)) 
10.56.150 - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at the curb, in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0103) 
10.56.160 - Observance of traffic regulations. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of the state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by the traffic code of this city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. Whenever such person dismounts from a bicycle he shall be subject to all regulations applicable to pedestrians. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(1)) 
10.56.170 - Riding on bicycles. 
    A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(2)) 
10.56.180 - Riding abreast. 
    Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(3)) 
10.56.190 - Use of bicycle paths required. 
    Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(4)) 
10.56.200 - Speed restrictions. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(5)) 
10.56.210 - Emerging from alleys or driveways. 
    The operators of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on such sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(6)) 
10.56.220 - Carrying article prohibited. 
    No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the handle bars. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(7)) 
10.56.230 - Riding on sidewalks. 
A.  No person shall ride a bicycle on a sidewalk except in accordance herewith. 
B.  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district. 
C.  When signs are erected on any sidewalk or roadway prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon by any person, no person shall disobey the signs. 
D.  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(8)) 
10.56.240 - Towing. 
    It is unlawful for any person riding a bicycle to be towed or to tow any other vehicle upon the streets of the city. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(9)) 
10.56.250 - Following fire trucks. 
    No person riding a bicycle shall follow a fire truck or other fire equipment at any time. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(10)) 
10.56.260 - Improper riding. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle in an irregular or reckless manner such as zig-zagging, stunting, speeding or otherwise so as to disregard the safety of the operation or others. 
(Prior code § 2.1-5.0102(11)) 
10.56.270 - Unlawful use upon tennis courts. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle upon any tennis court. 
(Ord. 817 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.56.280 - Temporary seizure of bicycle. 
    In the event a police officer has determined that an individual has violated any section of this article, said officer shall have the option, in lieu of issuing a citation, of temporarily seizing the bicycle being operated by the individual committing the offense for a period of up to fourteen days. If the individual who is violating a section of this article has committed any previous offense of any section of this chapter within the preceding three hundred sixty-five days, the officer shall have the option to temporarily seize the bicycle for up to thirty days. At the end of the appropriate number of days, the owner of the bicycle shall be able to pick up the bicycle at the Algona police department. The police shall have the ability to temporarily seize the bicycle being ridden by the violator even if the bicycle does not belong to the person committing the violation. If the person accused of violating a section of this article desires to contest the temporary seizure of the bicycle, that person shall file an application for hearing within five days after the bicycle was temporarily seized with the Kossuth County clerk of court, magistrate's division, at the Kossuth County Courthouse. A hearing shall then be set as soon as practical by the magistrate and shall be tried to the magistrate. 
(Ord. 817 § 1 (part), 1995) 
Article III. - Skateboards, Scooters, Roller Skates and Roller Blades 

10.56.290 - Unlawful use upon designated sidewalks. 
A.  No person shall roller skate, roller blade or ride a skateboard or scooter upon a sidewalk located in the following areas: 
1.  Either side of State Street from Jones Street to Hall Street; 
2.  Either side of Harlan Street from the alley between Nebraska Street and State Street north to the alley between State Street and Call Street; 
3.  Either side of Moore Street from the alley between Nebraska Street and State Street north to the alley between State Street and Call Street; 
4.  Either side of Dodge Street from the alley between Nebraska Street and State Street north to the alley between State Street and Call Street; and 
5.  Either side of Thorington Street from the alley between Nebraska Street and State Street north to the alley between State Street and Call Street. 
B.  When signs are erected on any sidewalk prohibiting roller skating, roller blading or the riding of skateboards or scooters thereon by any person, no person shall disobey the signs. 
C.  Whenever any person is roller skating, roller blading, or riding a skateboard or scooter upon any sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing. 
(Ord. 817 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.56.300 - Towing. 
    It is unlawful for any person who is roller skating, roller blading, riding a skateboard or riding a scooter to be towed or to tow any other person upon the streets of the city. 
(Ord. 817 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.56.310 - Following fire trucks. 
    No person who is roller skating, roller blading, riding a skateboard or riding a scooter shall follow a fire truck or other fire equipment at any time. 
(Ord. 817 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.56.320 - Improper riding. 
    No person shall roller skate, roller blade, ride a skateboard or ride a scooter in an irregular or reckless manner such as zigzagging, stunting, traveling at an excessive speed or acting in any other manner so as to disregard the safety of the operation or others. 
(Ord. 817 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.56.330 - Unlawful use upon tennis courts. 
    No person shall roller skate, roller blade or ride a skateboard or scooter upon any tennis court. 
(Ord. 817 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.56.340 - Temporary seizure of skateboards, scooters, roller skates and/or roller blades. 
    In the event a police officer has determined that an individual has violated any section of this article, said officer shall have the option, in lieu of issuing a citation, of temporarily seizing the skateboard, scooter, roller skates and/or roller blades being used by the individual committing the offense for a period of up to fourteen days. If the individual who is violating a section of this article has committed any previous offense of any section of this chapter within the preceding three hundred sixty-five days, the officer shall have the option to temporarily seize the skateboard, scooter, roller skates and/or roller blades for up to thirty days. At the end of the appropriate number of days, the owner of the skateboard, scooter, roller skates and/or roller blades shall be able to pick up the skateboard, scooter, roller skates and/or roller blades at the Algona police department. The police shall have the ability to temporarily seize the skateboard, scooter, roller skates and/or roller blades being ridden by the violator even if the skateboard, scooter, roller skates and/or roller blades do not belong to the person committing the violation. If the person accused of violating a section of this article desires to contest the temporary seizure of the skateboard, scooter, roller skates and/or roller blades, that person shall file an application for hearing within five days after the skateboard, scooter, roller skates and/or roller blades were temporarily seized with the Kossuth County clerk of court, magistrate's division, at the Kossuth County Courthouse. A hearing shall then be set as soon as practical by the magistrate and shall be tried to the magistrate. 
(Ord. 817 § 1 (part), 1995) 
Chapter 10.60 - SNOWMOBILES 

10.60.010 - Snowmobile defined. 
    "Snowmobile" means a motorized vehicle weighing less than one thousand pounds which uses sled-type runners or skis, endless belt-type tread, or any combination of runners, skis, or tread, and is designed for travel on snow or ice. 
(Ord. 910 § 3, 2003) 
10.60.020 - Manner of operation-General requirements. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile in the city except as hereafter provided. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03 (part)) 
10.60.030 - Observance of traffic regulations mandatory. 
    Snowmobile operators shall observe all state and local traffic-control regulations and devices. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(3)) 
10.60.040 - Registration-Display required. 
    No snowmobile shall be operated in the city unless registered pursuant to state law and unless the identifying number set forth in the registration is displayed on each side of the snowmobile. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(1)) 
10.60.050 - Standard equipment regulations. 
    All snowmobiles shall be equipped with muffling devices, brakes, lights and other equipment required by state law or regulation. Mufflers shall be properly attached and reduce the noise of operation of the vehicle to the minimum noise necessary for operating the vehicle and no person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass or similar device on the vehicle. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(2)) 
10.60.060 - Lights. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile without a lighted headlight and taillight when required for safety. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(7)) 
10.60.070 - Flag required. 
    No snowmobile shall be operated upon a street without displaying a flag with an area of not less than six by nine inches of flourescent orange color on a staff holder to put such flag at least five feet above the surface of the street. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(9)) 
10.60.080 - Dead man throttle. 
    No snowmobile shall be operated within the city unless equipped with a "dead man" throttle which when pressure is removed from the accelerator or throttle causes the engine to be disengaged from the drive mechanism. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(15)) 
10.60.090 - Careless operation unlawful. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile in a careless, reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the person or property of another or to cause injury or damage thereto. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(5)) 
10.60.100 - Speed limitations. 
    Snowmobiles shall not be operated on streets at a speed in excess of that posted nor at any time at a rate of speed greater than reasonable and proper under all existing circumstances. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(4)) 
10.60.110 - Yield required. 
    All snowmobiles while operating upon public streets shall upon approaching any intersection, yield to all other traffic which is within the intersection or approaching so closely as to constitute a hazard. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(18)) 
10.60.120 - Leaving unattended unlawful. 
    No operator or owner shall leave or allow a snowmobile to be or remain unattended on public property while the motor is running or with keys in the ignition switch. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(8)) 
10.60.130 - Disturbing the peace. 
    In a manner so as to create loud, unnecessary or unusual noise so as to disturb or interfere with the peace and quiet of other persons. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(17)) 
10.60.140 - Crossing prohibited streets or highways-Authorized when. 
    A snowmobile may make a direct crossing of a prohibited street or highway provided: 
A.  The crossing is made at an angle of approximately ninety degrees to the direction of the street or highway and at a place where no obstruction prevents a quick and safe crossing; and 
B.  The snowmobile is brought to a complete stop before crossing the shoulder or main traveling way of the street or highway; 
C.  The driver yields the right-of-way to all oncoming traffic which constitutes an immediate hazard. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(10)) 
10.60.150 - Operating under the influence. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotics or habit-forming drugs. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(6)) 
10.60.160 - Traveling single file required. 
    Snowmobiles shall be driven in a single file manner in the proper lane of traffic as close to the curb or edge of roadway as is possible under existing conditions. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(14)) 
10.60.170 - Towing. 
    No item shall be towed by a snowmobile unless coupled to the snowmobile by a rigid tow bar. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(16)) 
10.60.180 - Operation by minors. 
    No person under sixteen years of age shall operate a snowmobile on or across a public street unless he has in his possession a valid safety certificate issued to him by the state conservation commission nor shall the owner or operator of any snowmobile having an engine rating of three cubic centimeters or more permit any person under twelve years of age to operate such a snowmobile at any time except when accompanied by a responsible person of at least eighteen years of age. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(11)) 
10.60.190 - Hours of operation limited. 
    No snowmobile shall be operated in the city between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and seven a.m. except for emergency situations or for loading and unloading from a transport trailer. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(12)) 
10.60.200 - Time restrictions regulating use. 
    Snowmobiles shall not be operated upon city streets during the period from April 1st to September 30th of each year. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.03(13)) 
10.60.210 - Operation limitations-General requirements. 
    The operators of snowmobiles shall observe the limitations set out in Sections 10.60.220 through 10.60.260 as to where snowmobiles may be operated. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.02 (part)) 
10.60.220 - Operation limitations-Unplowed streets. 
    Snowmobiles may be operated upon streets which have not been plowed during the snow season. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.02(1)) 
10.60.230 - Operation limitations-Public ways designated. 
    Snowmobiles may be operated on any other street within the city except the following designated streets: 
A.  Phillips Street. On Phillips Street from the city limits on the south to Diagonal Street; 
B.  State Street. On State Street from Phillips Street to Ridgley; 
C.  Jones Street. On Jones Street from McGregor Street to the north corporate limits; 
D.  Diagonal Street. On Diagonal Street from Phillips to Roan; 
E.  Commercial Street. On Commercial Street from Roan to Main Street; 
F.  Main Street. On Main Street from McGregor to Highway 18; 
G.  McGregor Street. On McGregor Street from East Street to Lowe Street; 
H.  Call Street. On Call Street from Jones to Ridgley; 
I.  Nebraska Street. On Nebraska Street from Jones to Ridgley; 
J.  Highway 18. On Highway 18 from the city limits on the east to the city limits on the west; 
K.  Highway 169 North. On Highway 169 North from Highway 18 to the city limits on the north. 
(Ord. 628 §§ 1, 2, 3, 4, 1980: prior code § 2.1-6.02(2)) 
10.60.240 - Operation limitations-Parks and other recreation areas. 
    Snowmobiles shall not be operated in any city park, playground or upon any other publicly owned property except with the express permission of the governing body thereof. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.02(3)) 
10.60.250 - Trespassing on private property. 
    No snowmobile shall be operated upon private property without the express consent of the owner thereof. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.02(4)) 
10.60.260 - Operating on sidewalks and adjacent areas. 
    No snowmobiles shall be operated upon the public sidewalk, nor shall they be operated upon that portion of the street located between the curbline and the sidewalk or property line commonly referred to as the "parking" except for purposes of crossing the same to a public street upon which operation is authorized by the chapter. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.02(5)) 
10.60.270 - Violation-Penalty. 
    A snowmobile being operated in violation of Section 10.60.040 of this chapter may be impounded by the chief of police for a period to be determined by the chief but not to exceed seven days. 
(Prior code § 2.1-6.04) 
Chapter 10.64 - RAILROADS 

10.64.010 - Definitions. 
    For use in this chapter, the following terms are defined: 
A.  "Operator" means any individual, partnership, corporation or other association that owns, operates, drives or controls a railroad train. 
B.  "Railroad train" means any steam, electric or other motor driven engine and the cars, if any, coupled to the engine operated on rails, but does not include interurbans and street cars. 
(Prior code § 8-3.01) 
10.64.020 - Obstructing streets unlawful-Exceptions. 
A.  A railroad corporation or its employees shall not operate any train in such a manner as to prevent vehicular use of any highway, street or alley for a period of time in excess of ten minutes except: 
1.  Comply with Signals. When necessary to comply with signals affecting the safety of the movement of trains; 
2.  Avoid Striking. When necessary to avoid striking any object or person on the track; 
3.  Disabled. When the train is disabled; 
4.  Safety Regulations. When necessary to comply with governmental safety regulations including, but not limited to, speed ordinances and speed regulations. 
B.  Any officer or employee of a railroad corporation violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. An employee shall not be guilty of such violation if his action was necessary to comply with the direct order or instructions of a railroad corporation or it's supervisors. such guilt shall then be with the railroad corporation. 
(Prior code § 8-3.02) 
10.64.030 - Crossing maintenance required. 
    Operators shall construct and maintain good, sufficient and safe crossings over any street traversed by their rails. 
(Prior code § 8-3.03) 
Chapter 10.68 - GOLF CARTS 

10.68.010 - Manner of operation-General requirements. 
    No person shall operate a golf cart in the city except as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.020 - Observance of traffic regulations mandatory. 
    Golf cart operators shall observe all state and local traffic control regulations and devises. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.030 - Permit required. 
    No golf cart shall be operated in the city unless a permit from the Algona city clerk has been issued to the owner of said golf cart. The permit received from the city must be with the golf cart whenever it is operated within the city. The permit is good for the calendar year within which it is issued and shall be renewed annually. The fee for said permit is twenty-five dollars per year. Prior to any initial or renewal permit being issued, the golf cart shall be inspected by a person designated by the city to make sure said golf cart complies with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.040 - Proof of liability insurance. 
    As part of the permit process, the owner of the golf cart must provide proof of liability insurance before a permit will be issued. The proof of insurance must be with the golf cart whenever said golf cart is in operation. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.050 - Standard equipment regulations. 
    All golf carts shall be equipped with the following: 
A.  Brakes; 
B.  Brake lights; 
C.  Turn signals; 
D.  Slow moving vehicle sign; 
E.  Bicycle safety flag on a staff holder to put such flag at least five feet above the surface of the street; 
F.  Any other safety equipment which may be required for golf carts by Chapter 321 of the Code of Iowa. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.060 - Operation regulations. 
    The following regulations apply to the operation of a golf cart within the city. 
A.  Any operator of a golf cart must have a valid driver's license and be eighteen years of age or older; 
B.  All riders in the golf cart must remain seated at all times; 
C.  No more than two people may ride in the front seat of a golf cart and no more than two people may ride in the backseat of a golf cart, if said seat exists. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.070 - Times of operation limited. 
    Golf carts may be operated during the following times: 
A.  From sunrise to sunset, during the time of year when daylight savings time is in effect. 
B.  Golf carts are prohibited on streets during inclement weather. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.080 - Sidewalks and adjacent areas. 
    No golf carts shall be operated upon the public sidewalk, nor shall they be operated upon that portion of the street located between the curb line and the sidewalk or property line, referred to as the "parking" except for purposes of crossing the same to a public street upon which operation is authorized by this chapter. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.090 - Streets upon which golf carts may be operated. 
    Golf carts may only be operated on streets with speed limits of twenty-five miles per hour or less. Regardless of the speed limit, golf carts are prohibited from being operated on the following streets, except to cross said streets: 
A.  U.S. Highway 169; 
B.  U.S. Highway 18; 
C.  McGregor Street; 
D.  Main Street from Commercial Street to U.S. Highway 18; 
E.  Commercial Street from Diagonal Street to Putnam Street; 
F.  Putnam Street from Commercial Street to Oak Street; 
G.  Oak Street from Putnam Street to Finn Drive; 
H.  Finn Drive; 
I.  Phillips Street from State Street to Diagonal Street; 
J.  Diagonal Street; 
K.  State Street from Jones Street to Hall Street; 
L.  Call Street from Jones Street to Phillips Street; 
M.  Norwood Drive from U.S. Highway 169 to U.S. Highway 18. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.100 - Careless operation unlawful. 
    No person shall operate a golf cart in a careless, reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the person or property of another or to cause injury or damage thereto. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.110 - Operating under the influence. 
    No person shall operate a golf cart while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotics or habit forming drugs. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.120 - Towing. 
    No item shall be towed by a golf cart. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.130 - Trespassing on private property. 
    No golf cart shall be operated upon private property without the express consent of the owner thereof. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.140 - Operation limitation-Cemeteries. 
    No golf carts shall be operated on roadways or other areas in cemeteries located in the city. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.68.150 - Community events-Exception. 
    The Algona chief of police may grant exceptions and allow any type of golf cart to be used on any city street by community and civic organizations for community events. 
(Ord. 953 § 1 (part), 2008) 
Chapter 10.72 - ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES AND OFF-ROAD UTILITY VEHICLES 

10.72.010 - Definitions. 
    For use in this chapter the following terms are defined: 
1.  "All-terrain vehicle" or "ATV" as defined in Section 321I.1 of the Code of Iowa, amended. 
2.  "Off-road utility vehicle" or "ORV" as defined in Section 321I.1 of the Code of Iowa, amended. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.020 - Manner of operation-General requirements. 
    No person shall operate an all-terrain vehicle (ATV) or off-road utility vehicle (ORV) within the city in violation of the provisions of Chapter 321G and 321I of the Code of Iowa or rules established by the Natural Resource Commission of the Iowa Department of Natural Resources governing their registration, numbering, equipment and manner of operation; or the provisions of this chapter hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.030 - Registration required. 
    The owner of an ATV or ORV shall maintain a current Iowa Department of Natural Resources registration title through the county recorder. The registration certification shall be kept in the vehicle or on the person of the operator of said ATV or ORV when in use and shall be provided to a law enforcement officer upon request. The owner shall display the registration decal or nonresident user permit decal as specified in the Code of Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.040 - Registration exemption. 
    The registration requirements of this chapter shall not apply to an ATV or ORV operated for purposes as defined in Section 321.234A of the Code of Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.050 - Liability insurance required. 
    The owner of the ATV or ORV shall maintain financial liability insurance coverage covering operation of said ATV or ORV within city limits. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.060 - Equipment. 
    All ATVs and ORVs shall be equipped with the following: 
1.  Brakes; 
2.  Brake lights; 
3.  At least one mirror so located as to reflect to the operator a view to the rear of the vehicle of a distance of two hundred feet; 
4.  Proper working of all applicable safety equipment on the ATV or ORV, including safety belts if said safety equipment was manufactured with the vehicle; 
5.  Suitable and effective muffling devices that comply with the sound level standards and testing procedures established by the Society of Automotive Engineers under SAE J1287. An ATV or ORV shall not be operated in a manner that emits noise in excess of ninety-six decibels as measured on the A scale of SAE J1287; 
6.  A lighted headlight when operated from sunset to sunrise and at such other times as conditions provide insufficient lighting to render clearly discernable persons and vehicles at a distance of five hundred feet ahead; 
7.  A lighted taillight when operated from sunset to sunrise and at such other times as conditions provide insufficient lighting to render clearly discernable persons and vehicles at a distance of five hundred feet behind; 
8.  Any other safety equipment which may be required on ATV or ORV by Chapter 321 of the Code of Iowa. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.070 - Operator regulations. 
    The following regulations shall apply to all operators of ATV and ORVs within the city. 
1.  Any operator of an ATV or ORV shall possess a valid driver's license and be at least eighteen years of age or older; 
2.  Any operator of an ATV or ORV must observe all state and city traffic laws and regulations to the same extent as any other motor vehicle when operating an ATV or ORV within the city limits; 
3.  Operators shall signal of intentions to turn right or left either by means of a hand and arm signal or by a mechanical or electrical direction signal device as specified in Chapter 321 of the Code of Iowa; 
4.  No person shall operate an ATV or ORV with more persons on the vehicle than the ATV or ORV was originally designed to carry; 
5.  No person shall leave an ATV or ORV unattended on public property while the motor is running or the keys are in the ignition switch. Operators shall comply with all parking regulations in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.080 - Location of operation. 
1.  City Streets. ATV and ORVs are prohibited from being operated on the following streets, except to make a direct crossing of said streets: 
a.  U.S. Highway 169, including any portion of the right-of-way; 
b.  U.S. Highway 18, including any portion of the right-of-way. 
2.  "Parking". No ATV or ORV shall be operated upon that portion of a street right-of-way between the curb or edge of street paving and the sidewalk referred to as the "parking" area except for the purpose of snow removal, maintenance or landscaping activities of the abutting property, or to park the ATV or ORV in compliance with all parking regulations of the city; 
3.  Sidewalks. No ATV or ORV shall be operated on public sidewalks except for the purposes of snow removal, other sidewalk maintenance, gardening and/or lawn work, or the direct crossing of the sidewalk; 
4.  City Cemeteries. No ATV or ORV shall be operated on roadways or other areas in cemeteries located in the city; 
5.  City Parks, Trails, and Other Land Owned by the City of Algona. No ATV or ORV shall operate on any public recreational, bike or walking trail, city park, or other city owned property except for those areas designed to allow use of motor vehicles; 
6.  Private Property. No ATV or ORV shall be operated upon private property without the express consent of the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.090 - Community events-Exception. 
    The Algona chief of police may grant exceptions and allow an ATV or ORV to be used on a city street or any other city property by community and civic organizations for community events. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
10.72.100 - Accident reports. 
    The operator of an ATV or ORV involved in an accident within the limits of this city shall file a report as and when required by the Code of Iowa and the City of Algona. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 10-15-2018) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapter 12.04 - STREET NAMES 
Sections: 

12.04.010 - New street naming procedures. 
    New streets shall be assigned names in accordance with the following: 
A.  Extension of Existing Street. Streets added to the city that are natural extensions of existing streets shall be assigned the name of the existing street; 
B.  Planning Commission. Proposed street names shall be referred to the planning commission for review and recommendation; 
C.  Ordinance. All street names, except streets named as a part of a subdivision or platting procedure, shall be named by ordinance. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0401) 
12.04.020 - Street name change procedures. 
    The council may by ordinance change the name of a street. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0402) 
12.04.030 - Recording street names. 
    Following adoption of an ordinance naming or changing the name of a street, the mayor and clerk shall certify and file a copy thereof with the county recorder and county auditor. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0403) 
12.04.040 - Official street name map-Adopted. 
    Streets within the city are named as shown on the official street name map which is adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this chapter. The official street name map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor, and bearing the seal of the city under the following words: "This is to certify that this is the Official Street Name Map referred to in Section 12.04.040 of the Municipal Code of Algona, Iowa, 1988." 
(Prior code § 8-1.0404) 
12.04.050 - Official street name map-Amendments. 
A.  If in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes are made in street names, such changes shall be entered on the official street name map promptly after the amendment has been approved by the governing body with an entry on the official street name map as follows: 
 "On (date) , by official action of the city council, the following change(s) were made in the Official Street Name Map: (brief description) , which entry shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the clerk. 
B.  No amendment to this chapter which involves naming or changing the name of a street shall become effective until after such change and entry has been made on the map. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0405) 
Chapter 12.08 - STREET VACATIONS 
Sections: 

12.08.010 - Council authority to to vacate. 
    When in the judgment of the council it would be in the best interest of the city to vacate a street or alley, or portion thereof, they may do so in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0501) 
12.08.020 - Proposal review. 
    Any proposal to vacate a street or alley shall be referred by the council to the planning commission for its study and recommendation prior to further consideration by the council. The planning commission shall submit a written report including recommendations to the council within thirty days of the date the proposed vacation was referred to it. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0502) 
12.08.030 - Public hearing-Notice. 
    The council shall cause to be published a notice of public hearing at which time the proposal to vacate shall be considered. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0503) 
12.08.040 - Approval criteria determinations. 
    No street or alley, or portion thereof, shall be vacated unless the council finds that: 
A.  Public Use. The street or alley proposed to be vacated is not needed for the use of the public, and, therefore, its maintenance at public expense is no longer justified; 
B.  Abutting Property. The proposed vacation will not deny owners of property abutting on the street or alley reasonable access to their property. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0504) 
12.08.050 - Approval by passage of resolution. 
    When in the judgment of the council it would be in the best interest of the city to dispose of a vacated street or alley, or portion thereof, they may do so by resolution following notice and hearing. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0505) 
12.08.060 - Disposal by gift limited. 
    The city may not dispose of a vacated street or alley, or portion thereof, by gift except to a governmental body for a public purpose. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0506) 
12.08.070 - Effect on existing vacations. 
    Whereas, the city has heretofore by ordinance vacated certain streets and alleys, the action of the council in vacating the streets and alleys is ratified, approved and confirmed. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0507) 
12.08.080 - Filing and indexing. 
    Copies of all ordinances vacating streets or alleys are on file in the office of the clerk. An index to such ordinances vacating streets or alleys shall be included and maintained. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0508) 
12.08.090 - Recordkeeping. 
    The clerk shall maintain a book in which shall be kept a record of the ordinances by which streets and alleys were vacated. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0509) 
Chapter 12.12 - STREET AND SIDEWALK GRADES 
Sections: 

12.12.010 - Existing grades confirmed as official. 
    The grades of all streets, alleys and sidewalks, which have been heretofore established by ordinance are confirmed, ratified and established as official grades. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0601) 
12.12.020 - Maintenance of records. 
    The clerk shall maintain a record of all established grades and furnish information concerning such grades upon request. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0602) 
Chapter 12.16 - STREET MAINTENANCE AND USE REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Removal of warning devices. 
    It is unlawful for a person to wilfully remove, throw down, destroy or carry away from any highway, street, alley, avenue or bridge any lamp, obstruction, guard or other article or things, or extinguish any lamp or other light, erected or placed thereupon for the purpose of guarding or enclosing unsafe or dangerous places in such highway, street, alley, avenue or bridge without the consent of the person in control thereof. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0101) 
12.16.020 - Obstructing or defacing streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to obstruct, deface or injure any public road in any manner. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0102) 
12.16.030 - Placing debris on streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to throw or deposit on any street any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, trash, garbage, rubbish, litter, offal or any other debris, or any other substance likely to injure any person, animal or vehicle. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0103) 
12.16.040 - Injuring new pavement. 
    It is be unlawful for any person to wilfully injure new pavement in any street, alley or sidewalk by wilfully driving, walking or making marks on such pavement before it is ready for use. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0104) 
12.16.050 - Excavations-Permit required. 
    No person shall dig, excavate or in any manner disturb any street in the city, unless such person shall first obtain a permit therefor as hereinafter provided or as provided in other sections of this code. 
A.  Application. Before such permit shall be granted, the person shall file with the clerk a written application. The application shall give an exact description of the property, by lot and street number, in front of or along which it is desired to excavate, state the purpose and for whom and by whom the excavation is to be made, and who will be responsible for the refilling of said ditch and restoration of the street surface. 
B.  Backfill. That portion of any excavation lying within the travelled roadway shall be backfilled with gravel and all excess material promptly removed. 
C.  Fee. There shall be an excavation permit fee payable by the applicant in the amount as established by resolution of the council. In the event such fee is not paid by the applicant the clerk shall certify such delinquent fee to the county auditor for assessment against the property described in the application for collection in the manner of other taxes. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0105) 
12.16.060 - Dumping snow. 
    It is unlawful for any person to throw, push or place or cause to be thrown, pushed or placed, any ice or snow from private property, sidewalks or driveways onto the traveled way of streets; except where, in the cleaning of large commercial drives in the business district it is absolutely necessary to move the snow onto the streets temporarily, such accumulation shall be removed promptly by the property owner or the owner's agent, and only after first making arrangements for such prompt removal of the accumulation at the owner's cost within a reasonably short period of time. It is also unlawful for any person to throw, push or place or cause to be thrown, pushed or placed, any ice or snow from private property, sidewalks or driveways onto a neighbor's street right-of-way area located between the curb and sidewalk. 
(Ord. 934 § 1, 2006) 
12.16.070 - Playing in streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to coast, sled, skateboard or play games on streets or highways except in the areas blocked off by the chief of police for such purposes. 
(Ord. 732 § 1, 1988: prior code § 8-1.0107) 
12.16.080 - Traveling on barricaded streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to travel or operate any vehicle on any street or public way temporarily closed by barricades, lights, signs or flares placed thereon by the authority or permission of any city official, police officer or member of the fire department. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0108) 
12.16.090 - Use of parking strips. 
    It is unlawful to temporarily or permanently park, store or place any car, truck, vehicle, junk or any other goods, wares and merchandise of any kind upon any street parking without permission of the council. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0109) 
12.16.100 - Use of streets for business purposes. 
    It is unlawful to park, store or place any machinery, or any other goods, wares and merchandise of any kind upon any street for the purpose of storage, exhibition, sale or offering same for sale, without first obtaining written permission from the director of public works. 
(Ord. 722 § 1, 1987: prior code § 8-1.0110) 
12.16.110 - Washing vehicles in streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use any public sidewalk or street for the purpose of washing or cleaning any automobile, truck equipment, or any vehicle of any kind when such work is done for hire or as a business. This shall not be construed to prevent any person from washing or cleaning his own vehicle or equipment when it is lawfully parked in the street. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0111) 
12.16.120 - Burning in streets or adjacent areas. 
    No person shall burn any trash, leaves, rubbish or other combustible material in any curb and gutter or on any paved or surfaced street. 
(Prior code § 8-1.0112) 
12.16.130 - Yard waste on streets prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place or discharge or cause to be placed or discharged any yard waste onto the traveled way of streets. "Yard waste" means organic debris such as grass, grass clippings, leaves, garden waste, prunings, weeds, brush and tree branches. 
(Ord. 957 § 1, 2008) 
Chapter 12.20 - SIDEWALK MAINTENANCE AND USE REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - Definitions. 
    For use in this chapter the following terms are defined: 
A.  "Established grade" means that grade established by the city for the particular area in which a sidewalk is to be constructed. 
B.  "Sidewalk" means all permanent public walks in business, residential or suburban areas. 
(Prior code § 8-2.01) 
12.20.020 - Responsibility for maintenance. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owners to maintain in a safe and hazard free condition any sidewalk outside the lot and property lines and inside the curblines or travelled portion of the public street. 
(Prior code § 8-2.02) 
12.20.030 - Failure to maintain-Personal injuries. 
    If the abutting property owner does not maintain sidewalks as required and action is brought against the city for personal injuries alleged to have been caused by its negligence, the city may notify in writing any person by whose negligence it claims the injury was caused. The notice shall state the pendency of the action, the name of the plaintiff, the name and location of the court where the action is pending, a brief statement of the alleged facts from which the cause arose, that the city believes that the person notified is liable to it for any judgment rendered against the city, and asking the person to appear and defend. A judgment obtained in the suit is conclusive in any action by the city against any person so notified, as to the existence of the defect or other cause of the injury or damage, as to the liability of the city to the plaintiff in the first named action, and as to the amount of the damage or injury. The city may maintain an action against the person notified to recover the amount of the judgment together with all the expenses incurred by the city in the suit. 
(Prior code § 8-2.03) 
12.20.040 - Failure to maintain-Repair orders by city. 
    If the abutting property owner does not maintain sidewalks as required the council may serve notice on such owner, by certified mail, requiring him to repair, replace or reconstruct sidewalks within a reasonable time and if such action is not completed within the time stated in the notice the council may require the work to be done and assess the costs against the abutting property for collection in the same manner as a property tax. 
(Prior code § 8-2.04) 
12.20.050 - Sidewalk construction standards. 
    Sidewalks repaired, replaced or constructed shall meet the standards set forth in the Statewide Urban Design and Specifications for the State of Iowa. Residential sidewalks shall be located with the inner edge (edge nearest the abutting private property) two feet from the property line, unless the council shall establish a different distance due to circumstances. 
(Prior code § 8-2.05) 
(Ord. No. 959, § 1, 5-4-2009) 
12.20.060 - Removal of snow or ice. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owners to remove all snow, ice and accumulations, whether from natural causes or otherwise, promptly from sidewalks. If a property owner does not remove such snow, ice or accumulations within a reasonable time, reasonable time deemed to be twenty-four hours after such snow, ice or other accumulations have been deposited, whether from natural causes or otherwise, the city may do so and assess the costs against the property owner for collection in the same manner as a property tax. 
(Ord. 699 § 1, 1985: prior code § 8-2.06) 
12.20.070 - Encroachments-Council approval required. 
    It is unlawful for a person to erect or maintain any stairs or steps to any building upon any part of any sidewalk without permission by resolution of the council. 
(Prior code § 8-2.07) 
12.20.080 - Unlawful acts designated. 
    It is unlawful for a person to: 
A.  Stairs and Railings. Construct or build a stairway or passageway to any cellar or basement by occupying any part of the sidewalk, or to enclose any portion of a sidewalk with a railing without permission by resolution of the council; 
B.  Openings. Keep open any cellar door, grating or cover to any vault on any sidewalk except while in actual use with adequate guards to protect the public; 
C.  Protect Openings. Neglect to properly protect or barricade all openings on or within six feet of any sidewalk. 
(Prior code § 8-2.08) 
12.20.090 - Fires. 
    It is unlawful for a person to make a fire of any kind on any sidewalk. 
(Prior code § 8-2.09) 
12.20.100 - Fuel accumulations. 
    It is unlawful for a person to place or allow any fuel to remain upon any sidewalk. 
(Prior code § 8-2.10) 
12.20.110 - Defacing. 
    It is unlawful for a person to scatter or place any paste, paint or writing on any sidewalk. 
(Prior code § 8-2.11) 
12.20.120 - Throwing debris and littering. 
    It is unlawful for a person to throw or deposit on any sidewalk any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, trash, garbage, rubbish, litter, offal or any other debris, or any other substance likely to injure any person, animal or vehicle. 
(Prior code § 8-2.12) 
12.20.130 - Display of merchandise. 
    It is unlawful for a person to place upon or above any sidewalk, any goods or merchandise for sale or for display in such a manner as to interfere with the free and uninterrupted passage of pedestrians on the sidewalk; in no case shall more than three feet of the sidewalk next to the building be occupied for such purposes. 
(Prior code § 8-2.13) 
12.20.140 - Sales stands. 
    It is unlawful for a person to erect or keep any stand for the sale of fruit, vegetables or other substances or commodities on any sidewalk without first obtaining a written permit from the council. 
(Prior code § 8-2.14) 
Chapter 12.24 - TREES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1030, § 1, adopted May 15, 2017, amended Ch. 12.24 in its entirety, with the exception of §§ 12.24.010 and 12.24.020 which remain as codified by Ord. 821, to read as herein set out. Former §§ 12.24.030-12.24.120, pertained to simialr subject matter, and derived from: Ord. 821 adopted in 1995; and prior code §§ 6-2.0201-6-2.0205. 

Article I. - General Provisions 

12.24.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance and removal of trees, shrubs and other plants within the city. 
(Ord. 821 § 1 (part), 1995) 
12.24.020 - Definitions. 
    For use in this chapter, the following terms are defined: 
    "Large tree" means a tree that may attain a height of forty-five feet or more. 
    "Low growing tree" means a tree that will maintain a maximum height of thirty feet or less. 
    "Park" means all public parks having individual names. 
    "Parking" means that part of the right-of-way in the city not covered by sidewalk and lying between the lot line and the curbline; or, on unpaved streets, that part of the street, avenue, or highway lying between the lot line and that portion of the street usually traveled by vehicular traffic. 
    "Public works director" means the public works director of the city or his or her designee. The public works director shall have the following general powers and duties: 
1.  To direct, manage, supervise and control all planting, removal, maintenance and protection of all trees and shrubs on public areas; 
2.  To guard all trees and shrubs within the city to prevent the spread of disease or pests and to eliminate dangerous conditions that may affect the life, health or safety of persons or property; 
3.  Such other powers and duties as are provided by state law and/or city ordinance. 
    "Tree topping" means the practice of cutting the main trunk of a tree to limit the height of the tree. 
(Ord. 821 § 1 (part), 1995) 
12.24.030 - Tree board. 
A.  Establishment. There is hereby created and established a tree board for the City of Algona, which shall consist of five members, citizens and residents of this city, who shall be appointed by the council. Members of the board shall serve without compensation. The term of the tree board shall be three years, except that the term of two members appointed to the first board shall be only one year and the term for two members of the first board shall be for two years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his or her successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. The public works director and street superintendent will serve as ex-officio members of the tree board. 
B.  Duties. The tree board may develop and maintain a comprehensive plan for the management of the city, including planning, tree planting, and maintenance programs for all public trees. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.040 - Permits. 
    No person shall plant or remove any tree on any street, parking or municipal-owned property without first filing an application and procuring a permit from the public works director, who shall determine whether a permit will be issued. The person receiving the permit shall follow the regulations set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.050 - Planting restrictions. 
    No tree shall be planted on any street or parking except in accordance with the following: 
A.  Alignment. All trees hereafter planted in any street shall be planted in the parking at a point halfway between the sidewalk and curbline. In the event no tree line has been established, or the existing tree line is not halfway between the sidewalk and curbline, the public works director shall determine the tree line or the place where the tree line shall be planted. 
B.  Location. No tree shall be planted closer than five feet from the curbline or outer line of the sidewalk. Parkings must be at least ten feet in width for large tree plantings and at least eight feet wide for low growing trees. All trees should have a spacing of at least thirty feet from other trees or a greater distance depending on the species. No street tree shall be planted within thirty feet of the point where property lines intersect at the corner of street intersections. No street tree shall be planted within ten linear feet of alleys, driveways, hydrants, water curb boxes, transformers, poles, telephone junction boxes or manholes. No tree shall be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire unless it is a low growing tree approved by the public works director. No tree shall be planted within five lateral feet of any underground utility. No tree shall be planted within twenty-five linear feet or the width of spread of the mature tree, whichever is greater, from street lights. 
C.  Prohibited Trees. No person shall hereinafter plant in any street or parking any fruit-bearing trees, coniferous trees or any tree of the kinds commonly known as Black Locust, Bolleana Poplar, Boxelder, Catalpa, Cottonless Cottonwoods, Cottonwood, Evergreen, Green Ash, Mountain Ash, Mulberry, Norway Maple, Siberian (Chinese) Elm, Russian Olive, Silver Maple, Lombardy Poplar, Tree of Heaven, Weeping Birch, Willow or White Poplar. 
D.  The public works director is hereby authorized to establish specific standards governing the planting, selection of species, support, treatment of root systems, trimming, spraying, removal, filling of cavities and bracing for all trees and plant materials in, on or within public places. 
E.  Minimum Tree Size. All trees planted on any street or parking shall be at least six feet tall when planted. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.060 - Maintenance. 
    In the event a tree planted in the street or parking is not being properly cared for, the city may perform work on the trees. The owner or agent of the abutting property shall maintain trees on the abutting property that are overhanging the street or parking in such a manner so that all branches will be at least fifteen feet above the surface of the street and eight feet above the sidewalks. If the abutting property owner fails to trim the trees as required in the preceding sentence, the public works director may within a reasonable time initiate abatement procedures as outlined in Sections 8.12.030 through 8.12.110 of the Algona Municipal Code. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or city department to top any tree growing along the street or alley right-of-way, tree growing in a park or other tree growing on public property. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical shall be exempted from this article at the determination of the public works director. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.070 - Removal of trees. 
    The public works director shall remove, upon approval of the tree board, any tree on the streets of the city which interferes with the making of improvements or with travel thereon. He shall additionally remove any trees on the parking or street, not on private property, which have become diseased, or which constitute a danger to the public, or which may otherwise be declared a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.080 - Nuisance and abatement. 
    All trees planted in violation of, or not maintained in strict compliance with the provisions of this chapter, or that are dead, diseased, or dangerous are declared to constitute a public nuisance. The public works director may within a reasonable time initiate abatement procedures as outlined in Sections 8.12.030 through 8.12.110 of the Algona Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.090 - Protection of trees. 
    No person shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, attach any rope, wire, nails, advertising posters, or other contrivance to any tree; allow any gaseous, liquid, chemical, or solid substance that is harmful to such trees to come in contact with them; or set fire or permit fire to burn when such fire or the heat will injure any portion of any tree. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.100 - Appeals. 
    Any person who receives an order from the public works director and objects to all or a part thereof, may, within five days of receipt thereof, notify the public works director and tree board, in writing, of the nature of the objection and request a hearing thereon. The board, at its next meeting shall review the facts and affirm, modify or revoke the order. 
    Within five days after such hearing, the public works director shall notify the appellant of the board's decision. Appellant will then have an additional five days to notify the public works director, in writing, of an appeal of the board's decision to the city council. The council, at its next meeting shall review the facts and affirm, modify or revoke the order. Within five days, after such hearing, the public works director shall notify the appellant of the final decision. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.110 - Enforcement. 
    The public works director is hereby charged with the responsibility for the enforcement of this chapter and may serve notice to any person in violation thereof or institute legal proceedings as may be required, and the city attorney is hereby authorized to institute appropriate proceedings to that end. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
12.24.120 - Conflict resolution between tree and structures. 
    Where sidewalk or curb damage due to tree roots occurs, every effort shall be made to correct the problem without removing or damaging the tree. The public works director shall be responsible for developing or approving corrective measures. 
(Ord. No. 1030, § 1, 5-15-2017) 
Chapter 12.28 - BARRICADES ON STREETS 
Sections: 

12.28.010 - Permanent barricades. 
    Permanent barricades shall be located at the following places: 
A.  On East Maple Street, halfway between North Main Street and North Johnson Street. 
(Ord. 754 § 1 (part), 1990) 
12.28.020 - Temporary barricades. 
    It is unlawful for any person to travel or operate any motorized vehicle on any street or public way temporarily closed by barricades. This includes, but is not limited to, temporary barricades that are placed as follows: 
A.  Overmeyer Drive. Temporary barricades shall be placed on Overmeyer Drive north of the swimming pool on days when the swimming pool is being used. The portion of Overmeyer Drive which shall be barricaded begins at a point west of the intersection of South Thorington and Overmeyer Drive, then west to a point east of the intersection of the access street located west of the swimming pool and Overmeyer Drive. This area shall be barricaded, if the swimming pool is being used, from one p.m. to nine p.m. daily beginning with the Saturday before Memorial Day up to and including the Saturday before Labor Day. If the swimming pool is not being used on a particular day, and the street is not barricaded, then it shall not be unlawful to travel on that portion of Overmeyer Drive. 
(Ord. 754 § 1 (part), 1990) 
12.28.030 - Limited-access barricades. 
    It is unlawful for any person to travel or operate any motorized vehicle north of the barricade located on North Garfield Street. The barricade shall be located five hundred twenty nine feet north of the center point of the intersection of Pine Street and North Garfield Street. However, access to North Garfield Street located north of the barricade shall be available to any property owner that uses said portion of North Garfield Street for an access to their property. 
(Ord. 790 § 1, 1992) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapter 13.04 - SEWER SERVICE SYSTEM 
Article I. - General Provisions 

13.04.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish rules and regulations governing the treatment and disposal of sanitary sewage within the city in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0101) 
13.04.020 - Definitions. 
    For use in this chapter, unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the following terms are defined: 
1.  "BOD (biochemical oxygen demand)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at twenty degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter or parts per million. 
2.  "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
3.  "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
4.  "City" means the city of Algona, Iowa. 
5.  "Combined sewer" means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
6.  "Contributor" means any person responsible for the production of domestic, commercial or industrial waste which is directly or indirectly discharged into the public sewer system. 
7.  "Garbage" means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
8.  "Industrial wastes" means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade or business as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
9.  "Inspector" means the person duly authorized by the council to inspect and approve the installation of building sewers and their connections to the public sewer system; and to inspect such sewage as may be discharged therefrom. 
10.  "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
11.  "pH" means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
12.  "Private sewer" means a sanitary building drain and sewer privately owned and not directly controlled by public authority. 
13.  "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
14.  "Public sewer" means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
15.  "Sanitary sewage" means sewage discharging from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings (including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings, factories or institutions, and free from storm, surface water and industrial waste. 
16.  "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
17.  "Sewage" means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and stormwaters as may be present. 
18.  "Sewage treatment plant" means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
19.  "Sewage works" or "sewage system" means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
20.  "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
21.  "Sewer rental" means any and all charges, rates, fees or rentals levied against and payable by contributors, as consideration for the servicing of such contributors by the sewer system. 
22.  "Slug" means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen minutes more than five times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
23.  "Storm drain" or "storm sewer" means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
24.  "Superintendent" means the superintendent of public improvements of the city or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
25.  "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
26.  "Watercourse" means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0102) 
13.04.030 - Superintendent-Appointment-Powers and duties. 
    The superintendent of the city sewage system shall be appointed by the council and exercise the following powers and duties: 
A.  Operation and Maintenance. He shall operate and maintain the city sewage system; 
B.  Inspection and Tests. He shall conduct necessary inspections and tests to assure compliance with the provisions of this chapter; 
C.  Records. He shall maintain a complete and accurate record of all sewers, sewage connections and manholes constructed showing the location and grades thereof. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0103) 
13.04.040 - Administration-Right of entry. 
    The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall abide by all state and federal laws before entering the properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The superintendent or his representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(Amended during 1988 codification: prior code § 3-3.0107) 
13.04.050 - Sewer connection required. 
    The owners of any houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city, are required to install, at such owner's expense, suitable toilet facilities therein and a building sewer connecting such facilities directly with the proper public sewer, and to maintain the same all in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, such compliance to be completed within ninety days after the date of the official notice from the city to do so; provided, however, that the city council may grant a variance in certain situations and allow the owner to construct a private sewer system as set forth in Article IV of this chapter. The owner shall be responsible for the cost of constructing the sanitary sewer from the owner's property line to the place where it would connect with the public sewer. Any sewer main installed in the public right-of-way shall meet city specifications and shall become a part of the public sewer system once it has been constructed. 
(Ord. 851 § 1, 1998) 
13.04.060 - Service outside city limits. 
    The owners of property outside the corporate limits of the city so situated that it may be served by the city sewer system may apply to the council for permission to connect to the public sewer upon the terms and conditions stipulated by resolution of the council. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0106) 
13.04.070 - Owner liability limitations. 
    While performing the necessary work on private property, the superintendent or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the owner or occupant and the owner or occupant shall be held harmless for injury or death to city employees and the city shall indemnify the owner or occupant against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the owner or occupant and growing out of any gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the owner or occupant to maintain safe conditions. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0108) 
113.04.080 - Easement access-Authority. 
    The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0109) 
13.04.090 - Unlawful acts designated. 
    No person shall do, or allow, any of the following: 
A.  Damage Sewer System. Maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewer system; 
B.  Downspouts. Connect a roof downspout, exterior foundation drain, area-way drain, or other source of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer; 
C.  Manholes. Open or enter any manhole of the sewer system, except by authority of the superintendent; 
D.  Objectionable Wastes. Place or deposit in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste; 
E.  Septic Tanks. Construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage except as provided in this chapter; 
F.  Untreated Discharge. Discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under its jurisdiction, any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0104) 
13.04.100 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The following special penalty provisions shall apply to violations of this chapter: 
A.  Notice of Violation. Any person found to be violating any provision of this chapter except subsections A, C and D of Section 13.04.090 of this article, shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
B.  Continuing Violations. Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection A of this section, shall be guilty of a municipal infraction. Each day in which any violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense. 
C.  Liability Imposed. Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0110) 
(Ord. 998, § 2, 10-7-2013) 
Article II. - Building Sewers and Connections 

13.04.110 - Permit-Required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connection with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent in accordance with the provisions of Sections 13.04.120 through 13.04.150 of this article. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0201 (part)) 
13.04.120 - Permit-Application. 
    Any person desiring to make a connection with the sewer system shall first file with the clerk an application therefor, in writing setting forth the location and description of the property to be connected with the sewer system and for what purpose the sewer is to be used. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0201(1)) 
13.04.130 - Submission of plans and specifications. 
    The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specification or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0201(2)) 
13.04.140 - Permit-Fee. 
    The person who makes the application shall pay a connection fee to the clerk in a minimum amount of one hundred seventy-five dollars. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0201(3)) 
13.04.150 - Permit-Issuance conditions. 
    All permits to connect with sewer shall be given upon the express condition that the council may at any time before the work is completed revoke and annul the same and no party interested shall have a right to claim damages in consequence of any such permits being revoked or annulled. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0201(4)) 
13.04.160 - Connection requirements. 
    Any connection with a public sanitary sewer must be made under the direct supervision of the superintendent and in accordance with the provisions of Sections 13.04.170 through 13.04.290 of this article. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0203 (part)) 
13.04.170 - Old building sewers usable when. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0203(1)) 
13.04.180 - Separate connections required-Exceptions. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every occupied building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway. In such cases the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0203(2)) 
13.04.190 - Cleanout required. 
    A cleanout Y with plug shall be provided inside the basement proper or at a location approved by the superintendent. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0203(3)) 
13.04.200 - Installation and placement. 
    When possible, building sewers should be laid at least ten feet horizontally from a water service. The horizontal separation may be less, provided the water service line is located at one side and at least twelve inches above the top of the building sewer and is constructed of cast iron soil pipe with leaded joints. 
(Prior code § 3-3.0203(4)) 
13.04.210 - Size-Excepted peak sewage flow. 
    Building sewers shall be sized for the peak expected sewage flow from the building with a minimum building sewer size of six inches.
